episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:03.131 --> 00:00:04.467
Welcome, ladies and gentlemen.

2
00:00:04.467 --> 00:00:08.385
If you're looking for ITIL service
offerings and agreement information,

3
00:00:08.385 --> 00:00:12.181
then you're in the perfect place
because we have expert ITIL trainer Mr.

4
00:00:12.181 --> 00:00:13.570
Terry Decker in studios.

5
00:00:13.570 --> 00:00:14.690
How are you doing today, Terry?

6
00:00:14.690 --> 00:00:16.080
>> Doing super, Cherokee.

7
00:00:16.080 --> 00:00:18.640
>> So Terry, what are we gonna be
looking at in this particular series

8
00:00:18.640 --> 00:00:19.370
that's coming up?

9
00:00:19.370 --> 00:00:20.872
>> Well, service offerings and

10
00:00:20.872 --> 00:00:24.365
agreements is one of the capability
modules in the ITIL curriculum.

11
00:00:24.365 --> 00:00:28.600
Some of the modules are based on
lifecycle stages individually.

12
00:00:28.600 --> 00:00:33.160
The capability modules draw from
multiple stages in the lifecycle.

13
00:00:33.160 --> 00:00:37.620
SOA, Service Offerings and Agreements,
it borrows from service strategy and

14
00:00:37.620 --> 00:00:42.330
service thine and combined processes
in some operational context.

15
00:00:42.330 --> 00:00:46.220
We'll be looking at seven different
processes within service strategy and

16
00:00:46.220 --> 00:00:50.730
service design that deal with how
you appropriately offer services

17
00:00:50.730 --> 00:00:54.730
to customers and how you broke those
agreements with those customers and

18
00:00:54.730 --> 00:00:57.630
maintain your supplier contracts as well.

19
00:00:57.630 --> 00:01:04.120
So, it's a good course in depth and in
breadth, it also prepares you for an exam.

20
00:01:04.120 --> 00:01:08.140
We spend a lot of time doing some exam
preparation for this, and successful

21
00:01:08.140 --> 00:01:12.940
passing of the exam gets you four credits
towards your IT expert credentials.

22
00:01:12.940 --> 00:01:13.853
>> So ladies and gentlemen,

23
00:01:13.853 --> 00:01:15.852
I hope you enjoy the course
that we've prepared for you.

24
00:01:15.852 --> 00:01:18.313
Stay tune for more information.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.002 --> 00:00:03.239
Welcome to ITVProTV.

2
00:00:03.239 --> 00:00:10.520
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITVProTv.

3
00:00:10.520 --> 00:00:14.849
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to
your ITIL Service Offerings and

4
00:00:14.849 --> 00:00:16.440
Agreements series.

5
00:00:16.440 --> 00:00:18.610
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.610 --> 00:00:22.520
In this episode we'll really
just kinda set the stage and

7
00:00:22.520 --> 00:00:26.310
lay down the logistics and
expectations of this particular show.

8
00:00:26.310 --> 00:00:29.170
With us today in studio we have Mr.
Terry Decker.

9
00:00:29.170 --> 00:00:30.560
Thank you for joining us Terry.

10
00:00:30.560 --> 00:00:31.290
>> Glad to be here Cherokee.

11
00:00:31.290 --> 00:00:34.940
>> So what are we gonna be looking
at when we talk about ITIL SOA.

12
00:00:34.940 --> 00:00:39.030
>> Well service offers and agreements
borrows from a couple of the ITIL books,

13
00:00:39.030 --> 00:00:40.960
service strategy and service design.

14
00:00:40.960 --> 00:00:46.140
There's many topics as you can
see here on the PowerPoint here.

15
00:00:46.140 --> 00:00:47.290
Many topics to cover.

16
00:00:47.290 --> 00:00:49.740
Some of these came from
a service strategy book,

17
00:00:49.740 --> 00:00:52.580
some of them came from
a service design book, right.

18
00:00:52.580 --> 00:00:58.030
Portfolio management, you came recall,
service level management, service catalog,

19
00:00:58.030 --> 00:00:59.890
demand management, etc.

20
00:00:59.890 --> 00:01:03.640
These are processes within
The ITIL framework, and

21
00:01:03.640 --> 00:01:04.590
we're gonna talk about these.

22
00:01:04.590 --> 00:01:08.410
We'll also talk about roles and
responsibilities, and considerations for

23
00:01:08.410 --> 00:01:12.460
technology, and
the implementation of these processes.

24
00:01:12.460 --> 00:01:16.850
To do so, we'll also kinda set the stage
of what is service strategy trying to get

25
00:01:16.850 --> 00:01:19.630
done, what is service design
trying to get done, and then,

26
00:01:19.630 --> 00:01:24.040
these processes come together
to satisfy those goals.

27
00:01:24.040 --> 00:01:26.070
Of course we're also preparing for
an exam.

28
00:01:27.420 --> 00:01:30.930
It's not just enough to get ready for
work,

29
00:01:30.930 --> 00:01:34.210
this course is also designed
to get you ready for an exam.

30
00:01:34.210 --> 00:01:38.560
If it's your first intermediate
you're gonna find that

31
00:01:38.560 --> 00:01:42.610
this course work is a quite
a bit different than foundation.

32
00:01:42.610 --> 00:01:48.660
Foundation is rote memorization,
memorizing things and understanding it.

33
00:01:48.660 --> 00:01:51.290
At this level of learning
we're gonna be applying and

34
00:01:51.290 --> 00:01:54.550
analyzing with particular
focus on analysis.

35
00:01:54.550 --> 00:01:59.140
So the way this exam plays out, is you're
going to be reading a scenario and

36
00:01:59.140 --> 00:02:03.620
then using your knowledge of ITL,
things you've already remembered and

37
00:02:03.620 --> 00:02:07.970
understand, using that knowledge,
you're going to analyze the scenario and

38
00:02:07.970 --> 00:02:10.897
then try to pick the best
answer out of four choices.

39
00:02:11.910 --> 00:02:15.040
>> So Terry, I don't have any
background information with ITIL.

40
00:02:15.040 --> 00:02:17.140
I haven't sat through
that foundations course.

41
00:02:17.140 --> 00:02:19.670
Would you recommend doing so
at this time if I haven't,

42
00:02:19.670 --> 00:02:21.440
to, you know, to others out there.

43
00:02:21.440 --> 00:02:23.940
>> I recommend it for
a couple of reasons, one is requirement.

44
00:02:23.940 --> 00:02:29.150
It's an official prerequisite to have the
foundation exam before you get credit for

45
00:02:29.150 --> 00:02:33.630
the service strategy exam or for any,
the intermediate exams, I should say.

46
00:02:33.630 --> 00:02:35.350
So it is a requirement.

47
00:02:35.350 --> 00:02:36.580
It's also recommended.

48
00:02:36.580 --> 00:02:39.920
These exams are going to assume
you have that knowledge.

49
00:02:39.920 --> 00:02:41.040
And without that knowledge,

50
00:02:41.040 --> 00:02:44.610
you'd be swimming around in the dark
quite a bit on the intermediate levels.

51
00:02:44.610 --> 00:02:47.280
>> Well, at least we have you
here to help us guide the way.

52
00:02:47.280 --> 00:02:49.513
>> Yeah, that's right, shine some light.

53
00:02:49.513 --> 00:02:50.795
I shall do that.

54
00:02:50.795 --> 00:02:54.065
Great, so,
as we look at how we're gonna learn this,

55
00:02:54.065 --> 00:02:56.400
of course I'm gonna be presenting.

56
00:02:56.400 --> 00:03:00.450
I'm gonna be using theory and lecture
approach and giving real world examples.

57
00:03:00.450 --> 00:03:05.204
I have over 12 year of experience
in IT service management with

58
00:03:05.204 --> 00:03:09.405
ITIL as the framework for that experience.

59
00:03:09.405 --> 00:03:12.850
And bringing those real world examples
hopefully will shine light and

60
00:03:12.850 --> 00:03:16.250
give you some real world
application back at the office.

61
00:03:16.250 --> 00:03:17.820
As you prepare for the exam,

62
00:03:17.820 --> 00:03:22.174
you're going to get some
discussions to the ITProTV forum.

63
00:03:23.205 --> 00:03:28.205
Exercises and mock tests, practice exams,
are available for download.

64
00:03:28.205 --> 00:03:31.845
The importance of these practice
exams can't be overstated.

65
00:03:31.845 --> 00:03:35.615
They really do get you into
the mindset of the test maker and

66
00:03:35.615 --> 00:03:38.125
gives you an idea of their techniques for

67
00:03:38.125 --> 00:03:41.750
testing the objectives of these
intermediate level topics.

68
00:03:41.750 --> 00:03:45.610
And they do so in a way that's fair and
very constructive.

69
00:03:45.610 --> 00:03:48.580
You can learn a lot just by
taking the practice exams.

70
00:03:48.580 --> 00:03:51.390
Even if you fail the practice
exams you can learn a lot

71
00:03:51.390 --> 00:03:52.890
just by leading the rationale.

72
00:03:52.890 --> 00:03:55.040
>> So Terry,
where can we get these practice exams?

73
00:03:55.040 --> 00:03:55.540
>> Thank you.

74
00:03:55.540 --> 00:03:59.980
All these exercises and practice exams and

75
00:03:59.980 --> 00:04:02.520
other resources,
valuable resources are available for

76
00:04:02.520 --> 00:04:07.450
download in the upper right hand corner
just above me here, called show files.

77
00:04:07.450 --> 00:04:11.550
Please go there, there's a zip file there,
download that zip, unzip the files, and

78
00:04:11.550 --> 00:04:15.530
you're gonna find a treasure trove of
things that are gonna help you prepare.

79
00:04:15.530 --> 00:04:17.950
And be prepared to prepare.

80
00:04:17.950 --> 00:04:21.860
Just sitting to these lectures
could be enough but I doubt it.

81
00:04:21.860 --> 00:04:23.650
You're certainly gonna have
to practice the exam and

82
00:04:23.650 --> 00:04:26.480
work through some exercises
to get ready for the exam.

83
00:04:26.480 --> 00:04:31.068
So, anticipate some homework on your own,
right?

84
00:04:31.068 --> 00:04:32.450
Okay.

85
00:04:32.450 --> 00:04:34.960
A little background of ITIL.

86
00:04:34.960 --> 00:04:41.150
It's owned by a cabinet Office of
Government Commerce in the United Kingdom.

87
00:04:41.150 --> 00:04:46.990
It first began in the mid 80s and
it's kinda similar to our US Chamber

88
00:04:46.990 --> 00:04:51.110
of Commerce where they would try to
provide best practice to support business.

89
00:04:51.110 --> 00:04:53.590
Well, they came up with this
idea that we need to describe

90
00:04:53.590 --> 00:04:55.590
what this IT service management look like,

91
00:04:55.590 --> 00:05:00.760
what does success look like in this
idea of delivering IT services.

92
00:05:00.760 --> 00:05:05.860
And since the 80s, it has evolved, it's
gone through version upgrades, updates.

93
00:05:05.860 --> 00:05:07.270
It continues to be improved.

94
00:05:07.270 --> 00:05:11.140
As you can see,
the latest official upgrade was in 2011.

95
00:05:11.140 --> 00:05:13.560
But just last year, last spring of 2016,

96
00:05:13.560 --> 00:05:17.730
they published a new course
called Practitioner.

97
00:05:17.730 --> 00:05:22.920
Which helps you answer the question,
how do I start adopting ITIL?

98
00:05:22.920 --> 00:05:24.260
Where should I begin?.

99
00:05:24.260 --> 00:05:27.390
So they continue to look out, they
continue to look at the industry trends

100
00:05:28.450 --> 00:05:31.140
and make adjustments to
the curriculum as necessary.

101
00:05:31.140 --> 00:05:34.520
>> Terry does this certification has
an expiration date or how does that work?

102
00:05:34.520 --> 00:05:37.900
>> No longer it does,
it no longer has an expiration date.

103
00:05:37.900 --> 00:05:41.825
Between version two and version three,
the accrediting agencies along with

104
00:05:41.825 --> 00:05:45.567
the blessing of the cabinet office
decided everyone need to upgrade their

105
00:05:45.567 --> 00:05:49.600
certifications so they deprecated
the old ones, says you have re-certify.

106
00:05:49.600 --> 00:05:51.670
A lot of people got upset about that.

107
00:05:51.670 --> 00:05:54.650
So between version three in 2011.

108
00:05:54.650 --> 00:05:57.850
Notice they didn't actually up version it,
they just gave it a date.

109
00:05:57.850 --> 00:06:02.660
So the 2011 update did not
include a version upgrade,

110
00:06:02.660 --> 00:06:05.670
they didn't require people
to reset the exams.

111
00:06:05.670 --> 00:06:10.080
So some of the things in fact
play out on a foundation exam.

112
00:06:10.080 --> 00:06:13.670
If you were to take
a version three 2007 exam,

113
00:06:13.670 --> 00:06:17.180
you would find the similar topics
if you took one after 2011 as well.

114
00:06:17.180 --> 00:06:18.800
>> All right, good to know.

115
00:06:18.800 --> 00:06:23.470
>> Yep, all right, so you'll recall that

116
00:06:23.470 --> 00:06:28.695
the ITIL library consists of
five core publications, right?

117
00:06:28.695 --> 00:06:32.720
Service strategy, service design,
service transition, service operation and

118
00:06:32.720 --> 00:06:34.590
continual service improvement.

119
00:06:34.590 --> 00:06:38.550
Those five core publications
happen to correspond

120
00:06:38.550 --> 00:06:43.210
with ITIL's definition of the five
stages in the lifecycle of a service

121
00:06:43.210 --> 00:06:46.530
with service strategy being
the earliest lifecycle stage.

122
00:06:46.530 --> 00:06:49.640
So our course material in
service offerings agreement is

123
00:06:49.640 --> 00:06:53.220
going to be focusing on service
strategy and service design topics.

124
00:06:53.220 --> 00:06:56.270
So early in the lifecycle of a service

125
00:06:56.270 --> 00:06:59.505
is what we are going to be focusing our
attention on through out this course.

126
00:06:59.505 --> 00:07:04.680
Okay, that doesn't mean that you should be
totally ignorant of service transitions,

127
00:07:04.680 --> 00:07:07.565
service operations and
continual service improvement.

128
00:07:07.565 --> 00:07:11.270
Awareness of those
are the stages is also important

129
00:07:11.270 --> 00:07:14.265
to your success on the exam if
only at the superficial level,

130
00:07:14.265 --> 00:07:18.115
you'll still need to understand
those topics as well.

131
00:07:18.115 --> 00:07:22.960
That's why foundation is a prerequisite
because any of the topics are fair game in

132
00:07:22.960 --> 00:07:27.600
terms of how would you go about coming
up with a successful strategy design so

133
00:07:27.600 --> 00:07:31.928
that it can be transitioned,
operated and continually improved, okay?

134
00:07:31.928 --> 00:07:37.310
All right, so
what's the qualification scheme look like?

135
00:07:37.310 --> 00:07:38.680
First of all, accreditation.

136
00:07:40.490 --> 00:07:45.430
The official copyright owner of the
cabinet office, they own the copyright.

137
00:07:45.430 --> 00:07:51.050
They allow Axelose to be
the ITIL accreditor which then

138
00:07:51.050 --> 00:07:57.430
licenses exam institutes to be
on the ground making exams.

139
00:07:57.430 --> 00:08:04.410
Managing the logistics of exam
administration, exam creation, etc.

140
00:08:04.410 --> 00:08:09.880
And then accredited training organization,
such as PassionIT Group,

141
00:08:09.880 --> 00:08:13.710
they go through the rigors of being
audited by the exam institution,

142
00:08:13.710 --> 00:08:17.060
to make sure their course materials
are aligned with the syllabus.

143
00:08:17.060 --> 00:08:20.870
And accredited trainers,
such as me, we have to go through

144
00:08:20.870 --> 00:08:23.520
the accreditation through those
accredited training organizations.

145
00:08:23.520 --> 00:08:26.360
So, everyone is aligned
toward the same goals.

146
00:08:26.360 --> 00:08:29.960
>> Now, looks like a pretty well
respected and industry wide standard for

147
00:08:29.960 --> 00:08:31.650
this particular certification?

148
00:08:31.650 --> 00:08:32.990
>> It is, very well respected.

149
00:08:32.990 --> 00:08:37.730
And ITIL itself has become the de facto
best practice around the world for

150
00:08:37.730 --> 00:08:39.710
IT service management.

151
00:08:39.710 --> 00:08:45.625
It is well respected all over the world,
okay.

152
00:08:45.625 --> 00:08:49.930
Now here is somewhat of an example of
the course work that you could take at any

153
00:08:49.930 --> 00:08:50.705
given time.

154
00:08:50.705 --> 00:08:55.222
Of course we'd recommend that you
take the courses from ITProTV.

155
00:08:55.222 --> 00:08:57.730
They're all gonna be available
at some point in time.

156
00:08:57.730 --> 00:09:00.010
We've focused a lot on foundation and

157
00:09:00.010 --> 00:09:06.160
we also have in the ITProTV library
already release control and validation.

158
00:09:06.160 --> 00:09:10.080
We're working now on this episode here
of service offers and agreements.

159
00:09:10.080 --> 00:09:11.810
We have planning, protection, and

160
00:09:11.810 --> 00:09:15.840
optimization already
under the hood as well.

161
00:09:15.840 --> 00:09:17.788
PPO, OSA to follow.

162
00:09:17.788 --> 00:09:23.220
So of course as you can take here
they are without the abbreviations.

163
00:09:23.220 --> 00:09:24.309
A little bit easier to see here.

164
00:09:25.950 --> 00:09:30.340
If you wanted to achieve
a certification as an ITIL expert

165
00:09:30.340 --> 00:09:34.980
that is one of the credentials they hold,
that they offer.

166
00:09:34.980 --> 00:09:37.050
You need to amass credits and

167
00:09:37.050 --> 00:09:40.680
you can take this credits by taking
these various courses, right.

168
00:09:40.680 --> 00:09:43.460
Foundation is requirement,
you gotta have foundation.

169
00:09:43.460 --> 00:09:44.970
Everyone has to have that one.

170
00:09:44.970 --> 00:09:48.380
And then at the end you also have to
have Management Across the Lifecycle.

171
00:09:49.570 --> 00:09:51.130
Otherwise known as MALC.

172
00:09:51.130 --> 00:09:55.670
That's the capstone course,
the one that says you have mastered

173
00:09:55.670 --> 00:09:59.660
this information well enough to apply
it across all stages of the lifecycle.

174
00:10:01.070 --> 00:10:04.390
In between you can take
courses anyway you want.

175
00:10:04.390 --> 00:10:07.640
You can take Server Strategy And you
could take Service Offerings Agreements.

176
00:10:07.640 --> 00:10:13.070
You could mix and match the capability and
lifecycle courses as you wish.

177
00:10:13.070 --> 00:10:16.540
Once you have 17 credits,
you get two for foundation.

178
00:10:17.650 --> 00:10:21.810
A mass 15 credits among these courses for
a total of at least 17,

179
00:10:21.810 --> 00:10:25.940
you're then eligible to take
The Managing Across the Lifecycle exam.

180
00:10:25.940 --> 00:10:28.670
Passing that one gives you five
more credits, for a total of 22,

181
00:10:28.670 --> 00:10:32.570
22 credits gives you
the ITIL expert credential.

182
00:10:32.570 --> 00:10:36.240
>> How many exams are we looking at,
for the whole shebang here?

183
00:10:36.240 --> 00:10:40.662
>> The shortest path, exam-wise,
would be foundation one and

184
00:10:40.662 --> 00:10:43.950
then four capabilities plus MALC, five.

185
00:10:43.950 --> 00:10:47.430
>> Okay.
>> Five separate exams would be the total.

186
00:10:47.430 --> 00:10:48.670
Of course you can mix and match.

187
00:10:48.670 --> 00:10:53.340
You can take more exams with shorter
courses, do it different bits.

188
00:10:53.340 --> 00:10:55.570
Different ways to do that.

189
00:10:55.570 --> 00:11:00.390
Coming soon to ITProTV will be a path
to managing across the life or

190
00:11:00.390 --> 00:11:04.290
a path to the experts is what we're
focusing on in our production

191
00:11:04.290 --> 00:11:07.290
schedule is to give you
a path through capabilities.

192
00:11:07.290 --> 00:11:12.215
These four plus MALC and
of course foundation.

193
00:11:12.215 --> 00:11:12.715
Okay?

194
00:11:15.348 --> 00:11:17.670
So the exam is different.

195
00:11:17.670 --> 00:11:21.170
If you've had an intermediate
exam then you get this already.

196
00:11:21.170 --> 00:11:23.990
But the exam is certainly
different in foundation.

197
00:11:23.990 --> 00:11:30.590
You called it a foundation exam was
40 questions, one right answer right?

198
00:11:30.590 --> 00:11:34.420
And you had to get at least
26 of rank of 65%, right?

199
00:11:34.420 --> 00:11:37.820
And that was just rote memorization,
so the bar is not real, real high.

200
00:11:37.820 --> 00:11:40.223
I'm not saying is not a challenging exam.

201
00:11:40.223 --> 00:11:44.444
But it's still rote memorization and
understanding of the principles and

202
00:11:44.444 --> 00:11:47.220
foundational elements of ITIL.

203
00:11:47.220 --> 00:11:50.220
The reading level exams as we
noted before require you to

204
00:11:50.220 --> 00:11:54.090
provide some analysis of this
information you've learned.

205
00:11:54.090 --> 00:11:56.900
And there's not just one right answer.

206
00:11:56.900 --> 00:11:59.890
There's a best answer,
which we'll give you five points.

207
00:11:59.890 --> 00:12:02.780
There's a next best answer which
will give you three points.

208
00:12:02.780 --> 00:12:07.800
And then,as you go down the grade you
could also get a zero answer as well.

209
00:12:07.800 --> 00:12:13.570
So there's eight questions with the
possibility of five points per question.

210
00:12:13.570 --> 00:12:16.030
So there's a possible total number of 40.

211
00:12:16.030 --> 00:12:20.150
A perfect score would be 40
on intermediate level exams.

212
00:12:21.510 --> 00:12:24.030
To pass, you have to get 28.

213
00:12:24.030 --> 00:12:28.280
You get 90 minutes to take it, which is 30
minutes more than you get on foundation.

214
00:12:28.280 --> 00:12:31.730
They are challenging in that,
you have to manage your time well.

215
00:12:31.730 --> 00:12:34.810
There's, lengthy scenarios at times.

216
00:12:34.810 --> 00:12:37.180
There might be a page long scenario.

217
00:12:37.180 --> 00:12:40.840
The questions themselves might span one or
two pages, or one and a half pages.

218
00:12:40.840 --> 00:12:43.560
So, a bit more reading and analysis.

219
00:12:43.560 --> 00:12:45.880
But that's the nature of the beast, right?

220
00:12:45.880 --> 00:12:50.540
If you do the math on this,
you gotta get 28 out of 40.

221
00:12:50.540 --> 00:12:54.950
So if you were to get six three
point answers, that's 18,

222
00:12:54.950 --> 00:12:59.740
plus two five point answers,
that would give you your 28, right?

223
00:12:59.740 --> 00:13:03.230
So perfection obviously
is not mandatory here.

224
00:13:03.230 --> 00:13:07.170
But of course, if you were to pick
one zero answer, then of course

225
00:13:07.170 --> 00:13:10.420
you've raised the bar for having more
perfect answers you have to find.

226
00:13:10.420 --> 00:13:13.770
>> Now Terry, are we allowed to mark
answers and then go back for review or

227
00:13:13.770 --> 00:13:15.600
is it kind of a one and done situation?

228
00:13:15.600 --> 00:13:16.910
>> Absolutely can go back and mark.

229
00:13:17.990 --> 00:13:20.260
Whether you, as you take the exam online,

230
00:13:20.260 --> 00:13:23.299
you can start at question
eight instead of question one.

231
00:13:23.299 --> 00:13:25.590
You can go back to question one.

232
00:13:25.590 --> 00:13:28.095
You're not done until you click
that last little I'm finished.

233
00:13:28.095 --> 00:13:29.260
>> Okay, sounds good.

234
00:13:29.260 --> 00:13:32.460
It's good to know because sometimes we're
talking about time management in the exam.

235
00:13:32.460 --> 00:13:35.920
I'm setting some and
it's always good to know ahead of time.

236
00:13:35.920 --> 00:13:39.865
>> One of the things that is a bit
challenging for the online exam is if you

237
00:13:39.865 --> 00:13:43.554
were to take the exam on paper,
you can mark on the paper itself.

238
00:13:43.554 --> 00:13:47.220
So you gonna have to get creative
on the exam session because

239
00:13:47.220 --> 00:13:51.490
is on the screen electronically of
how you are eliminating answers.

240
00:13:51.490 --> 00:13:53.499
Are taking notes and
eliminating which you can.

241
00:13:53.499 --> 00:13:56.574
You can take notes on paper
while you're taking exam but

242
00:13:56.574 --> 00:14:00.750
you won't have that facility of
marking on the exam paper itself.

243
00:14:00.750 --> 00:14:01.762
That's the only difference, all right?

244
00:14:04.958 --> 00:14:08.578
Speaking of the exam,
the full instructions for

245
00:14:08.578 --> 00:14:13.710
how to get the exam scheduled
are available in the download, right?

246
00:14:13.710 --> 00:14:16.340
You're gonna get this exam
from PassionIT Group.

247
00:14:16.340 --> 00:14:20.550
They can broker the sale of that exam and
you will take online, right?

248
00:14:21.900 --> 00:14:24.950
Probably is the best way to approach that,
you can get your proctor one, but

249
00:14:24.950 --> 00:14:30.550
those cost more etc, okay.

250
00:14:31.840 --> 00:14:34.520
So, don't forget comes
exam time reach out,

251
00:14:34.520 --> 00:14:38.930
if you have questions reach out
to me at deckerheads@yahoo.com,

252
00:14:38.930 --> 00:14:44.883
through the forum at ITProTV, or
check out the website PassionITGroup.com.

253
00:14:44.883 --> 00:14:48.450
All right, that's a wrap for
the basic logistics of this.

254
00:14:48.450 --> 00:14:53.645
Up next is going to be a review
of some foundational principles.

255
00:14:53.645 --> 00:14:55.070
>> Terry, thank you for
coming in today and

256
00:14:55.070 --> 00:14:59.040
giving us at least a good foundation
of where we should begin here.

257
00:14:59.040 --> 00:15:02.410
But ladies and gentlemen, stay tuned,
we have more information headed your way.

258
00:15:02.410 --> 00:15:03.850
For this show we'll go ahead and sign out.

259
00:15:03.850 --> 00:15:05.900
Remember I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

260
00:15:05.900 --> 00:15:06.730
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

261
00:15:06.730 --> 00:15:08.203
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

262
00:15:08.203 --> 00:15:15.994
[MUSIC]

263
00:15:15.994 --> 00:15:18.757
>> Thank you for watching, ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Terry review concepts covered in the required prerequisite training  ITIL foundations) to help refresh basic concepts and terminology before diving into ITIL SOA.
episodes.title: ITIL Foundation Refresher
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:04.952
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:04.952 --> 00:00:11.092
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.092 --> 00:00:15.850
>> Welcome to your ITIL Service Offerings
and Agreements series.

4
00:00:15.850 --> 00:00:18.010
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

5
00:00:18.010 --> 00:00:21.060
In this episode, we'll really
be going back in looking at that

6
00:00:21.060 --> 00:00:25.990
foundation certification, and
kind of just give a refresher.

7
00:00:25.990 --> 00:00:29.610
And with us today back in studios we have
Mr. Terry Decker to help us with that.

8
00:00:29.610 --> 00:00:30.908
Thanks for joining us Terry.

9
00:00:30.908 --> 00:00:33.120
>> Glad to be here Cherokee as always.

10
00:00:33.120 --> 00:00:36.368
As she mentioned, we gotta knock the rust
off some of those foundation information.

11
00:00:36.368 --> 00:00:41.360
We gotta get back into the habit of using
ITIL language, the words are important.

12
00:00:41.360 --> 00:00:44.080
These words are gonna be used on the exam.

13
00:00:44.080 --> 00:00:47.160
So you need to recognize
them in the ITIL sense,

14
00:00:47.160 --> 00:00:51.510
not necessarily in the everyday sense
that you might be accustomed to.

15
00:00:51.510 --> 00:00:52.680
So we're gonna knock that rust off.

16
00:00:52.680 --> 00:00:56.260
And one of these words or very important
concepts is the idea of a lifecycle,

17
00:00:56.260 --> 00:00:58.860
particularly the service lifecycle.

18
00:00:58.860 --> 00:01:01.830
So, what does lifecycle mean to you?

19
00:01:01.830 --> 00:01:03.550
>> Terry, if I had to really define it,

20
00:01:03.550 --> 00:01:07.046
I guess I would say something with
a definite beginning and end.

21
00:01:07.046 --> 00:01:10.140
>> Make sense, project lifecycle.

22
00:01:10.140 --> 00:01:11.780
>> Exactly, that's where I'm pulling from.

23
00:01:11.780 --> 00:01:14.770
>> Exactly, a project has a lifecycle,
beginning and an end.

24
00:01:16.400 --> 00:01:23.320
A car has a lifecycle, from concept
stage through design, maybe a prototype.

25
00:01:23.320 --> 00:01:26.549
Eventually in a manufacturing it's sold,
it's operated.

26
00:01:27.770 --> 00:01:30.280
So, you can imagine almost anything.

27
00:01:30.280 --> 00:01:34.680
An employee has a lifecycle,
employment lifecycle, from hire to retire,

28
00:01:34.680 --> 00:01:37.520
or perhaps from hire to fire.

29
00:01:37.520 --> 00:01:40.840
Maybe somewhere in the, and
all the points in between.

30
00:01:40.840 --> 00:01:45.149
So that's really what a cycle is,
when something starts, and

31
00:01:45.149 --> 00:01:48.030
eventually gets ended or retired.

32
00:01:48.030 --> 00:01:53.913
So, ITIL certainly is focused on
the lifecycle of a service an IT service.

33
00:01:53.913 --> 00:01:58.430
The ITIL librarians have
gone through the trouble

34
00:01:58.430 --> 00:02:01.880
of dividing this life
cycle into five stages.

35
00:02:01.880 --> 00:02:05.890
And those stages as you can see here, and

36
00:02:05.890 --> 00:02:10.550
remember from your foundation course,
service strategy, service design,

37
00:02:10.550 --> 00:02:14.330
service transition, service operations and
continual service improvement.

38
00:02:14.330 --> 00:02:18.030
These five stages form the life
cycle with service strategy and

39
00:02:18.030 --> 00:02:22.450
service design being earlier than
transition operation against CSI.

40
00:02:23.470 --> 00:02:28.850
So in chronological order,
service strategy happens before design.

41
00:02:28.850 --> 00:02:34.592
I think we need to remember that this
course is focused on strategy and

42
00:02:34.592 --> 00:02:36.555
design topics.

43
00:02:36.555 --> 00:02:37.375
So therefore,

44
00:02:37.375 --> 00:02:41.885
we're gonna be focusing on the early
stages on the lifecycle of a service.

45
00:02:41.885 --> 00:02:46.615
Which might be foreign to a lot of
students that deal more with operational

46
00:02:46.615 --> 00:02:49.695
issues or
transitional issues on a day-to-day basis.

47
00:02:49.695 --> 00:02:51.745
So, get ready for that kind of learning.

48
00:02:51.745 --> 00:02:56.380
We're gonna be focused on the early
stages in a lifecycle of a service.

49
00:02:56.380 --> 00:03:00.150
And the early process definitions
in the lifecycle of a service.

50
00:03:02.678 --> 00:03:09.600
You'll see here the processes across
the various lifecycle stages.

51
00:03:09.600 --> 00:03:11.270
These were almost entirely,

52
00:03:11.270 --> 00:03:16.410
there was four processes that were
not in scope of foundation course.

53
00:03:16.410 --> 00:03:20.690
But there's 26 processes defined by ITIL.

54
00:03:20.690 --> 00:03:24.700
They're all listed here as a broken
down by each of the stages.

55
00:03:24.700 --> 00:03:27.410
The ones that are different color,
the ones in blue and

56
00:03:27.410 --> 00:03:30.780
bold, are the ones we're gonna
be talking about in this show.

57
00:03:31.990 --> 00:03:33.970
Service portfolio management,
demand management.

58
00:03:33.970 --> 00:03:36.810
You'll see financial management,
business relationship management.

59
00:03:36.810 --> 00:03:39.210
They actually come from
the service strategy book.

60
00:03:39.210 --> 00:03:41.781
We're gonna talk about catalog management,
service level management,

61
00:03:41.781 --> 00:03:45.540
and supplier management, which those
three come from the service design book.

62
00:03:45.540 --> 00:03:49.380
They put them together because they're
intricately related to each other

63
00:03:49.380 --> 00:03:52.470
in this topic called Service Offerings and
Agreements.

64
00:03:53.710 --> 00:03:57.490
So service offerings is particularly
in the remit of service strategy,

65
00:03:57.490 --> 00:04:00.900
the agreement side of the business is
particularly in the design aspects of it.

66
00:04:02.000 --> 00:04:05.980
So that's what we're gonna be focusing
on primarily throughout this course.

67
00:04:05.980 --> 00:04:09.180
We're also gonna have a necessary
look at strategy manage for

68
00:04:09.180 --> 00:04:11.890
IT services and design coordination.

69
00:04:11.890 --> 00:04:15.926
As you'll see at the bottom of Service
Design there's Design Coordination, and

70
00:04:15.926 --> 00:04:17.513
at the top of Service Strategy.

71
00:04:17.513 --> 00:04:21.528
We're gonna have a brief look at those
as well because in describing those

72
00:04:21.528 --> 00:04:25.221
processes, we'll also gonna describe
the overall chain value and

73
00:04:25.221 --> 00:04:29.063
output from these two stages,
service strategy and service design.

74
00:04:34.514 --> 00:04:35.920
So what is a service?

75
00:04:38.410 --> 00:04:42.660
>> Perhaps a service is
some kind of management

76
00:04:42.660 --> 00:04:44.250
that an IT department would offer.

77
00:04:44.250 --> 00:04:48.280
Where as we spoke about life cycle,
that may be something that has that

78
00:04:48.280 --> 00:04:52.400
beginning and end and that I'm complete,
a service could be ongoing.

79
00:04:52.400 --> 00:04:56.650
And again that's just my project
management background, coming in here.

80
00:04:56.650 --> 00:04:59.200
>> I like it, it's pretty good.

81
00:04:59.200 --> 00:05:03.880
One way to distinguish Windows driver
service is to distinguish what it's not or

82
00:05:03.880 --> 00:05:05.590
what it goes beyond.

83
00:05:05.590 --> 00:05:07.530
A service is certainly
different than a solution.

84
00:05:09.010 --> 00:05:13.740
Perhaps you've been involved in
relationships where the solution was

85
00:05:13.740 --> 00:05:18.360
delivered, and it was up to you to figure
out how to use it, a box was dropped.

86
00:05:18.360 --> 00:05:20.170
>> If we had hired an external consultant.

87
00:05:21.540 --> 00:05:23.480
>> Right, maybe an expert consultant.

88
00:05:23.480 --> 00:05:25.970
They come in, they make a bunch of noise,
and fly away, right?

89
00:05:25.970 --> 00:05:27.700
Seagull management,
I believe that's called.

90
00:05:27.700 --> 00:05:30.745
Make a bunch of noise,
leave a big mess, and then fly away.

91
00:05:30.745 --> 00:05:36.100
[LAUGH] A service is much
more than a solution.

92
00:05:36.100 --> 00:05:39.300
It's not just dropping a box and
saying here figure it out.

93
00:05:39.300 --> 00:05:43.880
Or, here's a training manual,
have a nice day, and then walking away.

94
00:05:43.880 --> 00:05:47.779
A service is a lot more
holistic in delivery.

95
00:05:47.779 --> 00:05:52.070
It needs to consider lots of interfaces
with humans as well as with technology.

96
00:05:52.070 --> 00:05:55.945
It needs to consider processes,
it needs to consider measurements.

97
00:05:55.945 --> 00:05:58.030
We'll remind you of those details.

98
00:05:58.030 --> 00:06:01.726
You certainly learned this
in the foundation course

99
00:06:01.726 --> 00:06:05.763
that a service is a lot more
complicated than a solution.

100
00:06:05.763 --> 00:06:11.780
And ITIL is focused on service delivery
and the lifecycle of a service.

101
00:06:11.780 --> 00:06:14.270
The rote memorization here,
what is a service?

102
00:06:14.270 --> 00:06:19.100
A means of delivering value
to customers by facilitating

103
00:06:19.100 --> 00:06:24.310
outcomes that they want to achieve without
the ownership of specific cost and risk.

104
00:06:24.310 --> 00:06:27.490
The IT service provider is
providing value to customers.

105
00:06:29.350 --> 00:06:33.180
I remember,
as I teach the foundation course,

106
00:06:33.180 --> 00:06:38.750
I remind students of the nine-tenths rule,
value, customers and service.

107
00:06:38.750 --> 00:06:43.780
Those three words can serve you
well on the exam, in any exam.

108
00:06:43.780 --> 00:06:47.150
Certainly, on the foundation
that are even plays through on

109
00:06:47.150 --> 00:06:49.050
the intermediate level exam as well.

110
00:06:49.050 --> 00:06:53.940
What I mean by that, the nine-tenths rule,
is that if you have four choices of

111
00:06:53.940 --> 00:06:58.800
questions, and
one of them has a focus on value,

112
00:06:58.800 --> 00:07:03.280
explicitly, and the other three don't,
chances are the one that explicitly

113
00:07:03.280 --> 00:07:08.910
expresses value in the answer is gonna
be more correct than the other three.

114
00:07:08.910 --> 00:07:10.820
Chances are, nine times out of ten.

115
00:07:10.820 --> 00:07:12.820
The same thing with the word customers.

116
00:07:12.820 --> 00:07:18.010
If you have an answer that clearly
includes the customer's considerations,

117
00:07:18.010 --> 00:07:21.660
either directly or
explicitly or even indirectly.

118
00:07:21.660 --> 00:07:26.140
You've gotten the requirements or
you've gotten their feedback or approvals.

119
00:07:26.140 --> 00:07:30.458
If the customer is a item of focus in one
of the answers, and is not an item focus

120
00:07:30.458 --> 00:07:35.100
of the other ones, chances are it's
gonna be the more correct answer.

121
00:07:35.100 --> 00:07:38.300
And of course service is
also one of those key words.

122
00:07:38.300 --> 00:07:43.900
An IT provider needs to provide service
not just solutions, not just technology.

123
00:07:43.900 --> 00:07:46.880
They need to kind of wrap
it all with governance,

124
00:07:46.880 --> 00:07:49.287
policies, and effective processes.

125
00:07:49.287 --> 00:07:54.258
So delivering the right value to the right
customers is really what this ITIL whole

126
00:07:54.258 --> 00:07:55.277
thing is about.

127
00:07:55.277 --> 00:07:55.931
>> Sounds good.

128
00:07:55.931 --> 00:07:57.167
>> Yep.

129
00:07:57.167 --> 00:08:00.328
All right, so what is service management?

130
00:08:00.328 --> 00:08:02.200
Again, a rote memorization thing.

131
00:08:02.200 --> 00:08:05.760
Service management is effectively
the capability to deliver value

132
00:08:05.760 --> 00:08:08.190
through services, right?

133
00:08:08.190 --> 00:08:10.110
You have appropriate praxis in place.

134
00:08:10.110 --> 00:08:12.820
You have knowledge in place,
the right skills.

135
00:08:12.820 --> 00:08:17.290
And you're transforming this idea
of well we just provide Internet,

136
00:08:17.290 --> 00:08:18.840
that's what we do.

137
00:08:18.840 --> 00:08:21.340
We provide services along with Internet.

138
00:08:21.340 --> 00:08:25.690
We make sure it's available on time,
on budget, etc.

139
00:08:25.690 --> 00:08:29.144
>> We're seeing a lot of that
with our Cloud types of services,

140
00:08:29.144 --> 00:08:31.865
software as a service,
platform as a service.

141
00:08:31.865 --> 00:08:32.442
>> Exactly.

142
00:08:32.442 --> 00:08:34.017
>> So pretty popular nowadays.

143
00:08:34.017 --> 00:08:41.700
>> You can even see trends,
I mean IBM was once a box dropper.

144
00:08:41.700 --> 00:08:44.635
They provided equipment and
they dropped it.

145
00:08:44.635 --> 00:08:47.855
And they did help with
implementation services, right,

146
00:08:47.855 --> 00:08:51.890
main frames back in the day,
still mid-range computers.

147
00:08:51.890 --> 00:08:55.985
Desktop computers, they're primarily
now a service organization.

148
00:08:55.985 --> 00:08:59.375
They've completely transformed their
business model to be a service

149
00:08:59.375 --> 00:09:00.183
organization.

150
00:09:00.183 --> 00:09:02.334
>> Well sure, it's like we've had to
evolve over the years in order to

151
00:09:02.334 --> 00:09:02.950
meet that demand.

152
00:09:02.950 --> 00:09:03.660
>> That's right.

153
00:09:04.740 --> 00:09:06.540
Organizations need IT.

154
00:09:06.540 --> 00:09:07.910
They need boxes dropped.

155
00:09:07.910 --> 00:09:10.590
They certainly do, but
they also need IT services.

156
00:09:10.590 --> 00:09:13.130
They need help to make
sure this all works and

157
00:09:13.130 --> 00:09:18.180
works well on time and allows them
to achieve their business outcomes.

158
00:09:18.180 --> 00:09:21.510
Again, the example of
being a geophysicist.

159
00:09:21.510 --> 00:09:23.250
If you're a geophysicist working for

160
00:09:23.250 --> 00:09:26.540
an oil company you don't
need to be an IT expert.

161
00:09:26.540 --> 00:09:29.720
To work in the IT department of that
same oil company you don't need to be

162
00:09:29.720 --> 00:09:31.460
a geophysicist, right?

163
00:09:31.460 --> 00:09:36.240
Bringing these two together, so

things could be enhancing services,

403
00:22:05.080 --> 00:22:08.250
that witness server be part
of everyday offerings.

404
00:22:08.250 --> 00:22:12.320
>> So it sounds like once you go ahead and
define these components it's not a one and

405
00:22:12.320 --> 00:22:14.850
done situation they may
evolve into something else?

406
00:22:14.850 --> 00:22:18.550
>> Absolutely and it's a common
thing that, it's pretty common.

407
00:22:18.550 --> 00:22:20.330
It's never static, and

408
00:22:20.330 --> 00:22:24.190
I think that's probably true about all the
life cycle IT service it's always moving,

409
00:22:24.190 --> 00:22:29.020
the business is moving, the services
are moving, the technology is moving.

410
00:22:29.020 --> 00:22:32.660
So I mean years ago,
we weren't thinking about cloud computing,

411
00:22:32.660 --> 00:22:35.910
we weren't thinking about
software as a service, right.

412
00:22:37.460 --> 00:22:40.460
Server visualization is
a relatively new thing, right?

413
00:22:40.460 --> 00:22:42.650
We can go on back even further.

414
00:22:42.650 --> 00:22:46.600
Main frame to client server
was a transformational thing.

415
00:22:46.600 --> 00:22:49.400
Right, so again it's never static.

416
00:22:49.400 --> 00:22:51.230
So understanding your service methodology.

417
00:22:51.230 --> 00:22:54.880
And I again, I appreciate ITIL
distinguishing core enabling and

418
00:22:54.880 --> 00:22:56.240
an enhancing services.

419
00:22:56.240 --> 00:22:57.880
It's an important distinction.

420
00:22:57.880 --> 00:23:03.720
And just it is was with internal shared
and external, an important distinction

421
00:23:03.720 --> 00:23:08.660
of what type of service providers you
have, these are important distinctions for

422
00:23:08.660 --> 00:23:12.830
the types of services you have,
core, enabling, enhancing.

423
00:23:12.830 --> 00:23:15.660
But again, these are distinctions
without a difference

424
00:23:15.660 --> 00:23:17.855
when it comes to the principles of ITIL.

425
00:23:17.855 --> 00:23:21.790
If you're maintaining or you're operating
an enhancing service, sure you have

426
00:23:21.790 --> 00:23:24.050
a little bit different nuance, but
you still have to provide values.

427
00:23:24.050 --> 00:23:25.750
You still have to have governance.

428
00:23:25.750 --> 00:23:28.590
You still have to have the appropriate
strategies in place for

429
00:23:28.590 --> 00:23:30.970
when it's going to become a core or
when it's not.

430
00:23:30.970 --> 00:23:34.414
So, this are distinction
without a difference, okay.

431
00:23:34.414 --> 00:23:36.540
All right.

432
00:23:39.703 --> 00:23:41.918
Again the vocabulary is important,

433
00:23:41.918 --> 00:23:45.925
looking at from the customer
perspective what is value look like.

434
00:23:45.925 --> 00:23:50.696
You recall this graphic almost identical
graphic from the foundation of

435
00:23:50.696 --> 00:23:53.443
course perhaps, utility and warranty.

436
00:23:53.443 --> 00:23:58.045
To be able to provide value, you must
be able to provide both, utility and

437
00:23:58.045 --> 00:23:58.800
warranty.

438
00:23:59.820 --> 00:24:02.100
Utility means it has
the right functionality.

439
00:24:03.700 --> 00:24:06.270
Warranty means it's there when
it's supposed to be there,

440
00:24:06.270 --> 00:24:07.360
performing like it's supposed to.

441
00:24:09.200 --> 00:24:15.310
You have to provide both, and you'll see
the AND gate down the lower right there.

442
00:24:15.310 --> 00:24:20.320
Both utility and warranty need to be
provided to be able to provide the value.

443
00:24:20.320 --> 00:24:22.210
So, let's consider this.

444
00:24:22.210 --> 00:24:28.010
Is it possible to have, let's say an
application that is got all the bells and

445
00:24:28.010 --> 00:24:33.007
whistles, it's intuitive to use,
it's got the nice work flow,

446
00:24:33.007 --> 00:24:36.470
it's easy, but it falls down every day?

447
00:24:36.470 --> 00:24:40.745
It doesn't stay up,
it clunky, it crashes, right?

448
00:24:40.745 --> 00:24:43.240
So you can see the utility's there,
but the warranty's not.

449
00:24:44.260 --> 00:24:49.124
Is it possible to have a highly available
piece of software that's just kinda,

450
00:24:49.124 --> 00:24:50.430
eh, icky?

451
00:24:50.430 --> 00:24:52.370
>> [CROSSTALK] Does it really execute or
do what you want it to do [LAUGH]?

452
00:24:52.370 --> 00:24:54.001
>> Right, yeah, counter-intuitive.

453
00:24:54.001 --> 00:24:54.970
>> But it's always there, Terry.

454
00:24:54.970 --> 00:24:56.130
>> But it's always there, right.

455
00:24:56.130 --> 00:24:57.740
Probably because no one's using it, right?

456
00:24:57.740 --> 00:24:59.000
But, you see.

457
00:24:59.000 --> 00:25:04.620
So, I mean, that's really a humorous
way to describe why both are important.

458
00:25:04.620 --> 00:25:09.270
As an IT service provider, you need
to provide both utility and warranty.

459
00:25:09.270 --> 00:25:11.160
Now, again, vocabulary is important.

460
00:25:11.160 --> 00:25:12.930
So they're just gonna use these words,
perhaps.

461
00:25:12.930 --> 00:25:17.440
They may say, the customer is quite happy
with the warranty of the service, but

462
00:25:17.440 --> 00:25:18.509
is not pleased with utility.

463
00:25:19.810 --> 00:25:21.166
So who do you invite to that meeting?

464
00:25:21.166 --> 00:25:25.786
So knowing the difference between utility
and warranty is going to be important for

465
00:25:25.786 --> 00:25:26.711
you to analyze.

466
00:25:26.711 --> 00:25:31.797
Remember, that's what we're trying to
do on this exam is provide analysis,

467
00:25:31.797 --> 00:25:35.186
to analyze what we should do,
who should we invite,

468
00:25:35.186 --> 00:25:40.090
who should be there at the meeting
to help us with that, or vice versa.

469
00:25:40.090 --> 00:25:41.070
Utility is really good.

470
00:25:41.070 --> 00:25:43.800
They love it, but the warranty's bad.

471
00:25:43.800 --> 00:25:47.430
Or they may use words like,
fit for purpose, or fit for use.

472
00:25:47.430 --> 00:25:49.760
Fit for use is associated with warranty.

473
00:25:49.760 --> 00:25:52.170
Fitness for
purpose is associated with utility.

474
00:25:52.170 --> 00:25:54.730
Getting those rights is important.

475
00:25:54.730 --> 00:25:58.618
Notice that, we see on another
graphic here coming up soon,

476
00:25:58.618 --> 00:26:03.260
utility and warranty,
what they're trying to do is,

477
00:26:03.260 --> 00:26:07.950
utility increases the ability for
positive outcomes.

478
00:26:07.950 --> 00:26:12.990
Warranty reduces variations
in performance, right?

479
00:26:12.990 --> 00:26:16.370
So imagine that geophysicist
at the oil company.

480
00:26:17.410 --> 00:26:23.390
He was used to going out and using some
hardware to drill down into the earth,

481
00:26:23.390 --> 00:26:28.820
bringing up those samples of earth, going
back to his lab and doing some magical

482
00:26:28.820 --> 00:26:33.770
work, right, to determine,
is this a good place to drill, right?

483
00:26:33.770 --> 00:26:34.650
Now, I understand.

484
00:26:34.650 --> 00:26:35.882
Again, I'm no geophysicist.

485
00:26:35.882 --> 00:26:38.980
Now I understand they can do
that with MRI imaging, right?

486
00:26:38.980 --> 00:26:40.458
They don't have to go drill down.

487
00:26:40.458 --> 00:26:44.255
They can use MRI imaging, and
he doesn't have to go to the field.

488
00:26:44.255 --> 00:26:48.160
He can stay back in his lab, and
data can be transferred to that.

489
00:26:48.160 --> 00:26:51.800
So look at what utility is
being given at geophysicists.

490
00:26:51.800 --> 00:26:53.060
He's no longer in the field, right?

491
00:26:54.430 --> 00:26:56.430
He's using data that's transported to him,
right?

492
00:26:57.790 --> 00:26:59.810
Now it better be good data.

493
00:26:59.810 --> 00:27:01.520
It better be reliable.

494
00:27:01.520 --> 00:27:03.195
It better be there and on time.

495
00:27:03.195 --> 00:27:06.950
So the warranty has to be there, but
you certainly provide the utility.

496
00:27:06.950 --> 00:27:08.730
Let's use one maybe a bit more realistic.

497
00:27:10.330 --> 00:27:16.750
Cherokee, I suspect you're probably young
enough not to remember days before email.

498
00:27:16.750 --> 00:27:18.280
>> Yeah I can remember days before email.

499
00:27:18.280 --> 00:27:19.890
>> All right, good, okay.
There was a time before there was

500
00:27:19.890 --> 00:27:20.860
email, right?

501
00:27:20.860 --> 00:27:23.950
In an office environment,
there was days when there was not email.

502
00:27:23.950 --> 00:27:27.390
When email came about it, obviously
provided the utility to be able to more

503
00:27:27.390 --> 00:27:32.490
quickly communicate with more people and
get read receipts and what not, right?

504
00:27:32.490 --> 00:27:37.500
So as you consider the value proposition
on the utility side, email allowed for

505
00:27:37.500 --> 00:27:41.900
faster, asynchronous communication, right?

506
00:27:41.900 --> 00:27:48.750
Now, that was supporting performance,
right, of communication.

507
00:27:48.750 --> 00:27:50.280
You could also remove the constraint,

508
00:27:50.280 --> 00:27:52.480
because I remember when
email first came about.

509
00:27:52.480 --> 00:27:56.952
I could have email with my office mates,
but I couldn't talk email.

510
00:27:56.952 --> 00:27:58.910
>> Externally?
>> Externally, right?

511
00:27:58.910 --> 00:28:03.170
So that constraint was removed,
primarily through the Internet, right?

512
00:28:03.170 --> 00:28:07.330
I also remember the constraint,
I had to be on a company desktop or

513
00:28:07.330 --> 00:28:09.275
laptop at the company office.

514
00:28:09.275 --> 00:28:12.850
So a virtual network helped with that.

515
00:28:12.850 --> 00:28:15.860
I could do it from home
with my company laptop, and

516
00:28:15.860 --> 00:28:19.360
connect to my network at work,
and then get access to my email.

517
00:28:19.360 --> 00:28:21.250
And then it removed that constraint.

518
00:28:21.250 --> 00:28:21.950
>> I know.

519
00:28:21.950 --> 00:28:23.025
>> I've got my phone now, right?

520
00:28:23.025 --> 00:28:26.421
>> [LAUGH We have all sorts of
collaboration tools available in

521
00:28:26.421 --> 00:28:27.080
real time.

522
00:28:27.080 --> 00:28:30.100
We don't even have to wait for
a few seconds delay with email anymore.

523
00:28:30.100 --> 00:28:32.040
It's crazy.
>> Exactly, it is absolutely amazing.

524
00:28:32.040 --> 00:28:36.710
So, again, the same basic service,
the same basic utility in terms of,

525
00:28:36.710 --> 00:28:38.430
I can still email people, but

526
00:28:38.430 --> 00:28:42.940
I removed the constraint of being
on a desktop or at home, right?

527
00:28:42.940 --> 00:28:44.450
I could be just about anywhere now.

528
00:28:44.450 --> 00:28:45.720
So that's on the utilities side.

529
00:28:45.720 --> 00:28:49.430
Of course, it has to be available and
ready to perform as expected.

530
00:28:49.430 --> 00:28:51.490
>> Alright, Terry,
I hate to be the bearer of bad news, but

531
00:28:51.490 --> 00:28:54.120
it looks like we are out of time for
this particular episode.

532
00:28:54.120 --> 00:28:57.230
So thank you for joining us today,
and thank you ladies and gentlemen for

533
00:28:57.230 --> 00:28:58.430
joining us as well.

534
00:28:58.430 --> 00:29:00.973
But, for this show, I'm gonna go ahead and

535
00:29:00.973 --> 00:29:02.558
Remember, I'm Cherokee Boose.

537

>> See you next time here at ITPRO.TV.

1

Welcome to ITPro.TV,

2

3

and Agreement Series.

6
00:00:15.082 --> 00:00:16.677
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:16.677 --> 00:00:18.529
In the previous episode,

8
00:00:18.529 --> 00:00:23.750
we are really just looking at
the foundations refresher if you will.

9
00:00:23.750 --> 00:00:26.039
And this show is actually a part
two of that previous episode.

10
00:00:26.039 --> 00:00:27.892
So with us today in studios, we have Mr.

11
00:00:27.892 --> 00:00:30.241
Terry Decker to contribute
to this conversation.

12

Thank you for joining as Terry.

13
00:00:31.836 --> 00:00:33.516
>> As always happy to be here.

14

And as Cherokee said we got a little bit
more to finish up on this review of some

15
00:00:37.307 --> 00:00:39.156

00:00:39.156 --> 00:00:41.138
And actually getting our head and

17
00:00:41.138 --> 00:00:45.118
tongue around the language of ITIL
cuz the language is important.

18
00:00:45.118 --> 00:00:46.172
We gotta keep up, and

19
00:00:46.172 --> 00:00:49.910
this is one of the best examples of
how important the language can be.

20
00:00:49.910 --> 00:00:54.949
Just look at the slide here, this word
asset has a very specific meaning in ITIL.

21
00:00:54.949 --> 00:00:59.690
It's commonly used in so many different
contexts that we could certainly

22
00:00:59.690 --> 00:01:02.770
have in our own mind what it might mean.

23
00:01:02.770 --> 00:01:07.163
But you'll see here, an asset in
the ITIL language is any resource or

24
00:01:07.163 --> 00:01:08.617
capability, right?

25
00:01:08.617 --> 00:01:11.060
What's a resource?

26
00:01:11.060 --> 00:01:17.380
It could be a server, an application,
a person, it could be a process, right?

27
00:01:17.380 --> 00:01:20.460
A capability of course,
is a little less tangible,

28
00:01:20.460 --> 00:01:25.434
something you have to measure through
skills or abilities or performance, right?

29
00:01:25.434 --> 00:01:31.182
So capabilities is an organizational
ability to build to get something done.

30
00:01:31.182 --> 00:01:35.157
So again an asset is either a resource or
a capability.

31
00:01:35.157 --> 00:01:38.399
It's not necessarily something
you slip up an asset tag on and

32
00:01:38.399 --> 00:01:41.466
have a depreciation schedule for
financial management.

33
00:01:41.466 --> 00:01:44.103
>> So Terry, you mean it doesn't
always have to be tangible.

34
00:01:44.103 --> 00:01:44.968
>> Exactly.

35
00:01:44.968 --> 00:01:49.620
An asset can be a resource or
a capability, a skill set, right?

36
00:01:49.620 --> 00:01:51.731
And another thing to remember,

37
00:01:51.731 --> 00:01:55.570
is that these assets exists in
two domains or two classes.

38
00:01:55.570 --> 00:02:00.600
Cherokee, you got an idea what
those two classes might be?

39
00:02:00.600 --> 00:02:03.620
>> I see, what do we have
here in our little columns?

40
00:02:03.620 --> 00:02:05.639
Resources in the orange and
what does that say in the blue?

41
00:02:05.639 --> 00:02:06.229
The capabilities.

42
00:02:06.229 --> 00:02:06.792
>> The capabilities.

43
00:02:06.792 --> 00:02:08.337
>> I don't know,
is that really where we're heading?

44
00:02:08.337 --> 00:02:12.080
>> Well that's the types if you will,
that's the types of assets.

45
00:02:12.080 --> 00:02:13.539
But these assets exist in two domains.

46
00:02:13.539 --> 00:02:16.600
Customer assets and service assets.

47
00:02:16.600 --> 00:02:21.598
So IT has their resources and capabilities
and customers have their resources and

48
00:02:21.598 --> 00:02:22.618
capabilities.

49
00:02:22.618 --> 00:02:26.700
You recall the question,
the rhetorical question I asked.

50
00:02:26.700 --> 00:02:32.377
Do you have to be a geophysicist to work
in the IT department of a oil company?

51
00:02:32.377 --> 00:02:34.330
No, right?

52
00:02:34.330 --> 00:02:37.930
You have your assets and
resources and capabilities in IT, and

53
00:02:37.930 --> 00:02:41.370
you add those assets to customer assets,

54
00:02:41.370 --> 00:02:46.340
like the scientist,
the engineers in that oil company.

55
00:02:46.340 --> 00:02:49.990
And together, you create some sort of
business outcome, like finding oil,

56
00:02:49.990 --> 00:02:52.240
and extracting it and distributing it.

57
00:02:52.240 --> 00:02:57.540
So it's not IT's job to do the extraction,
the location and distributing.

58
00:02:57.540 --> 00:03:02.460
But it's IT's job to bring their assets,
so that the company's assets can be used

59
00:03:02.460 --> 00:03:05.600
to get those business outcomes achieved,
right?

60
00:03:05.600 --> 00:03:07.530
So that's another important
asset of the word assets.

61
00:03:07.530 --> 00:03:09.040
There's two types, resources and

62
00:03:09.040 --> 00:03:11.930
capabilities, and
they exist in two domains.

63
00:03:11.930 --> 00:03:16.190
As you consider service strategy and
service design and

64
00:03:16.190 --> 00:03:18.060
service offerings and agreements.

65
00:03:18.060 --> 00:03:22.481
You're necessarily going to have to
be concerned about customer assets,

66
00:03:22.481 --> 00:03:23.680
as well as your own.

67
00:03:23.680 --> 00:03:28.080
To ignore customer assets would
be doing so at your own peril.

68
00:03:28.080 --> 00:03:33.591
Because you might introduce a great
solution in the eyes of an IT person that

69
00:03:33.591 --> 00:03:38.940
is not really usable by a person in
the business, as an example, right?

70
00:03:38.940 --> 00:03:41.665
So that's why here's a reminder, okay?

71
00:03:41.665 --> 00:03:46.750
Again, words, what is a process?

72
00:03:46.750 --> 00:03:50.797
A structured set of activities, designed
to accomplish a specific objective.

73
00:03:50.797 --> 00:03:53.397
>> Now those,
do they have to go in sequential order?

74
00:03:53.397 --> 00:03:57.210
I've read in several books that that's
usually from the IT perspective, but

75
00:03:57.210 --> 00:03:59.183
is that here also with ITIL definition?

76
00:03:59.183 --> 00:04:02.940
>> Absolutely, a process,
it follows a flow.

77
00:04:02.940 --> 00:04:07.397
And while ITIL defines 26
processes that should be

78
00:04:07.397 --> 00:04:12.066
executed to be a successful
IT service organization.

79
00:04:12.066 --> 00:04:14.222
They don't tell you how to
define that process, so

80
00:04:14.222 --> 00:04:15.685
you should have these processes.

81
00:04:15.685 --> 00:04:16.964
>> The knowledge.

82
00:04:16.964 --> 00:04:19.762
>> The knowledge, and
I mean you should write them down.

83
00:04:19.762 --> 00:04:23.955
They just don't prescribe the specific
way you should do it in the process.

84
00:04:23.955 --> 00:04:28.765
That has to be adopted to the reality
of what business you're in, right?

85
00:04:28.765 --> 00:04:33.400
And keep in mind that there's business
processes and business outcomes, and

86
00:04:33.400 --> 00:04:35.040
there's IT processes and IT outcomes.

87
00:04:35.040 --> 00:04:37.045
And again,
as we've talked about resources,

88
00:04:37.045 --> 00:04:39.007
what you're trying to
do is harmonize those.

89
00:04:39.007 --> 00:04:44.143
So that what IT is doing on behalf of
the business process wise, is in effect

90
00:04:44.143 --> 00:04:49.300
moving the needle in the right
direction for the business themselves.

91
00:04:49.300 --> 00:04:51.484
>> And Terry, there's also I
know from my experience in IT,

92
00:04:51.484 --> 00:04:54.533
there are a lot of different white papers
out there and different publications.

93
00:04:54.533 --> 00:04:58.343
Organizations that offer guidelines for
specific IT processes for

94
00:04:58.343 --> 00:05:03.100
like you've mentioned, depending on
whatever field or industry that you're in?

95
00:05:04.200 --> 00:05:07.240
>> Right, well so what ITIL does
is a good example, Cherokee.

96
00:05:07.240 --> 00:05:09.607
What ITIL does,
is they describe this framework,

97
00:05:09.607 --> 00:05:11.988
these processes need to
interact with each other.

98
00:05:11.988 --> 00:05:16.367
And you can find various templates and
various downloadable services,

99
00:05:16.367 --> 00:05:20.327
you can hire consultants,
you could look at your own practices.

100
00:05:20.327 --> 00:05:23.456
There are some things that are reusable
from one place to another.

101
00:05:23.456 --> 00:05:25.987
But ITIL presents its findings and

102
00:05:25.987 --> 00:05:32.390
its best practise at a higher level before
defining what you should do or must do.

103
00:05:32.390 --> 00:05:36.240
They describe here's the framework
adapted to your reality.

104
00:05:36.240 --> 00:05:37.860
>> Okay, I got you, thank you.
>> You better.

105
00:05:39.130 --> 00:05:43.780
All right, so moving forward, looking
at the characteristics of a process.

106
00:05:45.060 --> 00:05:49.129
They are measurable,
they provide some sort of output for

107
00:05:49.129 --> 00:05:52.460
specific results to
a specific stake holders.

108
00:05:52.460 --> 00:05:55.430
You see the term customer focus?

109
00:05:55.430 --> 00:06:01.530
Absolutely, you're trying to do this
on behalf of your customers, right?

110
00:06:01.530 --> 00:06:04.700
And response to specific events or
triggers.

111
00:06:04.700 --> 00:06:08.450
So something gets them started, they

112
00:06:08.450 --> 00:06:13.410
spit out something of use to
a particular stake holder, right?

113
00:06:13.410 --> 00:06:17.450
And this process,
all these processes should be measurable.

114
00:06:17.450 --> 00:06:19.366
The implication is there,
you actually measure them.

115
00:06:19.366 --> 00:06:23.243
So again, ITIL describes 26 processes.

116
00:06:23.243 --> 00:06:27.325
They are high on the idea

117
00:06:27.325 --> 00:06:29.755
that you should also measure
these processes you implement.

118
00:06:29.755 --> 00:06:32.095
So what does measurement mean?

119
00:06:32.095 --> 00:06:33.283
When you consider for

120
00:06:33.283 --> 00:06:37.375
instance the success of incident
management which is when a user calls and

121
00:06:37.375 --> 00:06:41.810
says, I'm having an issue with this
application or an issue with the service.

122
00:06:41.810 --> 00:06:45.110
>> So our metrics may be of response time.

123
00:06:45.110 --> 00:06:48.173
>> Exactly, how quickly did it take
you to respond to that call, or

124
00:06:48.173 --> 00:06:50.535
how quickly did it take you to fix it-
>> Right.

125
00:06:50.535 --> 00:06:51.515
>> If there's something broken, right?

126
00:06:51.515 --> 00:06:53.588
So we're talking about measuring, right?

127
00:06:53.588 --> 00:06:57.090
So that's just an example
of measuring a process.

128
00:06:57.090 --> 00:07:00.050
As it relates to strategy and design,

129
00:07:00.050 --> 00:07:04.215
what you want to measure is
the ultimate success of the process.

130
00:07:04.215 --> 00:07:05.925
Is it fit for purpose?

131
00:07:05.925 --> 00:07:09.025
Does it actually satisfy customer needs?

132
00:07:09.025 --> 00:07:13.285
And does it allow the customer to be more
successful, really what it comes down to.

133
00:07:13.285 --> 00:07:19.205
So measuring your processes is a
fundamental feature of process ownership.

134
00:07:19.205 --> 00:07:20.215
And as it relates to design,

135
00:07:20.215 --> 00:07:26.050
which we're gonna be talking about In
depth as we go through this course

136
00:07:26.050 --> 00:07:31.220
is that measurement is something you
need to define as a designed element.

137
00:07:31.220 --> 00:07:35.690
You dont wait until operations to figure
out how we're going to measure this thing.

138
00:07:35.690 --> 00:07:37.980
You build into the design of the service.

139
00:07:37.980 --> 00:07:43.460
We will be reinforcing this idea
many times as we go through, okay?

140
00:07:45.070 --> 00:07:49.070
So process model effectively
what a process model is,

141
00:07:49.070 --> 00:07:52.430
is understanding what the process
is trying to get done.

142
00:07:52.430 --> 00:07:56.020
You'll see in the red text there
process definition, right?

143
00:07:56.020 --> 00:07:58.630
Understanding what it's trying to do.

144
00:07:58.630 --> 00:08:00.700
Understanding a process owner,

145
00:08:00.700 --> 00:08:04.880
what objectives are actually trying
to be achieved by the process.

146
00:08:04.880 --> 00:08:07.239
So a process has a genesis,
why do we even do this?

147
00:08:07.239 --> 00:08:10.193
Why do we have an incident
management process?

148
00:08:10.193 --> 00:08:13.010
Why do we have a change
management process?

149
00:08:13.010 --> 00:08:17.715
More relevant to our course, why would we
have a business relationship process or

150
00:08:17.715 --> 00:08:21.585
a financial management process,
why do we have them?

151
00:08:21.585 --> 00:08:25.532
A process model is defining the whose and
the whys of any given process, and

152
00:08:25.532 --> 00:08:28.869
it's backed by governance,
it's backed by policy, right?

153
00:08:28.869 --> 00:08:31.370
So it's one thing to have a process.

154
00:08:31.370 --> 00:08:35.240
It's another thing to make sure it's
followed, and that it's done well.

155
00:08:35.240 --> 00:08:38.665
So that's when you get involved in
the measurement of the process, and

156
00:08:38.665 --> 00:08:40.502
the policies backing up the process.

157
00:08:40.502 --> 00:08:46.020
And the audit, going around and seeing,
are you following the process or not?

158
00:08:46.020 --> 00:08:49.140
So that's also part of the process
model and of course, you need something

159
00:08:49.140 --> 00:08:52.110
that enables the process, that's
the people that actually get it done.

160
00:08:52.110 --> 00:08:56.917
You have wise people trained in
the process, understand how to use it, and

161
00:08:56.917 --> 00:08:59.300
do so consistently and well, okay?

162
00:08:59.300 --> 00:09:03.060
Again, reviewing these topics, question.

163
00:09:03.060 --> 00:09:04.580
What is a process model?

164
00:09:04.580 --> 00:09:08.050
You just need to consider that
processes need to be backed by

165
00:09:08.050 --> 00:09:10.470
a model of governance,
auditing, and measurement.

166
00:09:11.940 --> 00:09:16.470
Again going through these definitions,
words you're gonna encounter on the exam.

167
00:09:17.650 --> 00:09:21.520
Not as a question, but
just as part of the language, a function.

168
00:09:21.520 --> 00:09:24.470
A function is a group of
people with special skills or

169
00:09:24.470 --> 00:09:26.890
tools that's short hand for it.

170
00:09:26.890 --> 00:09:29.780
Where as a process,
it's a structure set of activities.

171
00:09:29.780 --> 00:09:33.958
A function is a group of people
that get things done, right?

172
00:09:33.958 --> 00:09:36.800
They have special skills and
tools to get those things done.

173
00:09:36.800 --> 00:09:37.770
So I tell this,

174
00:09:37.770 --> 00:09:42.600
again the really good at kind of devolving
things down at the digestible bits.

175
00:09:42.600 --> 00:09:45.169
And they define four functions,
in fact an only four.

176
00:09:45.169 --> 00:09:49.770
An applications management, those people
that know every thing about application.

177
00:09:49.770 --> 00:09:53.475
Technology management, those people know
everything who knows about infrastructure.

178
00:09:53.475 --> 00:09:59.839
Backend, servers, data bases, networks,
cloud computing, web services etc.

179
00:09:59.839 --> 00:10:04.564
And then you have day to day operations,
the things that have to happen everyday.

180
00:10:04.564 --> 00:10:08.995
Not necessarily experts, but people
that just do the day to day grind of IT.

181
00:10:08.995 --> 00:10:13.562
And then you have a other
function called service desk,

182
00:10:13.562 --> 00:10:19.790
that interface between the service
provider and the end users, all right?

183
00:10:19.790 --> 00:10:20.878
Good deal.

184
00:10:20.878 --> 00:10:22.850
Now what about roles?

185
00:10:25.080 --> 00:10:29.825
Roles are specific people with specific

186
00:10:29.825 --> 00:10:33.195
points of accountability and
here's one called the process owner.

187
00:10:33.195 --> 00:10:36.987
Nice generically described, the process
owner is accountable to ensure that

188
00:10:36.987 --> 00:10:40.384
the process is performed according
to agreed in documented process.

189
00:10:40.384 --> 00:10:45.340
And it meets the goals,
it's fit for purpose, right?

190
00:10:45.340 --> 00:10:49.481
So a process owner doesn't necessarily
get involved in the day to day grind of

191
00:10:49.481 --> 00:10:51.023
the execution of a process.

192
00:10:51.023 --> 00:10:56.015
But has defined it, has trained it,
has enabled its measurement, has ensured

193
00:10:56.015 --> 00:11:01.460
that it's followed and auditable and
ultimately that it's fit for purpose.

194
00:11:01.460 --> 00:11:04.100
So a process owner is someone
that's accountable for

195
00:11:04.100 --> 00:11:09.040
the quality of a process
throughout its life cycle, okay?

196
00:11:09.040 --> 00:11:11.050
Now again, this is generic role.

197
00:11:11.050 --> 00:11:15.620
Later on, we'll be talking about service
portfolio management as a process.

198
00:11:15.620 --> 00:11:18.360
To make service portfolio
management happen,

199
00:11:18.360 --> 00:11:21.280
if you want to get that done
as an IT service provider.

200
00:11:21.280 --> 00:11:24.310
The one of the first things
you do is name someone,

201
00:11:24.310 --> 00:11:27.280
the owner of the service
portfolio management process.

202
00:11:27.280 --> 00:11:30.000
They become the owner of that process.

203
00:11:30.000 --> 00:11:33.487
>> So Terry, you had mentioned in
the previous slide about the importance of

204
00:11:33.487 --> 00:11:36.029
process governance and
just really enforcing that.

205
00:11:36.029 --> 00:11:39.587
Now I've worked in a capacity for
process improvement and

206
00:11:39.587 --> 00:11:42.570
I saw that there wasn't
any kind of governance.

207
00:11:42.570 --> 00:11:47.071
And people were just kind of taking it
upon themselves to modify that process in

208
00:11:47.071 --> 00:11:49.380
a way that might help themselves.

209
00:11:49.380 --> 00:11:53.345
So if a process owner sees that happening
with they could have pull in some one to

210
00:11:53.345 --> 00:11:56.668
perhaps initiate a process improvement or
something like that?

211
00:11:56.668 --> 00:12:01.097
>> Interesting how you ask that question
cuz I think it's a common symptom of

212
00:12:01.097 --> 00:12:05.111
dysfunction, to have a process
without the process being owned.

213
00:12:05.111 --> 00:12:09.331
So ITIL would consider a predictive step,

214
00:12:09.331 --> 00:12:14.372
a predicate step,
a first step in the definition of

215
00:12:14.372 --> 00:12:20.133
a process is to name an owner,
it organically developed.

216
00:12:20.133 --> 00:12:21.124
>> Wait until the problem occurs.

217
00:12:21.124 --> 00:12:23.101
>> Right, be in front of it, and

218
00:12:23.101 --> 00:12:27.270
give someone the authority
through process ownership.

219
00:12:27.270 --> 00:12:30.180
They are empowered to be
owner of this process, and

220
00:12:30.180 --> 00:12:32.400
they make sure that it works and
fits the purpose.

221
00:12:32.400 --> 00:12:35.368
So as it relates to continuous
improvement, the example you cited.

222
00:12:35.368 --> 00:12:40.138
ITIL would say if you want
to have a CSI approach and

223
00:12:40.138 --> 00:12:47.550
you want to make it methodical,
you should determine improvement process.

224
00:12:47.550 --> 00:12:51.127
Assign an owner to it and let them beat
the drum and crack the whip as necessary.

225
00:12:51.127 --> 00:12:52.299
>> [LAUGH] All right.

226
00:12:52.299 --> 00:12:53.660
>> Yeah, good question.

227
00:12:54.830 --> 00:12:57.119
Now a process manager is
their accountable for

228
00:12:57.119 --> 00:12:59.358
the operational management of the process.

229
00:12:59.358 --> 00:13:02.079
So while the owner owns the process.

230
00:13:02.079 --> 00:13:08.130
The process manager manages
it on a day to day basis.

231
00:13:08.130 --> 00:13:11.781
Now could any one person be both
a process owner and a process manager?

232
00:13:11.781 --> 00:13:13.487
>> I don't seem so.

233
00:13:13.487 --> 00:13:15.358
>> Yeah.
>> Specially considering some budgets.

234
00:13:15.358 --> 00:13:18.037
>> Right, and
the size of the organization, right?

235
00:13:18.037 --> 00:13:19.551
>> Sure.
>> Absolutely, so

236
00:13:19.551 --> 00:13:22.688
don't think of these as
an organizational chart.

237
00:13:22.688 --> 00:13:23.956
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> Right,

238
00:13:23.956 --> 00:13:25.946
these are roles that should be played,

239
00:13:25.946 --> 00:13:29.940
if you put both of these roles in the mind
of one person, that's totally fine.

240
00:13:29.940 --> 00:13:32.185
>> Okay.
>> It's totally fine.

241
00:13:32.185 --> 00:13:33.852
In fact, it's not even hierarchical,

242
00:13:33.852 --> 00:13:36.066
even if you separate the roles
in a different people.

243
00:13:36.066 --> 00:13:41.298
It could be that a process owner is
actually outranked by a process manager.

244
00:13:41.298 --> 00:13:44.944
So this is not describing an hierarchical
organizational relationship either.

245
00:13:44.944 --> 00:13:45.516
>> Okay.

246
00:13:45.516 --> 00:13:49.288
>> And
then you have process practitioners,

247
00:13:49.288 --> 00:13:54.370
people carrying out one or
more process activities.

248
00:13:54.370 --> 00:13:58.890
Now again, could any given person be
a process owner, a process manager and

249
00:13:58.890 --> 00:14:00.220
a practitioner?

250
00:14:00.220 --> 00:14:03.381
Sure, could it be that the hierarchy
is not relevant here either?

251
00:14:03.381 --> 00:14:08.357
Absolutely, a process practitioner
could outrank a process manager or

252
00:14:08.357 --> 00:14:10.960
a process owner for that matter.

253
00:14:10.960 --> 00:14:12.796
A good example, change management.

254
00:14:12.796 --> 00:14:14.722
Change management process,

255
00:14:14.722 --> 00:14:19.815
there might be a step within the process
that requires senior level approval.

256
00:14:19.815 --> 00:14:20.352
>> Sure.

257
00:14:20.352 --> 00:14:21.067
>> Right?

258
00:14:21.067 --> 00:14:25.329
So in that case that senior level person
is actually a practitioner with a role

259
00:14:25.329 --> 00:14:26.523

00:14:26.523 --> 00:14:31.323
>> They might have that background
expertise to see if that change request

00:14:31.323 --> 00:14:36.355

like if it's applicable to that project.

262
00:14:36.355 --> 00:14:38.425
>> Absolutely, it could be for
technical acumen,

00:14:38.425 --> 00:14:42.865
it could be for finance,
it could be for business needs.

264
00:14:42.865 --> 00:14:47.485
Why you would have someone else involved

00:14:47.485 --> 00:14:49.327
They could outrank everyone else
in the process for that matter.

266
00:14:49.327 --> 00:14:49.902
>> Makes sense.

267
00:14:49.902 --> 00:14:54.260
>> So it's not hierarchical, not intended
to be, it's not organizational structure.

268
00:14:54.260 --> 00:14:58.550
Quite generically speaking then, we've
got process owner, process manager and

00:14:58.550 --> 00:15:00.200

00:15:00.200 --> 00:15:03.540
As this plays out on your exams,
you might be

the CIO on what roles

00:15:10.780 --> 00:15:15.330
should be brought to bare on a given
issue, this played out in a scenario.

00:15:15.330 --> 00:15:18.080
So you would need to
name the roles by name.

274
00:15:18.080 --> 00:15:20.806
We need a service portfolio
management process owner,

275
00:15:20.806 --> 00:15:24.354

manager owner, those types of things.

276
00:15:24.354 --> 00:15:28.516
So that's what these generic
roles turn into very specific

00:15:28.516 --> 00:15:30.355
actions as we go through.

00:15:30.355 --> 00:15:34.215
So as we talk about each of
the processes later on in the show,

you'll also have the opportunity to

00:15:42.989 --> 00:15:43.655
like this.

282
00:15:43.655 --> 00:15:48.570
All right, and the service owner.

283
00:15:48.570 --> 00:15:51.639
The service owner is accountable for

00:15:51.639 --> 00:15:55.997

that's short hand.

00:16:00.514 --> 00:16:03.400

Now this word accountable

00:16:09.786 --> 00:16:14.780

00:16:14.780 --> 00:16:18.190
Well accountable means,
you make sure it gets done.

00:16:18.190 --> 00:16:22.590
You don't actually do anything

00:16:22.590 --> 00:16:26.146
So notice the service owner is accountable
for the delivery of an IT service,

293
00:16:26.146 --> 00:16:29.062

the customer's needs, right?

294
00:16:29.062 --> 00:16:32.758
They have lots of people that's
gonna help them do that, right?

295
00:16:32.758 --> 00:16:36.340
Quite generic in its description,
service owner.

296
00:16:37.360 --> 00:16:39.201
Depending on what service is
in play at any given time.

297
00:16:39.201 --> 00:16:40.676
As this plays out on an exam,

298
00:16:40.676 --> 00:16:44.868
you might be looking at a situation where
the service owners been doing reviews.

00:16:44.868 --> 00:16:47.828
And getting complaints
from the costumers that

00:16:47.828 --> 00:16:51.162
their services not's a able

00:16:51.162 --> 00:16:55.260
The service owner needed to go to service
strategist to come up with an idea

00:16:55.260 --> 00:16:57.320
probably going to fix that, right?

00:16:57.320 --> 00:17:00.993
So [INAUDIBLE], we'll be talking about the
role of business relationship management

00:17:00.993 --> 00:17:02.480
a little bit later on as a process.

00:17:03.840 --> 00:17:09.660

You could see that the service owner

00:17:15.380 --> 00:17:17.260
So try to connect the dots

00:17:18.550 --> 00:17:20.550
That'll all be playing out later

00:17:20.550 --> 00:17:21.837
business relationship management.

All right, very good, so that is it for

00:17:26.622 --> 00:17:32.580

00:17:32.580 --> 00:17:37.079
What's up next is gonna be start looking

00:17:38.975 --> 00:17:39.919

00:17:39.919 --> 00:17:40.702
