So not just do it at any cause, but

465
00:25:38.800 --> 00:25:42.630
do it effectively for
cost effectively for risks, right.

466
00:25:42.630 --> 00:25:46.605
So, value is often rendered than dollars.

467
00:25:46.605 --> 00:25:50.805
But it's also as often rendered
in non-monetary terms.

468
00:25:50.805 --> 00:25:52.285
But who defines it?

469
00:25:52.285 --> 00:25:53.525
The customer.

470
00:25:53.525 --> 00:25:58.695
The customer's perception or opinion about
value is the only one that really matters.

471
00:26:00.355 --> 00:26:03.285
That's not just ITIL speaking,
it's just practical terms.

472
00:26:03.285 --> 00:26:08.630
If they think it's slow, it's slow, right?

473
00:26:08.630 --> 00:26:12.690
Or they think it's too much or
cost too much or it's not effective,

474
00:26:12.690 --> 00:26:16.280
it's counter intuitive,
then their opinion matters.

475
00:26:16.280 --> 00:26:19.355
It's not that the customers are always
right, this is their opinion so

476
00:26:19.355 --> 00:26:21.670
when it matters when it comes to value.

477
00:26:21.670 --> 00:26:25.090
Okay, so
they look at value through three lenses.

478
00:26:26.130 --> 00:26:29.980
Business outcomes,
perceptions, and preferences.

479
00:26:29.980 --> 00:26:34.900
So to close up this [INAUDIBLE] segment,
we'll look at this in the next segment

480
00:26:34.900 --> 00:26:38.980
as relates to what is a business outcome,
what is perceptions and preferences.

481
00:26:38.980 --> 00:26:42.370
And wouldn't it be nice if we could
just focus on business outcomes?

482
00:26:42.370 --> 00:26:44.570
Come back for the next one and
we'll take a look at that.

483
00:26:44.570 --> 00:26:46.430
>> All right, Terry, thank you so
much for joining us.

484
00:26:46.430 --> 00:26:48.331
But as you heard it yourselves,
stay tuned,

485
00:26:48.331 --> 00:26:50.140
we have more information headed your way.

486
00:26:50.140 --> 00:26:52.270
But for this show,
we'll go ahead and sign out.

487
00:26:52.270 --> 00:26:54.040
Remember I'm your host, Chekoree Boose.

488
00:26:54.040 --> 00:26:56.079
>> And I'm Terry Decker.
>> See you next time here in ITProTV.

489
00:26:56.079 --> 00:27:03.825
[MUSIC]

490
00:27:03.825 --> 00:27:06.411
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Terry continue to set the context for strategic and design elements. They examine the "big picture" by explaining a high level overview of relationships between the various services you will learn of in the following shows.
episodes.title: The Big Picture of Strategy and Design Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:03.324
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.324 --> 00:00:09.635
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're

3
00:00:09.635 --> 00:00:13.185
watching ITProTV
>> Welcome ladies and

4
00:00:13.185 --> 00:00:16.850
gentlemen to your ITIL Service Offerings
and Agreements series.

5
00:00:16.850 --> 00:00:18.930
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:18.930 --> 00:00:22.180
In this episode, we'll continue to
take a look at the big picture.

7
00:00:22.180 --> 00:00:25.510
We'll specifically be defining
our strategy management and

8
00:00:25.510 --> 00:00:26.940
design coordination.

9
00:00:26.940 --> 00:00:28.670
And back in studios,
we have Mr Terry Decker.

10
00:00:28.670 --> 00:00:30.810
Thank you for joining us Terry.

11
00:00:30.810 --> 00:00:32.240
>> Glad to be here as always.

12
00:00:32.240 --> 00:00:36.120
And as we're talking about this big
picture, we've been looking at how service

13
00:00:36.120 --> 00:00:39.230
strategy is trying to make sure that
the right services are being offered.

14
00:00:39.230 --> 00:00:44.110
And the service design Is making
sure the strategy is realized and

15
00:00:44.110 --> 00:00:48.790
that the agreements for what success looks
like are clear and transparent to all.

16
00:00:48.790 --> 00:00:51.324
Okay, so as it relates to value,

17
00:00:51.324 --> 00:00:56.670
that's what the certifier has to deliver,
value to the customer.

18
00:00:56.670 --> 00:01:00.330
So what's the customers' idea of value?

19
00:01:00.330 --> 00:01:02.780
Right.
So we have to look at this slide here,

20
00:01:02.780 --> 00:01:06.530
you'll see that the customer
considers value through three lenses.

21
00:01:06.530 --> 00:01:09.810
Business outcomes,
perception, and preferences.

22
00:01:09.810 --> 00:01:16.260
It would be nice if IT could just focus
on business outcomes right, and not have

23
00:01:16.260 --> 00:01:22.530
to worry about these rather subjective
ideas of perception and preferences.

24
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:24.500
But you can't,
you have to focus on perception and

25
00:01:24.500 --> 00:01:27.180
preferences as well as business outcomes.

26
00:01:27.180 --> 00:01:29.780
I'll use a non-IT example
to kind of reinforce this.

27
00:01:31.500 --> 00:01:35.220
Imagine if the business outcome,
you've talked with the customers, and

28
00:01:35.220 --> 00:01:38.640
the business outcome is your
customers want the ability

29
00:01:38.640 --> 00:01:42.710
to lower the window of the car.

30
00:01:42.710 --> 00:01:46.330
You won't have the ability to
lower the window of the car.

31
00:01:46.330 --> 00:01:48.470
So you look at your IT budget.

32
00:01:48.470 --> 00:01:49.800
You look at the regulatory risk.

33
00:01:49.800 --> 00:01:51.930
You look at the skill set you have in IT.

34
00:01:51.930 --> 00:01:54.790
And you come up with the absolute
best solution based on those things.

35
00:01:54.790 --> 00:01:57.280
You know the business wants to be
able to lower the window on the car.

36
00:01:57.280 --> 00:02:02.660
It needs to be cost effective,
it needs to be risk averse and it needs to

37
00:02:02.660 --> 00:02:07.260
go ahead and match, obviously, the skills
and capabilities of your organization.

38
00:02:07.260 --> 00:02:10.210
So you come up with the perfect
solution based on business outcomes,

39
00:02:10.210 --> 00:02:13.920
cost considerations, safety,
and regulatory risks.

40
00:02:13.920 --> 00:02:16.310
And you deliver them a crank handle.

41
00:02:16.310 --> 00:02:17.835
Well, they can just crank it down.

42
00:02:17.835 --> 00:02:19.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> Appreciate the laughter,

43
00:02:19.240 --> 00:02:22.780
cuz most people don't perceive as a car
window being lowered as a crank handle

44
00:02:22.780 --> 00:02:25.070
anymore, because expectations,
perceptions, and

45
00:02:25.070 --> 00:02:30.660
preferences have certainly moved
the marker on the quality of the service.

46
00:02:30.660 --> 00:02:32.870
>> Yeah, some kids might not even
know what you're talking about.

47
00:02:32.870 --> 00:02:35.020
>> Exactly, good point, right.

48
00:02:35.020 --> 00:02:37.459
So again, kind of a silly example but

49
00:02:37.459 --> 00:02:42.060
it kinda points to you satisfied
the business outcome, clearly.

50
00:02:42.060 --> 00:02:43.670
The window can be lowered.

51
00:02:43.670 --> 00:02:48.140
It can be lowered if you've drive
into a lake and lose power.

52
00:02:48.140 --> 00:02:50.410
>> Yeah.
>> It can still be lowered, right,

53
00:02:50.410 --> 00:02:51.460
it's easy to replace.

54
00:02:51.460 --> 00:02:53.530
It's easy to manufacture, right.

55
00:02:53.530 --> 00:02:57.740
The regulatory, the Feds aren't on our
butt for safety regulations, right.

56
00:02:57.740 --> 00:03:00.490
We have limited our regulatory risk.

57
00:03:00.490 --> 00:03:03.210
Business, what more could you possibly,
ask for?

58
00:03:03.210 --> 00:03:04.150
This is what you need.

59
00:03:04.150 --> 00:03:05.600
Stop talking to us.

60
00:03:05.600 --> 00:03:07.570
Right, that would be inappropriate for
IT to do.

61
00:03:09.160 --> 00:03:12.120
Again, I've worked at IT organizations
that maybe weren't that bad.

62
00:03:12.120 --> 00:03:13.960
But they did have a predisposition.

63
00:03:13.960 --> 00:03:15.000
We know what's best.

64
00:03:15.000 --> 00:03:16.130
We know the technology.

65
00:03:16.130 --> 00:03:17.640
We know our skill set.

66
00:03:17.640 --> 00:03:19.090
We know what we can and can't do.

67
00:03:19.090 --> 00:03:23.210
We know what cost parameters are in play,
risk parameters in play.

68
00:03:23.210 --> 00:03:25.380
Unfortunately, you can't
get away with that.

69
00:03:25.380 --> 00:03:27.030
They may have the reception or

70
00:03:27.030 --> 00:03:30.230
the preference that it is electric window,
cleared.

71
00:03:30.230 --> 00:03:33.940
They may even have the extra perception
that you don't even have to hold

72
00:03:33.940 --> 00:03:37.710
the button down, you just have to click it
once, right, and it goes down by itself.

73
00:03:37.710 --> 00:03:43.120
And that also, that feature also
serves the passenger windows, right?

74
00:03:43.120 --> 00:03:44.370
To heck with the people in the back seats,

75
00:03:44.370 --> 00:03:46.460
they didn't even have to
wear their safety belts.

76
00:03:46.460 --> 00:03:47.670
We don't care about them apparently.

77
00:03:47.670 --> 00:03:51.270
I don't know what it is about that but
at any rate, I digress.

78
00:03:51.270 --> 00:03:54.700
The idea of this perception and
preferences related to

79
00:03:54.700 --> 00:03:58.210
the window being lowered, what I'm
getting at is there is nuance in it.

80
00:03:58.210 --> 00:03:59.520
Right?
What do they want?

81
00:03:59.520 --> 00:04:03.090
Do they want a single button push,
or is it okay if it just holds down?

82
00:04:03.090 --> 00:04:04.860
What about the upward motion?

83
00:04:04.860 --> 00:04:06.520
Does that need to be automatic?

84
00:04:06.520 --> 00:04:08.820
If that's also automatic,
what about the pinch factor?

85
00:04:08.820 --> 00:04:11.530
Do we have to have the automatic
detection and rollback?

86
00:04:11.530 --> 00:04:14.440
I mean,
you see how complicated it can get, right?

87
00:04:14.440 --> 00:04:19.600
So knowing your customer, knowing
what they might perceive or prefer,

88
00:04:19.600 --> 00:04:24.210
Is as important as knowing what the actual
outcome is that we're trying to achieve.

89
00:04:24.210 --> 00:04:27.320
As an IT server, by the way,
you gotta consider all the three things.

90
00:04:27.320 --> 00:04:29.970
Is this kind of thing placed out on exam,

91
00:04:29.970 --> 00:04:35.480
it really is more in the idea of
recognition of what the customer wants.

92
00:04:35.480 --> 00:04:38.960
They're not going to probably get
involved in a nuanced discussion of

93
00:04:38.960 --> 00:04:41.800
what's best perception or
preference wise, right?

94
00:04:41.800 --> 00:04:45.030
You're gonna be focused on
business outcomes, surely you are.

95
00:04:45.030 --> 00:04:48.990
But if the scenario is playing out in such
a way where it's explicitly saying, and

96
00:04:48.990 --> 00:04:54.000
the customer is willing to pay for,
blah, blah, blah and

97
00:04:54.000 --> 00:04:58.510
prefers that then why would you
ignore that in your solution?

98
00:04:58.510 --> 00:05:00.410
Would be the way that kinda plays out,
a little bit.

99
00:05:00.410 --> 00:05:02.960
They're willing to pay for it,
there is some risk involved.

100
00:05:02.960 --> 00:05:04.960
They're willing to pay for it, hey, go.

101
00:05:04.960 --> 00:05:09.400
Now if on the other side of the coin,
they're very cost-averse,

102
00:05:09.400 --> 00:05:11.030
keep it as cheap as possible.

103
00:05:11.030 --> 00:05:13.750
Then you also need to manage
your customers, in this regard.

104
00:05:13.750 --> 00:05:16.700
So maybe you do give them
a window that's a crank handle.

105
00:05:16.700 --> 00:05:19.986
But you do manage your preferences and
you manage your perceptions so

106
00:05:19.986 --> 00:05:23.907
they're not aghast or agog when you
actually deliver that particular solution.

107
00:05:23.907 --> 00:05:28.350
>> You might even market it as the value,
flagship or whatever it may be.

108
00:05:28.350 --> 00:05:30.900
>> Absolutely,
that's a good call Cherokee.

109
00:05:30.900 --> 00:05:34.240
You might even market it as here's what
we're providing you, as delivered.

110
00:05:34.240 --> 00:05:35.080
We're saving you money.

111
00:05:35.080 --> 00:05:36.040
We're doing this.

112
00:05:36.040 --> 00:05:38.660
Safety regulations,
the Feds are off our back.

113
00:05:38.660 --> 00:05:40.880
Blah, blah, blah, you get the idea.

114
00:05:40.880 --> 00:05:42.480
All right, very good.

115
00:05:44.500 --> 00:05:48.400
Now this is a interesting graphic
as you go to the full screen here.

116
00:05:48.400 --> 00:05:56.130
You'll see that value added is not really
anything until value is realized, right.

117
00:05:56.130 --> 00:05:59.940
All this really means is in the service
chain is you're trying to deliver what

118
00:06:01.420 --> 00:06:02.270
we're delivering today.

119
00:06:02.270 --> 00:06:08.670
We're trying to deliver ITIL learning
through a web interface with video content

120
00:06:08.670 --> 00:06:13.770
and experts and a hostess making
sure everything is working well.

121
00:06:13.770 --> 00:06:17.810
All right, I'm adding value,
the technology's adding value.

122
00:06:17.810 --> 00:06:19.180
Cherokee is adding value.

123
00:06:19.180 --> 00:06:20.990
The lights are adding value.

124
00:06:20.990 --> 00:06:23.450
Our editors are adding value, right?

125
00:06:23.450 --> 00:06:28.300
We have value added all along this
stream of delivering this to you.

126
00:06:28.300 --> 00:06:29.380
But when does it really matter?

127
00:06:30.650 --> 00:06:32.000
When you can use it.

128
00:06:32.000 --> 00:06:34.240
That's when value is actually realized.

129
00:06:34.240 --> 00:06:35.940
All these other things have to be added.

130
00:06:35.940 --> 00:06:37.610
I mean we have to do these things.

131
00:06:37.610 --> 00:06:40.220
I couldn't do it without
the technology being here.

132
00:06:40.220 --> 00:06:41.600
I couldn't do it without
Cherokee being here.

133
00:06:41.600 --> 00:06:43.405
>> I surely couldn't
host the show on my own.

134
00:06:43.405 --> 00:06:44.390
[LAUGH]
>> Right, there you go.

135
00:06:44.390 --> 00:06:46.900
So we're all adding this value and
that's important.

136
00:06:46.900 --> 00:06:49.120
The technology is adding value,
people are adding value.

137
00:06:49.120 --> 00:06:51.320
We need to bring this value and
we're adding it.

138
00:06:51.320 --> 00:06:52.770
We certainly are but

139
00:06:52.770 --> 00:06:58.430
value is not realized until the customer
can realize the value themselves, right?

140
00:06:58.430 --> 00:07:00.210
So you're gonna get subscribers.

141
00:07:00.210 --> 00:07:01.120
You're gonna get members.

142
00:07:01.120 --> 00:07:03.330
You're going to get people viewing, right?

143
00:07:03.330 --> 00:07:06.920
That's gonna be your measurement of,
are they finding value in this?

144
00:07:06.920 --> 00:07:08.200
Perhaps they provide feedback.

145
00:07:08.200 --> 00:07:11.510
Perhaps they pass the exam and
say hey thanks a lot,

146
00:07:11.510 --> 00:07:14.090
I couldn't have done that without you,
those kinds of things, right?

147
00:07:14.090 --> 00:07:17.770
That's what we're trying to get done here
as value being realized on behalf of

148
00:07:17.770 --> 00:07:18.730
customers.

149
00:07:18.730 --> 00:07:21.910
We're not doing this for
any other reason, right?

150
00:07:21.910 --> 00:07:24.170
Value to customers is the focus, right?

151
00:07:24.170 --> 00:07:27.840
And of course, we get to make some money
along the way, you get to pass exams along

152
00:07:27.840 --> 00:07:32.728
the way and that's why we're trying
to generate the value being realized.

153
00:07:32.728 --> 00:07:36.490
Okay, all right.

154
00:07:36.490 --> 00:07:40.670
Again nothing magical about that
concept just pretty straightforward.

155
00:07:40.670 --> 00:07:44.037
Realizing that value realized is not
the same thing as value being added.

156
00:07:45.950 --> 00:07:49.491
My goodness,
what does service design have in scope?

157
00:07:49.491 --> 00:07:54.162
I mentioned earlier in quite
generic terms, answering all

158
00:07:54.162 --> 00:07:59.777
the questions that need to be answered
before it gets into transition.

159
00:07:59.777 --> 00:08:01.765
Before you even start
building the service,

160
00:08:01.765 --> 00:08:04.720
you answer all the questions
that need to be answered.

161
00:08:04.720 --> 00:08:07.970
>> Yeah, and it's kind of interesting
looking at different disciplines and

162
00:08:07.970 --> 00:08:08.930
bodies of knowledge.

163
00:08:08.930 --> 00:08:13.400
And when we talk about project management,
they might have their own approach to it.

164
00:08:13.400 --> 00:08:18.550
You'll see that first phase, or section,
or however they want to word it, but that

165
00:08:18.550 --> 00:08:22.550
planning is always going to be where most
of the work is happening, right Terry?

166
00:08:22.550 --> 00:08:23.380
>> Absolutely.

167
00:08:23.380 --> 00:08:26.340
Getting that right is also so
predictive of the success.

168
00:08:26.340 --> 00:08:28.660
Getting that wrong,
you're less successful.

169
00:08:28.660 --> 00:08:32.510
If you plan inappropriately,
you'll put out fires later, basically,

170
00:08:32.510 --> 00:08:33.900
is what it points to.

171
00:08:33.900 --> 00:08:36.720
So, that means, there's a lot in scope.

172
00:08:36.720 --> 00:08:38.820
What is the scope of service design?

173
00:08:38.820 --> 00:08:40.970
Every question that needs to be asked and

174
00:08:40.970 --> 00:08:45.890
answered before you even go to the next
stage which I took all service transition.

175
00:08:45.890 --> 00:08:48.990
Which is a stage yet
before service operations.

176
00:08:48.990 --> 00:08:51.490
Quite early in the process.

177
00:08:51.490 --> 00:08:54.510
And also keep in mind that these
don't operate in a vacuum.

178
00:08:54.510 --> 00:08:58.280
Service design is gonna be operating
under constraints of time and money and

179
00:08:58.280 --> 00:08:59.560
resources, right?

180
00:08:59.560 --> 00:09:01.770
Just as any project might, right?

181
00:09:01.770 --> 00:09:06.940
So operating within those constraints
to answer all the questions

182
00:09:06.940 --> 00:09:14.110
as fully as possible before moving forward
is the goal and scope of service design.

183
00:09:14.110 --> 00:09:17.840
And design coordination, that would be
the process that makes that happen.

184
00:09:17.840 --> 00:09:25.230
Now the output, as defined by ITIL,
is called a service design package, right?

185
00:09:25.230 --> 00:09:27.800
The service design package is the package.

186
00:09:27.800 --> 00:09:28.860
It's a good name for it.

187
00:09:28.860 --> 00:09:33.890
It is what is required before service
transition can actually get started

188
00:09:34.920 --> 00:09:36.510
and moving on their work, right?

189
00:09:36.510 --> 00:09:37.462
Now some of these things
can happy in parallel.

190
00:09:37.462 --> 00:09:41.779
It's not like when this is complete,
service transition has to wait for

191
00:09:41.779 --> 00:09:43.080
everything.

192
00:09:43.080 --> 00:09:47.230
But the service design package is
going to be the culmination of

193
00:09:47.230 --> 00:09:50.270
all the artifacts required,
all the questions being answered.

194
00:09:50.270 --> 00:09:52.810
So I'll give you an example.

195
00:09:52.810 --> 00:09:56.660
If you're involved perhaps in
the software development life cycle,

196
00:09:56.660 --> 00:09:58.240
some of this might be familiar to you.

197
00:09:58.240 --> 00:10:00.510
You come up with business requirements,

198
00:10:00.510 --> 00:10:03.400
you come up with functional
requirements for the solution.

199
00:10:03.400 --> 00:10:06.120
Maybe that leads to system requirements,

200
00:10:06.120 --> 00:10:09.860
which leads to a technical specification
or a design specification.

201
00:10:09.860 --> 00:10:13.835
All those things I just mentioned,
business requirements, functional system,

202
00:10:13.835 --> 00:10:18.820
design spec,
all those things end up being artifacts,

203
00:10:18.820 --> 00:10:23.450
documents, something that's written
down and understood and agreed.

204
00:10:23.450 --> 00:10:27.170
Maybe come up with
a solution architecture,

205
00:10:27.170 --> 00:10:30.790
which shows the big picture of client
servers and how they talk to each other.

206
00:10:30.790 --> 00:10:33.351

learn on your own, and that's going
to be good motivation to self-study.

684
00:34:58.368 --> 00:35:02.422
And there's a specific exercise related to
some of these topics we've talked about.

685
00:35:02.422 --> 00:35:04.945
That exercise is called
Generic Role activities.

686
00:35:04.945 --> 00:35:09.106
So it's one of the downloads of that
title, Generic Role activities.

687
00:35:09.106 --> 00:35:11.656
The suggested timing's about 20 minutes.

688
00:35:11.656 --> 00:35:12.888
And again, what's it gonna focus one?

689
00:35:12.888 --> 00:35:15.822
It's gonna focus on the process owner,
process manager, and

690
00:35:15.822 --> 00:35:19.265
process practitioner roles,
as well as the service owner.

691
00:35:19.265 --> 00:35:22.605
So it gets your juices
flowing in your self-study.

692
00:35:22.605 --> 00:35:24.165
It's a pretty easy one to do.

693
00:35:24.165 --> 00:35:24.965
And again,

694
00:35:24.965 --> 00:35:29.022
it's just getting you into discipline
of following up with self-study.

695
00:35:29.022 --> 00:35:33.540
Remember, self-study is also
gonna include some exam practice.

696
00:35:33.540 --> 00:35:35.350
We'll get to that a little bit later.

697
00:35:35.350 --> 00:35:38.507
We're not quite ready to go and
practice any of the exams just yet.

698
00:35:38.507 --> 00:35:39.940
But that is where we're at.

699
00:35:39.940 --> 00:35:43.957
That concludes the part about
the big picture strategy and design,

700
00:35:43.957 --> 00:35:48.269
forming the basis of all of our learning
throughout the rest of the show.

701
00:35:48.269 --> 00:35:52.482
And next up, we're gonna start diving
into the processes themselves,

702
00:35:52.482 --> 00:35:56.990
the set of processes we're talking about,
the real meat of the course.

703
00:35:56.990 --> 00:35:59.840
And the first one of those processes
is Service Portfolio Management.

704
00:35:59.840 --> 00:36:03.063
So enjoy yourself, study,
remember those downloads,

705
00:36:03.063 --> 00:36:07.450
they're in the upper righthand
corner there from Show Files.

706
00:36:07.450 --> 00:36:10.210
And enjoy that, and let us know if you
have any questions through the forum.

707
00:36:10.210 --> 00:36:11.100
>> All right, Terry.

708
00:36:11.100 --> 00:36:14.280
Ladies and gentlemen,
you heard it yourself right from the man.

709
00:36:14.280 --> 00:36:15.350
We've got some homework to do.

710
00:36:15.350 --> 00:36:17.200
But that's all right,
great information there.

711
00:36:17.200 --> 00:36:19.810
So thank you, and thank you,
ladies and gentlemen, for joining us.

712
00:36:19.810 --> 00:36:22.420
But stay tuned,
we have more information headed your way.

713
00:36:22.420 --> 00:36:23.990
For this show we'll go ahead and sign out.

714
00:36:23.990 --> 00:36:25.930
Remember, I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

715
00:36:25.930 --> 00:36:26.700
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

716
00:36:26.700 --> 00:36:30.546
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

717
00:36:30.546 --> 00:36:36.145
[MUSIC]

718
00:36:36.145 --> 00:36:40.049
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Terry addresses how the process of Service Portfolio Management contributes to SOA practices. The lifecycle stage emphasized in this show is service strategy. A complete overview of the purpose, objectives, scope and importance of SPM as a process to generate business value is explored and demonstrated using examples. SPM policies, principles, concepts, activities, methods and techniques are explained in relation to SOA practices.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.732
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:01.732 --> 00:00:08.011
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.011 --> 00:00:11.795
>> Your watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.795 --> 00:00:14.970
>> Welcome to your ITIL Service Offerings
and Agreements series.

5
00:00:14.970 --> 00:00:17.074
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.074 --> 00:00:20.830
In this episode we'll be taking a look
at service portfolio management.

7
00:00:20.830 --> 00:00:24.340
And with us today, back in studios,
we have Mr.Terry Decker.

8
00:00:24.340 --> 00:00:25.558
Thank you for joining us today, Terry.

9
00:00:25.558 --> 00:00:28.350
>> As always, Cherokee, happy to be here.

10
00:00:28.350 --> 00:00:32.950
What's up in this particular episode
is an examination of the process called

11
00:00:32.950 --> 00:00:34.610
service portfolio management.

12
00:00:34.610 --> 00:00:38.080
In fact, the next several episodes
you're gonna be dealing with processes.

13
00:00:38.080 --> 00:00:41.110
The seven processes that are in scope for
this particular course.

14
00:00:41.110 --> 00:00:42.870
SOA, service offerings and agreements.

15
00:00:42.870 --> 00:00:47.860
So, as we look at the slides here,
service portfolio management.

16
00:00:47.860 --> 00:00:51.660
I want you to look at it as a tool,
the service portfolio.

17
00:00:51.660 --> 00:00:53.375
It's the deliverable, if you will,

18
00:00:53.375 --> 00:00:56.910
of service portfolio management;
it's gonna be the dataset.

19
00:00:56.910 --> 00:00:58.620
But I also want you to consider and

20
00:00:58.620 --> 00:01:02.250
accentuate your learning
regarding the process.

21
00:01:02.250 --> 00:01:06.233
Think more about the process of service
portfolio management as opposed to

22
00:01:06.233 --> 00:01:08.393
the actual deliverable, the tool set.

23
00:01:08.393 --> 00:01:10.554
Because, honestly,
in any given environment,

24
00:01:10.554 --> 00:01:13.080
the tool set's gonna manifest
itself in different ways.

25
00:01:13.080 --> 00:01:17.150
There's no one way to define what
this deliverable needs to look like.

26
00:01:17.150 --> 00:01:20.380
We'll give some general parameters of
what kind of data should be included

27
00:01:20.380 --> 00:01:22.934
in this portfolio, we certainly will.

28
00:01:22.934 --> 00:01:26.804
But academically speaking, and
even operationally speaking,

29
00:01:26.804 --> 00:01:31.096
it's going to be necessary to understand
the management process before

30
00:01:31.096 --> 00:01:32.874
you understand the tool set.

31
00:01:32.874 --> 00:01:36.208
The tool set is gonna
follow the process anyway.

32
00:01:36.208 --> 00:01:39.048
Academically speaking,
that's also important,

33
00:01:39.048 --> 00:01:42.667
because you're not gonna be asked
to design an IT tool on the exam.

34
00:01:42.667 --> 00:01:46.762
You're not gonna be asked to design
in detail a service portfolio.

35
00:01:46.762 --> 00:01:49.390
You need to understand what
it is in a big picture.

36
00:01:49.390 --> 00:01:52.020
And you need to understand what
data points it needs to have, but

37
00:01:52.020 --> 00:01:53.810
not design the full thing.

38
00:01:53.810 --> 00:01:56.870
So, as we learn about
the portfolio management process,

39
00:01:56.870 --> 00:01:59.610
I want you to focus more on the process.

40
00:01:59.610 --> 00:02:02.660
And not the derivable called
the service portfolio, itself.

41
00:02:02.660 --> 00:02:06.570
Now, we can't extract them completely,
we're gonna be talking about them both.

42
00:02:06.570 --> 00:02:08.660
The reason why I find
it's very important is,

43
00:02:08.660 --> 00:02:12.650
later on we're gonna be talking about a
process called service catalog management.

44
00:02:12.650 --> 00:02:16.055
And as you'll remind yourself
from your foundation course,

45
00:02:16.055 --> 00:02:19.136
the service catalog is
a portion of service portfolio.

46
00:02:19.136 --> 00:02:24.726
So another point of potential confusion
is where does the portfolio tool end and

47
00:02:24.726 --> 00:02:26.150
the catalog begin?

48
00:02:27.460 --> 00:02:29.400
That's kind of a non-starter,
they're integrated,

49
00:02:29.400 --> 00:02:31.960
they're part of the same
deliverable if you will.

50
00:02:31.960 --> 00:02:34.370
So, if you think about the processes,
however,

51
00:02:34.370 --> 00:02:38.100
there is a clear different mandate for
each of the different processes.

52
00:02:38.100 --> 00:02:43.010
They have different scope,
different process flows, etc.

53
00:02:43.010 --> 00:02:46.080
So think about the process
more than the tool.

54
00:02:46.080 --> 00:02:49.750
I invite you to do that to kind of save
yourself some sanity as you try to

55
00:02:49.750 --> 00:02:50.670
piece this thing together.

56
00:02:52.150 --> 00:02:55.750
All right, so
what is the portfolio itself, right?

57
00:02:55.750 --> 00:02:59.960
What you're trying to do with
a portfolio is describe what services

58
00:03:01.930 --> 00:03:04.120
are meeting what business outcomes.

59
00:03:05.170 --> 00:03:08.790
So it's a way that you can
map up what you have and

60
00:03:08.790 --> 00:03:12.600
what you don't have as relates to
what's the business trying to get done.

61
00:03:12.600 --> 00:03:15.427
So as you look at the full screen
of this particular PowerPoint.

62
00:03:15.427 --> 00:03:19.872
You'll see that your trying to answer
questions as why should a customer buy

63
00:03:19.872 --> 00:03:21.550
this service?

64
00:03:21.550 --> 00:03:22.690
Why they should buy it from you.

65
00:03:23.920 --> 00:03:25.725
What's the pricing and
charge back options?

66
00:03:25.725 --> 00:03:28.714
Where are your strengths and
where are your weaknesses?

67
00:03:28.714 --> 00:03:30.108
What's in the pipeline for later?

68
00:03:30.108 --> 00:03:33.180
Maybe you already have
an improvement plan in place, right?

69
00:03:33.180 --> 00:03:36.190
So you can see that you're being
transparent with what services

70
00:03:36.190 --> 00:03:36.960
you're offering.

71
00:03:36.960 --> 00:03:41.120
But in a way you're also being transparent
about what you could be offering, right?

72
00:03:41.120 --> 00:03:44.754
So this is getting engaged with your
customers at a meaningful level.

73
00:03:44.754 --> 00:03:47.530
Now, a lot of the process
is behind the scenes.

74
00:03:47.530 --> 00:03:53.540
IT is not gonna necessarily, expose
the whole portfolio to their customers.

75
00:03:53.540 --> 00:03:55.850
They'll certainly expose one part of it.

76
00:03:55.850 --> 00:04:00.210
The catalog, those operational services,
but not necessarily all of them.

77
00:04:00.210 --> 00:04:03.571
So again, think about the process more so
than the tool set.

78
00:04:03.571 --> 00:04:06.550
And I think you're gonna find
the academics a little bit more easier to

79
00:04:06.550 --> 00:04:07.320
swallow, okay?

80
00:04:08.880 --> 00:04:13.530
So as we go through then, what is
the purpose of the process at large?

81
00:04:13.530 --> 00:04:16.270
Basically to allow the provider to
make sure that the right services

82
00:04:16.270 --> 00:04:17.010
are being offered.

83
00:04:17.010 --> 00:04:23.280
The right balance of services in
terms of funding risk mitigation.

84
00:04:23.280 --> 00:04:25.510
What business outcomes are being served.

85
00:04:25.510 --> 00:04:27.010
Again, if you imagine that Barnes and

86
00:04:27.010 --> 00:04:31.580
Noble IT organization before Amazon.com
and the services they were offering.

87
00:04:31.580 --> 00:04:34.108
They offered IT services and
an online presence.

88
00:04:34.108 --> 00:04:40.050
You could order a book online and go pick
it up at the brick and mortar store.

89
00:04:40.050 --> 00:04:42.080
Or pay a bit more for shipping.

90
00:04:42.080 --> 00:04:45.470
Back in the day it was just you wanted to
go and have a nice cup of coffee anyway.

91
00:04:45.470 --> 00:04:46.638
So you went and had a cup of coffee,

92
00:04:46.638 --> 00:04:50.670
sit in a cushy chair, and you got
your book there from the front desk.

93
00:04:50.670 --> 00:04:54.205
Not a bad business model,
they had kiosks in the store.

94
00:04:54.205 --> 00:04:59.000
So if I walked in as the customer I could
go to the kiosk or I could ask a clerk,

95
00:04:59.000 --> 00:05:00.310
where is this book?

96
00:05:01.600 --> 00:05:04.880
First time I did it,
the clerk showed me how the kiosk works.

97
00:05:04.880 --> 00:05:08.740
Very clever, I came back to subsequent
visits, I used the kiosk itself.

98
00:05:09.770 --> 00:05:12.950
Pretty cool, I liked Barnes and
Noble, I liked their IT solutions.

99
00:05:12.950 --> 00:05:16.510
But Amazon.com changed their
business model quite a bit, right?

100
00:05:16.510 --> 00:05:20.868
>> Yeah, we don't really see things like
the dewy decimal system being really

101
00:05:20.868 --> 00:05:22.550
utilized that often.

102
00:05:22.550 --> 00:05:25.497
>> No, exactly, right,
different ways of managing these things.

103
00:05:25.497 --> 00:05:28.030
They're gonna show you a rack number,
and you're gonna get there.

104
00:05:28.030 --> 00:05:31.645
So you go to libraries, of course,
it's even changed by this, right?

105
00:05:31.645 --> 00:05:35.196
So, again, you're changing where
you are as a portfolio manager,

106
00:05:35.196 --> 00:05:38.300
you need to look at what
the business is trying to get done.

107
00:05:38.300 --> 00:05:41.200
What are the outcomes that
are being desired and

108
00:05:41.200 --> 00:05:45.140
are your services supporting
those outcomes, right?

109
00:05:45.140 --> 00:05:48.060
So you're gonna be looking
at the right costs,

110
00:05:48.060 --> 00:05:50.420
are you tracking
the investment appropriately?

111
00:05:50.420 --> 00:05:52.930
We'll look later at the details
of tracking investment through

112
00:05:52.930 --> 00:05:54.170
financial management.

113
00:05:54.170 --> 00:05:59.698
But portfolio has a stake in what
these services cost as a process.

114
00:05:59.698 --> 00:06:02.800
And also, make sure you're
working with other processes.

115
00:06:02.800 --> 00:06:04.290
Have you got the balance right?

116
00:06:04.290 --> 00:06:05.420
You're gonna be working with designers.

117
00:06:05.420 --> 00:06:07.060
You're gonna be working
with transition and

118
00:06:07.060 --> 00:06:11.570
operations folks to make sure that
what you're offering is sufficient.

119
00:06:11.570 --> 00:06:14.230
Or are there new technologies
that can be put into play?

120
00:06:14.230 --> 00:06:17.910
Again, consider back in the day
mainframe dummy terminals

121
00:06:17.910 --> 00:06:21.970
would client server with desktop
applications be more effective, right?

122
00:06:21.970 --> 00:06:24.180
That sort of thing, right?

123
00:06:24.180 --> 00:06:26.900
And then full circle
back to cloud services,

124
00:06:26.900 --> 00:06:30.122
which seems like just a web
device that can connect and

125
00:06:30.122 --> 00:06:34.070
use application services that
are being hosted, right.

126
00:06:34.070 --> 00:06:37.990
So, again, technology shifts,
customers need shifts.

127
00:06:37.990 --> 00:06:41.360
Portfolio management's here to
understand as those things shift,

128
00:06:41.360 --> 00:06:43.925
are we continuing to offer the right
value through our services, right?

129
00:06:43.925 --> 00:06:47.880
Focused on business outcomes.

130
00:06:47.880 --> 00:06:52.480
So the objectives of service portfolio
management is to make sure that you can

131
00:06:52.480 --> 00:06:57.460
follow these potential services
throughout their lifecycle.

132
00:06:57.460 --> 00:07:00.172
So that you can capture
the appropriate value statements.

133
00:07:00.172 --> 00:07:06.530
So that you can approve the right services
and therefore design the right services.

134
00:07:06.530 --> 00:07:08.758
And ultimately you're
also trying to determine,

135
00:07:08.758 --> 00:07:11.878
are the services that we currently have,
are they still adding value?

136
00:07:11.878 --> 00:07:15.510
Or is it time to retire them,
or to replace them, right?

137
00:07:15.510 --> 00:07:18.350
So which ones are still viable,
which ones still aren't?

138
00:07:18.350 --> 00:07:21.680
Which ones should we be offering,
that we're currently not?

139
00:07:21.680 --> 00:07:25.363
Are there additional customers we could
provide our existing services to?

140
00:07:25.363 --> 00:07:27.170
That type of thing, okay?

141
00:07:29.530 --> 00:07:32.000
So the scope of service
portfolio management.

142
00:07:32.000 --> 00:07:36.820
All services that are planned to be
delivered, that's called the pipeline.

143
00:07:36.820 --> 00:07:40.500
You might recall from your foundation
class, that there's three portions of

144
00:07:40.500 --> 00:07:43.700
the portfolio, the pipeline,
the catalog, and retired services.

145
00:07:43.700 --> 00:07:48.489
The pipeline's that portion of
the portfolio that describes services

146
00:07:48.489 --> 00:07:50.731
that could be approved, right?

147
00:07:50.731 --> 00:07:52.614
They're under consideration, right?

148
00:07:52.614 --> 00:07:55.207
Services that are currently
being delivered or

149
00:07:55.207 --> 00:07:58.975
have already been approved for
delivery are in the catalog portion.

150
00:07:58.975 --> 00:08:01.554
And then, of course,
those services that have been.

151
00:08:01.554 --> 00:08:05.780
Determined they're gonna be no
longer funded, or already did, or

152
00:08:05.780 --> 00:08:09.500
in the retired services portion
of the portfolio, right?

153
00:08:10.650 --> 00:08:15.710
So again, that's the tool set, pipeline,
catalog, and retired services.

154
00:08:15.710 --> 00:08:20.220
You also need a process to evaluate
the movement into the pipeline,

155
00:08:20.220 --> 00:08:23.970
from pipeline into catalog, and
from catalog into retired services.

156
00:08:23.970 --> 00:08:27.070
So it's one thing to have
the data set in a tool.

157
00:08:27.070 --> 00:08:30.720
It's another thing to have a methodical
process that does the ongoing evaluation

158
00:08:30.720 --> 00:08:34.240
of your services, so
that you're moving them into and

159
00:08:34.240 --> 00:08:38.130
out of each of these different
portions of the portfolio, right?

160
00:08:38.130 --> 00:08:40.482
That's what service
portfolio management is, and

161
00:08:40.482 --> 00:08:44.100
again why I encourage you to consider
the process as your primary motivation for

162
00:08:44.100 --> 00:08:48.280
learning now and not how are you going
to design this data model that keeps up

163
00:08:48.280 --> 00:08:50.520
with the pipeline,
catalog, retired services?

164
00:08:50.520 --> 00:08:53.095
That's really kind of
a nonstarter academically.

165
00:08:53.095 --> 00:08:57.020
And it's even a nonstarter operationally,
you gotta get the process right first

166
00:08:57.020 --> 00:09:00.372
before you can understand what your
data sets gonna look like, okay?

167
00:09:00.372 --> 00:09:04.650
All right, so why do this?

168
00:09:04.650 --> 00:09:07.740
Why have portfolio management, right?

169
00:09:07.740 --> 00:09:08.740
Is there operating question?

170
00:09:08.740 --> 00:09:12.030
What value does it add to the business?

171
00:09:12.030 --> 00:09:16.220
Well if it's purpose is to make sure
you're offering the right services,

172
00:09:16.220 --> 00:09:18.790
that one of the values it adds
is offering the right services.

173
00:09:18.790 --> 00:09:23.960
>> Sure, I mean, if we were sitting
here explaining study material for

174
00:09:23.960 --> 00:09:25.760
an exam that didn't even exist anymore.

175
00:09:25.760 --> 00:09:27.813
Maybe if it had got revamped and
there was a new series,

176
00:09:27.813 --> 00:09:29.565
then it probably would be pointless,
right?

177
00:09:29.565 --> 00:09:32.671
>> Exactly right, are we delivering
the right things at the right time for

178
00:09:32.671 --> 00:09:36.417
the right customers is what's portfolio
management's trying to get done, right?

179
00:09:36.417 --> 00:09:39.932
So if you're doing that well then
the output is you're delivering

180
00:09:39.932 --> 00:09:42.860
the right services at the right time,
right?

181
00:09:42.860 --> 00:09:45.150
It gives you a basis for
cost and risk control, right?

182
00:09:46.180 --> 00:09:49.062
It allows you to more effectively
understand the cost and

183
00:09:49.062 --> 00:09:52.786
risk of your existing services or
potential services, or even the cost of

184
00:09:52.786 --> 00:09:56.528
existing services that are no longer
providing the right value, right?

185
00:09:56.528 --> 00:10:01.216
To pay for an expensive service
that has very little value,

186
00:10:01.216 --> 00:10:06.089
it could be an item on the chopping block,
or for redesign, or

187
00:10:06.089 --> 00:10:08.274
a drastic change, right?

188
00:10:08.274 --> 00:10:13.800
All right, so,
interesting here the term industrialized.

189
00:10:13.800 --> 00:10:17.790
Frequently organizations rush to
industrialize service outcomes

190
00:10:17.790 --> 00:10:19.220
without having a strategy in place.

191
00:10:19.220 --> 00:10:20.645
>> Yeah,
I'm gonna need some explanation there too.

192
00:10:20.645 --> 00:10:21.685
>> Yeah, interesting term.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Terry continue to address how the process of Service Portfolio Management contributes to SOA practices. The lifecycle stage emphasized in this show is service strategy. A complete overview of the purpose, objectives, scope and importance of SPM as a process to generate business value is explored and demonstrated using examples. SPM policies, principles, concepts, activities, methods and techniques are explained in relation to SOA practices.

here's the project manager,

The inputs to Service Portfolio Management

We've also talked about these interfaces,

It's fairly intuitive when

this and tweaking that to

And things you might need, okay?

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Terry address how the process of Service Catalog Management contributes to SOA practices. The lifecycle stage emphasized in this show is service strategy. A complete overview of the purpose, objectives, scope and importance of SCM as a process to generate business value is explored and demonstrated using examples. SCM policies, principles, concepts, activities, methods and techniques are explained in relation to SOA practices.

episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.005 --> 00:00:06.457
Welcome to ITPRO.TV and
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.457 --> 00:00:08.000
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.000 --> 00:00:12.165
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.165 --> 00:00:15.243
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to
your ITIL Service Offerings and

5
00:00:15.243 --> 00:00:16.690
Agreements series.

6
00:00:16.690 --> 00:00:18.600
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.600 --> 00:00:19.452
In this episode,

8
00:00:19.452 --> 00:00:24.560
we will be looking at defining our
service catalog management processes.

9
00:00:24.560 --> 00:00:27.290
And with us today back in studios,
we have Mr. Terry Decker.

10
00:00:27.290 --> 00:00:28.780
Thank you for joining us Terry.

11
00:00:28.780 --> 00:00:29.700
>> As always Cherokee,

12
00:00:29.700 --> 00:00:32.570
happy to be here and
plenty to discuss here on service catalog.

13
00:00:32.570 --> 00:00:36.900
The good news is,
the catalog is part of the portfolio, so

14
00:00:36.900 --> 00:00:39.630
we've kinda done some of
the heavy lifting already, right?

15
00:00:39.630 --> 00:00:44.300
>> Now Terry, I know we had three episodes
looking at our portfolio management but

16
00:00:44.300 --> 00:00:48.040
when we're talking about our catalog
management, how do those two relate?

17
00:00:48.040 --> 00:00:49.060
>> Yeah, good question.

18
00:00:49.060 --> 00:00:52.710
The catalog is certainly part of
the portfolio and you may recall from

19
00:00:52.710 --> 00:00:56.770
previous episodes that I encouraged you
to think about the processes more so

20
00:00:56.770 --> 00:00:59.820
than the data set, the data model.

21
00:00:59.820 --> 00:01:02.420
That's certainly true as it relates
to service portfolio management and

22
00:01:02.420 --> 00:01:05.750
service catalog management and
the differentiation they have.

23
00:01:05.750 --> 00:01:10.570
Service portfolio management as a process
is focused on the strategic decision.

24
00:01:10.570 --> 00:01:12.580
What services should we have?

25
00:01:12.580 --> 00:01:13.880
Are we offering them?

26
00:01:13.880 --> 00:01:15.820
And if we have services that
are not providing value,

27
00:01:15.820 --> 00:01:17.220
is it time time to get rid of them?

28
00:01:17.220 --> 00:01:20.270
So that's when we talk about the pipeline,
the catalog,

29
00:01:20.270 --> 00:01:25.570
the portion of the portfolio that has
the services that we've agreed to offer,

30
00:01:25.570 --> 00:01:27.880
right, and then of course,
retired services.

31
00:01:27.880 --> 00:01:29.120
Now as a process,

32
00:01:29.120 --> 00:01:35.630
service catalog management is maintaining
the details of that one portion.

33
00:01:35.630 --> 00:01:39.610
So if you think of it process-wise,
they have different focuses.

34
00:01:39.610 --> 00:01:43.740
Strategic decisions are made
through service portfolio.

35
00:01:43.740 --> 00:01:46.210
Tactical decisions of
updating the catalog,

36
00:01:46.210 --> 00:01:50.340
keeping it current, making sure that
the right views are available to the right

37
00:01:50.340 --> 00:01:54.430
audiences is what the service
catalog management process is about.

38
00:01:54.430 --> 00:01:57.730
So, I think it's easy to distinguish the
difference between portfolio management

39
00:01:57.730 --> 00:02:00.750
and catalog management when
you consider the processes.

40
00:02:00.750 --> 00:02:04.186
Where it's get kinda confusing is
when you consider that they're

41
00:02:04.186 --> 00:02:06.588
using a data-set that's uncommon, right?

42
00:02:06.588 --> 00:02:09.140
The catalog is part of the portfolio.

43
00:02:09.140 --> 00:02:11.179
So again, to distinguish these,

44
00:02:11.179 --> 00:02:15.331
the process of Service Portfolio
Management is a strategic process,

45
00:02:15.331 --> 00:02:19.926
trying to discern what services should
we offer for what business outcomes.

46
00:02:19.926 --> 00:02:24.773
And if they're not providing any value,
to get rid of them, the pipeline,

47
00:02:24.773 --> 00:02:27.215
the catalog, and retired services.

48
00:02:27.215 --> 00:02:31.142
Catalog management is focused just on
that one part of the portfolio and

49
00:02:31.142 --> 00:02:34.023
it's more of a tactical
nature in making sure that it

50
00:02:34.023 --> 00:02:36.574
has the right information
at the right time and

51
00:02:36.574 --> 00:02:41.108
that that information is exposed to the
right customers in the right way, right.

52
00:02:41.108 --> 00:02:43.640
So a lot different on the process side.

53
00:02:43.640 --> 00:02:46.300
All right, so again,
we kind of know the heavy lifting.

54
00:02:46.300 --> 00:02:47.600
What is the catalog, right?

55
00:02:47.600 --> 00:02:50.680
If you look at the slide here,

56
00:02:50.680 --> 00:02:55.190
you'll see that the catalog covers all
services that are already in transition.

57
00:02:55.190 --> 00:02:59.810
They've already gone through and have been
brought into live environment, right, or

58
00:02:59.810 --> 00:03:02.180
they've been approved for the same, right?

59
00:03:02.180 --> 00:03:03.730
So again, if you think about portfolio,

60
00:03:03.730 --> 00:03:07.900
portfolio is making decision about
a service and a pipeline saying,

61
00:03:07.900 --> 00:03:11.640
yeah, we want this service to happen,
we've approved it, we've chartered it.

62
00:03:11.640 --> 00:03:13.560
Well, portfolio's done its business.

63
00:03:13.560 --> 00:03:15.130
It's now supposed to move to the catalog.

64
00:03:15.130 --> 00:03:18.430
Well, that's when service catalog
management takes over, right, and

65
00:03:18.430 --> 00:03:21.780
they'll make sure that the appropriate
details are put in there and

66
00:03:21.780 --> 00:03:25.560
that those details are exposed to
the right people at the right time.

67
00:03:25.560 --> 00:03:30.180
So that's why it says here it's services
that are already live and those that

68
00:03:30.180 --> 00:03:35.460
have been approved to become live, is
what service management scope is, right?

69
00:03:35.460 --> 00:03:40.820
So the purpose is to make sure
the details of all services are stored

70
00:03:40.820 --> 00:03:44.750
appropriately and
made view-able to the right people, right?

71
00:03:44.750 --> 00:03:45.638
Simple as that.

72
00:03:45.638 --> 00:03:47.786
As its listed here, to provide and

73
00:03:47.786 --> 00:03:52.976
maintain a single source of consistent
information on all operational services,

74
00:03:52.976 --> 00:03:56.235
and those that have been
prepared to be run, right,

75
00:03:56.235 --> 00:04:00.850
as well as ensuring it is widely
available to those authorized to view it.

76
00:04:00.850 --> 00:04:07.860
Now if you consider, remember we talked
about core services and enabling services?

77
00:04:07.860 --> 00:04:11.510
In other words, a core service as an
example, we have email as a core service.

78
00:04:11.510 --> 00:04:16.290
Everyone gets to use it, but underneath
the code, you have these enabling or

79
00:04:16.290 --> 00:04:20.270
supporting services like servers and
databases and network.

80
00:04:20.270 --> 00:04:24.756
Well underneath the hood, customers aren't
necessarily concerned about all of those

81
00:04:24.756 --> 00:04:26.780
services in the background.

82
00:04:26.780 --> 00:04:29.403
They're concerned about email,
how do I get email?

83
00:04:29.403 --> 00:04:34.036
And the catalog, you need to expose those
details to those types of viewers, right.

84
00:04:34.036 --> 00:04:39.550
But an IT practitioner might need to see
what services are underneath the hood.

85
00:04:39.550 --> 00:04:43.260
So this catalog needs to expose those
kind of services to an IT audience.

86
00:04:43.260 --> 00:04:47.833
So you kind of see that service
catalog management is really

87
00:04:47.833 --> 00:04:52.497
a tactical exercise making sure
the right information about

88
00:04:52.497 --> 00:04:57.540
services is exposed to the right
people in the right ways, okay?

89
00:04:57.540 --> 00:05:02.409
So the scope, again, all of the services
that have already been defined, right.

90
00:05:02.409 --> 00:05:07.351
And those services that are about to
be brought into our operations, right,

91
00:05:07.351 --> 00:05:10.620
all those service package
descriptions meaning,

92
00:05:10.620 --> 00:05:14.118
like if you subscribe to email
as one of your services,

93
00:05:14.118 --> 00:05:19.080
do you also get instant messaging
as part of the package or not?

94
00:05:19.080 --> 00:05:22.400
The service catalog would describe
those additional services.

95
00:05:22.400 --> 00:05:26.580
You might consider that
like a cable TV provider.

96
00:05:26.580 --> 00:05:29.180
The different packages you can get from
them, you get level one, level two.

97
00:05:29.180 --> 00:05:29.980
>> Like our triple play.

98
00:05:29.980 --> 00:05:30.620
We've got our voice.

99
00:05:30.620 --> 00:05:32.180
What is it our data?

100
00:05:32.180 --> 00:05:33.080
>> Yeah good point.

101
00:05:33.080 --> 00:05:33.980
>> What's the other?

102
00:05:33.980 --> 00:05:35.390
Cable, yeah.
>> Cable, that's right.

103
00:05:35.390 --> 00:05:35.950
>> TV.

104
00:05:35.950 --> 00:05:37.410
Yeah, how they package.

105
00:05:37.410 --> 00:05:41.048
You get internet, cable and
phone, and then under the cable,

106
00:05:41.048 --> 00:05:45.340
TV subscriptions,
do you get premium channels or not.

107
00:05:45.340 --> 00:05:49.820
Do you get HD or not, DVR included or
not, those types of things.

108
00:05:49.820 --> 00:05:54.170
So the catalog is going to
expose those offerings,

109
00:05:54.170 --> 00:05:58.310
those packages in meaningful ways
to customers as well, right.

110
00:05:58.310 --> 00:06:04.540
So again, the scope is how does a customer
get access to these services, who do they

111
00:06:04.540 --> 00:06:09.090
contact if they have issues, what are the
operating hours, those types of things.

112
00:06:09.090 --> 00:06:11.645
That's the information
stored in the catalog and

113
00:06:11.645 --> 00:06:16.430
as a service catalog management process is
playing out, it's making sure the right

114
00:06:16.430 --> 00:06:20.490
data is presented to the right
customers in meaningful ways.

115
00:06:20.490 --> 00:06:24.940
All right, it is a single source.

116
00:06:24.940 --> 00:06:28.940
The business knows where to go to look for
what services are being offered.

117
00:06:31.860 --> 00:06:34.540
It does need to have
a customer facing view.

118
00:06:34.540 --> 00:06:39.045
Another reason why it gets special
attention as its own process is that this

119
00:06:39.045 --> 00:06:44.320
is exposed to a company if you will,
it's exposed to guests, customers, right?

120
00:06:44.320 --> 00:06:45.630
Whereas the pipeline and

121
00:06:45.630 --> 00:06:49.540
retired services, those two portions
of the portfolio are probably for

122
00:06:49.540 --> 00:06:54.105
IT use only, right, they're not
necessarily exposed to customers.

123
00:06:54.105 --> 00:06:57.025
But the catalogue is intended
to be exposed to customers,

124
00:06:57.025 --> 00:06:58.485
as well as some other groups.

125
00:06:58.485 --> 00:07:02.661
>> In my mind Terry, I'm thinking,
perfect example here at ITPRO TV,

126
00:07:02.661 --> 00:07:06.921
we could go ahead and classify our
course library as our catalog here.

127
00:07:06.921 --> 00:07:10.517
So for instance, any kind of order
videos like those other phases that you

128
00:07:10.517 --> 00:07:13.185
are talking about,
we could go ahead and retire them or

129
00:07:13.185 --> 00:07:16.375
even if they were unlike beta phase,
during that analyse phase,

130
00:07:16.375 --> 00:07:20.940
different components like that, but here
we're talking about the outward phasing.

131
00:07:20.940 --> 00:07:24.870
You guys are logging on to IT PRO.TV,
you couldn't see the different layout,

132
00:07:24.870 --> 00:07:27.380
the different descriptions and
then go ahead and view those videos.

133
00:07:27.380 --> 00:07:28.920
>> That's very good.

134
00:07:28.920 --> 00:07:31.310
And I think another way to create example,

135
00:07:32.410 --> 00:07:36.810
another example related to IT PRO.TV is
part of your service obviously is this,

136
00:07:36.810 --> 00:07:40.820
the content being delivered to
desktops through streaming video.

137
00:07:40.820 --> 00:07:44.490
But you also offer services that allow for
file downloads.

138
00:07:44.490 --> 00:07:48.660
You also add services that are available
for forums and discussion groups.

139
00:07:48.660 --> 00:07:51.854
So that's also part of
your packaging as well.

140
00:07:51.854 --> 00:07:54.088
That was a good example of the content,
but

141
00:07:54.088 --> 00:07:57.140
part of your service model is
not just streaming content.

142
00:07:57.140 --> 00:07:58.579
You have other things wrapped around it.

143
00:07:58.579 --> 00:08:01.369
This chat Your Facebook interface.

144
00:08:01.369 --> 00:08:04.597
This is also part of your service that
you're developing and making available,

145
00:08:04.597 --> 00:08:07.160
I should say developing,
making it available to folks.

146
00:08:07.160 --> 00:08:11.390
So, as folks use your service,
they should have the ability to understand

147
00:08:11.390 --> 00:08:13.730
these other service offerings,
other parts.

Do you trust the service owner?

00:26:15.710 --> 00:26:18.920
However that is, you need to make
sure you have a representation

472
00:26:18.920 --> 00:26:21.310
of the business needs, right?

473
00:26:21.310 --> 00:26:23.780
And you're avoiding this
head office mentality.

474
00:26:23.780 --> 00:26:29.960
What that means is, you're not dictating
to the customer what success looks like.

475
00:26:29.960 --> 00:26:32.470
You flip that script and
you say, customer,

476
00:26:32.470 --> 00:26:35.070
what does successful looks like to you,
right?

477
00:26:35.070 --> 00:26:38.760
Instead the head office says,
here's what you're going to get.

478
00:26:38.760 --> 00:26:41.410
We're gonna give you availability,
instant resolution time.

479
00:26:41.410 --> 00:26:42.760
That's what we're doing, right?

480
00:26:43.920 --> 00:26:46.700
Chances are you're gonna back yourself
into a corner if the customers don't

481
00:26:46.700 --> 00:26:47.460
really care about that.

482
00:26:47.460 --> 00:26:50.800
If they care about others indicators, you
need to be looking at those indicators.

483
00:26:53.450 --> 00:26:56.430
Of course the risk will also include
you don't have the right tool sets.

484
00:26:56.430 --> 00:26:58.620
You don't have the right governance.

485
00:26:58.620 --> 00:27:02.810
You don't have enough authority to
say we're going to implement this

486
00:27:02.810 --> 00:27:05.360
improvement or agreed to this target.

487
00:27:05.360 --> 00:27:07.332
>> Is that the head office mentality?

488
00:27:07.332 --> 00:27:08.113
>> Yeah.

489
00:27:08.113 --> 00:27:10.429
>> I am not sure,
I haven't heard that term before.

490
00:27:10.429 --> 00:27:12.687
>> Head office just means top-down.

491
00:27:12.687 --> 00:27:15.880
IT telling the customers what they need or
what they want.

492
00:27:15.880 --> 00:27:18.071
We've decided here's what you get.

493
00:27:18.071 --> 00:27:19.440
>> Okay.
>> That's really what it means.

494
00:27:19.440 --> 00:27:21.982
It is more of a British term
than it is an American term.

495
00:27:21.982 --> 00:27:23.400
>> Okay.
>> Pretty that what it is.

496
00:27:25.120 --> 00:27:27.880
Basically, it means you're
not just dictating.

497
00:27:27.880 --> 00:27:29.920
You're not telling the users or customers,

498
00:27:29.920 --> 00:27:32.470
here's what you should have
as performance indicators.

499
00:27:32.470 --> 00:27:36.020
You're asking the customers
what they need, right?

500
00:27:36.020 --> 00:27:38.710
What does this look like to you customer?

501
00:27:38.710 --> 00:27:40.590
Now, you can lead them to the water,
they should drink.

502
00:27:40.590 --> 00:27:43.020
I mean availability is
an important metric.

503
00:27:43.020 --> 00:27:45.810
Response time at the service
desk is an important metric.

504
00:27:45.810 --> 00:27:47.140
And whatever that metric might be,

505
00:27:47.140 --> 00:27:50.880
you have to have the ability
to actually capture that data.

506
00:27:50.880 --> 00:27:53.970
So there's gonna be some
constraints on what's possible.

507
00:27:53.970 --> 00:27:54.940
>> Sure.
[LAUGH]

508
00:27:54.940 --> 00:27:55.530
>> Right?

509
00:27:55.530 --> 00:27:58.587
>> Yeah.
>> But the constraints shouldn't be driven

510
00:27:58.587 --> 00:27:59.191
by you.

511
00:27:59.191 --> 00:28:02.491
It should be more driven by the customer,
right?

512
00:28:02.491 --> 00:28:07.121
That's really what that's getting to,
all right.

513
00:28:07.121 --> 00:28:11.574
By bypassing,
by not having service management in place,

514
00:28:11.574 --> 00:28:13.800
that's one of the risks.

515
00:28:13.800 --> 00:28:14.720
You just avoid.

516
00:28:16.130 --> 00:28:19.100
There's a direct customer
interaction with IT and

517
00:28:19.100 --> 00:28:21.950
you don't consider measurement,
then everything becomes opinion.

518
00:28:21.950 --> 00:28:23.480
Everything becomes a crisis.

519
00:28:23.480 --> 00:28:28.288
If a high ranking business user says it's
slow, you start putting out that fire

520
00:28:28.288 --> 00:28:31.876
when really if you actually measured it,
you'd find out,

521
00:28:31.876 --> 00:28:36.950
the reason why it was slow is because he
was using his phone from a Starbucks.

522
00:28:36.950 --> 00:28:40.110
It had nothing to do with
the normal performance of ours.

523
00:28:40.110 --> 00:28:43.090
Let's consider the mobility piece of it,
right?

524
00:28:43.090 --> 00:28:46.480
And if we follow the SLM process,
we could have dug that out a little bit

525
00:28:46.480 --> 00:28:50.130
more deeply instead of
responding to a complaint.

526
00:28:50.130 --> 00:28:51.450
>> And sometimes we even see that.

527
00:28:51.450 --> 00:28:56.570
For example, with an Internet Service
Provider, maybe they've capped or

528
00:28:56.570 --> 00:28:59.470
throttled a particular bandwidth and
someone may be calling

529
00:28:59.470 --> 00:29:03.010
to let them know hey, it's slow,
but it may be intentional at times.

530
00:29:03.010 --> 00:29:04.370
>> Exactly, right.

531
00:29:05.560 --> 00:29:06.640
So that's the kind of things you get.

532
00:29:06.640 --> 00:29:10.690
As we talked about in other processes,
coming up with a process owner for

533
00:29:10.690 --> 00:29:14.120
service level management and coming up
with a process manager for service level

534
00:29:14.120 --> 00:29:18.850
management are kinda foundational
fundamental steps you take, right?

535
00:29:18.850 --> 00:29:23.080
So if you want to implement
service level management formally,

536
00:29:23.080 --> 00:29:26.560
your first steps are to name a service
level management process owner.

537
00:29:27.640 --> 00:29:29.260
Gives someone accountability for and

538
00:29:29.260 --> 00:29:34.060
empower them to define and
move these processes to maturity.

539
00:29:34.060 --> 00:29:35.870
>> So
by empowerment you also mean authority,

540
00:29:35.870 --> 00:29:39.430
in a way that they can actually enforce
what it is they're set out to do?

541
00:29:39.430 --> 00:29:42.760
>> Exactly, that service level management
process owner is probably one of

542
00:29:42.760 --> 00:29:45.560
the first things they're gonna do,
is saying, what authority do I have?

543
00:29:45.560 --> 00:29:46.890
Can I have a policy that backs it up?

544
00:29:46.890 --> 00:29:49.084
Remember, the governance fabric that
we talked about a little bit earlier.

545
00:29:49.084 --> 00:29:50.030
>> Sure.

546
00:29:50.030 --> 00:29:53.656
>> So certainly first steps early on in
the definition of process is the name

547
00:29:53.656 --> 00:29:55.340
an owner, accountable.

548
00:29:55.340 --> 00:29:57.460
And of course you need someone
to manage on a day to day basis,

549
00:29:57.460 --> 00:30:02.455
so having a process manager is also key,
right?

550
00:30:02.455 --> 00:30:05.395
And that's it for
service level management.

551
00:30:05.395 --> 00:30:07.035
As with the other topics,

552
00:30:07.035 --> 00:30:10.175
there are opportunities to
learn in Directed Self Study.

553
00:30:10.175 --> 00:30:13.215
We have two, one called a SLM 1,
another called a SLM 2.

554
00:30:13.215 --> 00:30:18.045
You see the time frames for those,
some pretty lengthy task there.

555
00:30:18.045 --> 00:30:20.015
These are available for download.

556
00:30:20.015 --> 00:30:22.585
Please, I encourage you
to check these out for

557
00:30:22.585 --> 00:30:24.920
reinforcing this learning on
service level management.

558
00:30:24.920 --> 00:30:28.590
They're available up in the upper
right here under Shell files.

559
00:30:28.590 --> 00:30:29.610
>> All right, Terry.

560
00:30:29.610 --> 00:30:31.190
Thank you so much for joining us today.

561
00:30:31.190 --> 00:30:33.810
And thank you ladies and
gentlemen for being with us as well.

562
00:30:33.810 --> 00:30:35.470
For this show,
we will go ahead and sign out.

563
00:30:35.470 --> 00:30:37.310
Remember, I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

564
00:30:37.310 --> 00:30:38.130
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

565
00:30:38.130 --> 00:30:41.471
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

566
00:30:41.471 --> 00:30:47.322
[MUSIC]

567
00:30:47.322 --> 00:30:50.471
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Terry discuss Demand Management and explain how it should be conducted to contribute to quality assurance for introducing services that are fit-for-purpose and fit-for-use.
episodes.title: Demand Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.600
Welcome ITPro.TV, I'm host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.600 --> 00:00:06.452
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.452 --> 00:00:08.426
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.426 --> 00:00:12.167
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:12.167 --> 00:00:15.847
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to your
Service Offerings and Agreement Series.

6
00:00:15.847 --> 00:00:17.863
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.863 --> 00:00:21.214
And these episodes will be taken
a look at demand management.

8
00:00:21.214 --> 00:00:25.480
And with us today we have Mr. Terry Decker
in house, thank you for joining us Terry.

9
00:00:25.480 --> 00:00:26.547
>> Happy to be here.

10
00:00:26.547 --> 00:00:30.034
We'll continue our exploration of
the processes associated with service

11
00:00:30.034 --> 00:00:31.580
offerings and agreements.

12
00:00:31.580 --> 00:00:33.413
We've gone through portfolio managements,

13
00:00:33.413 --> 00:00:35.672
service catalog management
service level management.

14
00:00:35.672 --> 00:00:39.135
And now we'll have a look
at demand management.

15
00:00:39.135 --> 00:00:41.925
The objectives of demand
management are pretty clear.

16
00:00:41.925 --> 00:00:43.345
As the word demand suggests,

17
00:00:43.345 --> 00:00:47.475
you're trying to understand what
the demand of a service is going to be.

18
00:00:47.475 --> 00:00:50.637
So you're trying to be
predictive of potential demand.

19
00:00:50.637 --> 00:00:55.715
And you're also trying to respond after
a service is live to the actual demand.

20
00:00:55.715 --> 00:00:58.955
And that could clue you in to
perhaps you need more capacity or

21
00:01:00.550 --> 00:01:03.970
more capability to serve more customers,
etc.

22
00:01:03.970 --> 00:01:06.730
So demand management is
born in service strategy,

23
00:01:06.730 --> 00:01:09.310
trying to be predictive
of what demand might be.

24
00:01:09.310 --> 00:01:13.410
But it's alive and well in operations
as well to make sure that demand

25
00:01:13.410 --> 00:01:15.700
is being sufficiently met, okay?

26
00:01:15.700 --> 00:01:20.450
So as you might guess, it has a tight
correlation with capacity planning.

27
00:01:20.450 --> 00:01:24.870
Understanding demand is going to be
a feeder into capacity management.

28
00:01:24.870 --> 00:01:29.563
So the objectives of demand
management are to understand not just

29
00:01:29.563 --> 00:01:32.733
the demand from a holistic view, big view.

30
00:01:32.733 --> 00:01:36.276
3,000 users or 5,000 users or
whatever it might be.

31
00:01:36.276 --> 00:01:40.496
It's also to understand their
patterns of business activity.

32
00:01:40.496 --> 00:01:45.251
Patterns of business activity
relates to when things are used.

33
00:01:45.251 --> 00:01:50.561
For instance, Amazon.com might get
very busy between November and

34
00:01:50.561 --> 00:01:54.200
December dealing with Christmas holidays.

35
00:01:54.200 --> 00:01:56.644
Depending on what service
you're providing,

36
00:01:56.644 --> 00:02:00.620
maybe there's patterns you can try to
anticipate or try to discern, right?

37
00:02:00.620 --> 00:02:03.583
Month end reporting, financial reporting.

38
00:02:03.583 --> 00:02:05.053
>> Just even on a daily level.

39
00:02:05.053 --> 00:02:09.412
I mean if we think about users getting to
work, logging in, checking their email,

40
00:02:09.412 --> 00:02:13.103
and having that lull around noon,
lunchtime, whatever that may be?

41
00:02:13.103 --> 00:02:17.392
>> Right, and
equating it here to ITPro.TV.

42
00:02:17.392 --> 00:02:20.978
The demand when all five studios
are going with heavy lab involvement and

43
00:02:20.978 --> 00:02:21.989
that sort of thing.

44
00:02:21.989 --> 00:02:25.260
Maybe certainly have to anticipate
all five being up at one time.

45
00:02:25.260 --> 00:02:26.400
What's that look like?

46
00:02:26.400 --> 00:02:30.520
What's your ISP gonna be doing to
help you with that flexible demand.

47
00:02:30.520 --> 00:02:33.660
Give you kind of a crazy example
of patterns of business activity.

48
00:02:33.660 --> 00:02:37.580
I worked with the Commonwealth
of Virginia, and

49
00:02:37.580 --> 00:02:43.043
they had a centralized IT function
that served elections, right?

50
00:02:43.043 --> 00:02:45.778
So if you could imagine
elections as registrations.

51
00:02:45.778 --> 00:02:49.303
Getting voter registrations load and
stuff, but in elect Tuesday of

52
00:02:49.303 --> 00:02:53.390
November every couple of years has
a particular pattern of business activity.

53
00:02:53.390 --> 00:02:57.354
Where lots of people coming and
using these electronic election systems.

54
00:02:57.354 --> 00:02:58.180
>> Exactly.

55
00:02:58.180 --> 00:02:59.680
>> So again patterns vision.

56
00:02:59.680 --> 00:03:02.390
When are things happening not
just numbers of users but

57
00:03:02.390 --> 00:03:06.298
when and how are they utilizing it, right?

58
00:03:06.298 --> 00:03:10.320
Another tell tale example from my learning
management experience back in the day.

59
00:03:10.320 --> 00:03:14.240
We discovered that, I'll describe
a weakness in demand management.

60
00:03:14.240 --> 00:03:17.664
Basically where we weren't quite fully
functional in understanding these patterns

61
00:03:17.664 --> 00:03:19.190
of business activity.

62
00:03:19.190 --> 00:03:24.010
The service was already live and as we
launched service, everything was fine.

63
00:03:24.010 --> 00:03:30.130
We understood the numbers of users
we have when Malaysia comes online.

64
00:03:30.130 --> 00:03:31.570
What's that look like for our network?

65
00:03:31.570 --> 00:03:34.750
What happens when by the time it gets
to Poland and the United Kingdom,

66
00:03:34.750 --> 00:03:37.240
what's it look like in terms
of network utilization?

67
00:03:37.240 --> 00:03:40.460
We kinda have a sense for that,
we did predictive measures etc.

68
00:03:40.460 --> 00:03:43.423
And we had sense for
how to plan capacity for

69
00:03:43.423 --> 00:03:48.207
geography through our demand management,
but we found surprises.

70
00:03:48.207 --> 00:03:51.535
Again, we know now that it was
a demand management issue, but

71
00:03:51.535 --> 00:03:55.300
we were troubleshooting
an issue every other Friday.

72
00:03:55.300 --> 00:03:58.270
Every other Friday,
our performance just kept is falling over.

73
00:03:58.270 --> 00:03:59.100
We weren't sure why.

74
00:04:00.120 --> 00:04:03.408
We couldn't figure out,
and so we did a few steps,

75
00:04:03.408 --> 00:04:08.245
a few alliterations of analysis and
eventually we found what was going on.

76
00:04:08.245 --> 00:04:11.218
>> It was pay day and
everyone was taking the afternoon off.

77
00:04:11.218 --> 00:04:11.767
>> No.

78
00:04:11.767 --> 00:04:14.291
>> [LAUGH]
>> For our learning management system,

79
00:04:14.291 --> 00:04:16.110
what was happening is every other Friday,

80
00:04:16.110 --> 00:04:18.760
the sales team would
come in from the field.

81
00:04:18.760 --> 00:04:19.980
And when they cam in from the field,

82
00:04:19.980 --> 00:04:22.000
they were heavy users of
learning management system.

83
00:04:22.000 --> 00:04:24.820
They were either updating their training
records because they've been out on

84
00:04:24.820 --> 00:04:26.370
the training junket.

85
00:04:26.370 --> 00:04:30.251
Or they had to take training before they
went back out to the field because that

86
00:04:30.251 --> 00:04:32.650
was also a very dynamic
training environment.

87
00:04:32.650 --> 00:04:38.030
So the sales folks were regularly engaged,
but every two weeks.

88
00:04:38.030 --> 00:04:41.880
That corresponded to the weekly
reporting that a manufacturing

89
00:04:41.880 --> 00:04:43.440
training managers were doing.

90
00:04:43.440 --> 00:04:45.830
They were doing audit readiness reports.

91
00:04:45.830 --> 00:04:49.158
Which meant, they had to analyze
everyone's training through reports

92
00:04:49.158 --> 00:04:51.184
against our learning management service.

93
00:04:51.184 --> 00:04:53.985
They were doing these reports,
very intensive reports.

94
00:04:53.985 --> 00:04:56.250
And they were doing it all over the globe,
right?

95
00:04:56.250 --> 00:05:00.826
Some 300 practitioner using heavy
queries against our system,

96
00:05:00.826 --> 00:05:05.157
every Friday, add that to every to weeks,
every other Friday,

97
00:05:05.157 --> 00:05:08.148
the sales team coming and
a hitting it hard.

98
00:05:08.148 --> 00:05:11.339
Now again, we know the answer know but
we went moths must after month,

99
00:05:11.339 --> 00:05:14.250
after month trying to feel
what going on on this Fridays?

100
00:05:14.250 --> 00:05:17.353
In fact, it took's us months to realize
its was every other friday, right?

101
00:05:17.353 --> 00:05:21.290
It wasn't obvious that that's when it
was happening, then it dawned on us.

102
00:05:21.290 --> 00:05:24.410
So if we had an effective
demand management

103
00:05:24.410 --> 00:05:28.240
process that methodically ask questions
that could discern from the business,

104
00:05:28.240 --> 00:05:30.440
what are your patterns
of business activity?

105
00:05:30.440 --> 00:05:35.150
We might have anticipated that particular
heavy hitting day, every other Friday, and

106
00:05:35.150 --> 00:05:37.860
perhaps change behaviors, right?

107
00:05:37.860 --> 00:05:42.227
Let's have the manufacturing team do
the reporting on Monday instead of Friday,

108
00:05:42.227 --> 00:05:44.896
that would fix it,
that's what we did actually.

109
00:05:44.896 --> 00:05:45.840
Or we could have built

110
00:05:45.840 --> 00:05:47.564
the appropriate capacity-
>> Sure.

111
00:05:47.564 --> 00:05:49.683
>> To handle that
>> And that's why we see cloud computing.

112
00:05:49.683 --> 00:05:53.722
I know we've mentioned it several times
Terry, throughout this series, but

113
00:05:53.722 --> 00:05:55.610
it's such a great example of that.

114
00:05:55.610 --> 00:05:57.449
Because you can use
elastic provisioning on

115
00:05:57.449 --> 00:05:58.085
an-
>> It's true.

116
00:05:58.085 --> 00:05:59.797
>> As needed basis.

117
00:05:59.797 --> 00:06:02.099
>> And of course it all comes
down to cost-benefit analysis.

118
00:06:02.099 --> 00:06:04.169
How good are you at
predicting your demand?

119
00:06:04.169 --> 00:06:05.107
And certainly, by the way,

120
00:06:05.107 --> 00:06:07.990
that's what the Commonwealth of Virginia
did with their election things.

121
00:06:07.990 --> 00:06:10.660
They had that elastic provisioning,
they didn't need to buy and

122
00:06:10.660 --> 00:06:12.190
maintain the infrastructure.

123
00:06:12.190 --> 00:06:15.110
Just for election days, right?

124
00:06:15.110 --> 00:06:17.650
They could expand as they needed to.

125
00:06:17.650 --> 00:06:20.007
So this idea of patterns
of business activity and

126
00:06:20.007 --> 00:06:23.232
understanding user profiles is
what demand management is about.

127
00:06:23.232 --> 00:06:26.774
And by user profile is who is using it,
what and how heavily, right?

128
00:06:26.774 --> 00:06:29.949
Who's using what and how heavily are they
using it and when are they using it?

129
00:06:31.450 --> 00:06:36.000
So understanding the demand through
patterns of business activity and

130
00:06:36.000 --> 00:06:41.250
through user profiling, gives you a basis
for planning appropriate capacity, okay?

131
00:06:41.250 --> 00:06:45.280
That's what demand management is about,
intended to be predictive, right?

132
00:06:45.280 --> 00:06:49.430
Demand management is also about
ascertaining, is there gonna be demand for

133
00:06:49.430 --> 00:06:53.100
this service,
is it worth offering this service, right?

134
00:06:53.100 --> 00:06:56.729
We kinda miss the demand management
piece a couple of times on our business

135
00:06:56.729 --> 00:06:58.613
intelligence solution at one point.

136
00:06:58.613 --> 00:07:03.876
Again, just as an example where
we anticipated 3,000 users,

137
00:07:03.876 --> 00:07:05.456
we end up with 12.

138
00:07:05.456 --> 00:07:09.811
Something was broken at analysis, we
