00:00:30.024 --> 00:00:31.649
>> As always, happy to be here.

14
00:00:31.649 --> 00:00:35.120
And supplier management is
a good important topic.

15
00:00:35.120 --> 00:00:39.020
And worthy of the good discussion here,
in that it's gonna make sure that our

16
00:00:39.020 --> 00:00:41.542
suppliers are able to perform as needed,
right?

17
00:00:41.542 --> 00:00:44.122
And on time, on budget, etc.

18
00:00:44.122 --> 00:00:47.525
So as we look at the graphics here,
at the PowerPoints here,

19
00:00:47.525 --> 00:00:52.150
we're moving past this identification
of requirements and selection.

20
00:00:52.150 --> 00:00:55.380
And now we're actually going to establish,
what's necessary

21
00:00:55.380 --> 00:00:58.850
when actually getting these new suppliers
and contracts in the house, right?

22
00:00:58.850 --> 00:01:01.290
We know who we want to be there,
and we're bringing them in,

23
00:01:01.290 --> 00:01:03.030
and they're gonna start
providing services for us.

24
00:01:03.030 --> 00:01:04.130
So we've already gone through that.

25
00:01:05.370 --> 00:01:08.165
The establishment of new suppliers should
probably be handled through change

26
00:01:08.165 --> 00:01:09.640
management.

27
00:01:09.640 --> 00:01:16.810
Change management is sometimes understated
I think, in service management traditions.

28
00:01:16.810 --> 00:01:19.118
Change management is often
seen as what you do,

29
00:01:19.118 --> 00:01:21.608
when you have to do a technical
change to a service.

30
00:01:21.608 --> 00:01:26.275
Just to remind you, ITIL looks at
change management a lot more broadly,

31
00:01:26.275 --> 00:01:30.943
to cover any kind of thing, any kind
of activity that's a new activity,

32
00:01:30.943 --> 00:01:34.000
that can impact the delivery of services.

33
00:01:34.000 --> 00:01:36.070
So I think it is pretty
straightforward then,

34
00:01:36.070 --> 00:01:41.010
that you could consider the adoption of a
new supplier, or establish a new supplier,

35
00:01:41.010 --> 00:01:46.600
as significant enough to manage through
an ongoing change management process.

36
00:01:46.600 --> 00:01:49.160
Which effectively is going to
manage the risk for you, right?

37
00:01:49.160 --> 00:01:51.860
Change management and
risk management go hand-in-hand.

38
00:01:51.860 --> 00:01:55.520
So understanding your operational
risk of a new supplier coming in.

39
00:01:55.520 --> 00:02:01.770
And quantifying that risk, identifying it
and analysing is gonna be pretty critical.

40
00:02:01.770 --> 00:02:05.450
And understanding the business impact
analysis of this particular contract, or

41
00:02:05.450 --> 00:02:07.590
this particular supplier is big too.

42
00:02:07.590 --> 00:02:11.150
Just where do they fit in
the overall scheme of things?

43
00:02:11.150 --> 00:02:12.600
Now, these next few bullets.

44
00:02:12.600 --> 00:02:13.420
The blame game.

45
00:02:13.420 --> 00:02:15.430
Relationship threats.

46
00:02:15.430 --> 00:02:17.360
Relationship ownership and reviews.

47
00:02:17.360 --> 00:02:19.110
Thresholds and break points.

48
00:02:19.110 --> 00:02:24.190
This is really about,
one part good contracts.

49
00:02:24.190 --> 00:02:26.930
Establishing good fences and
good neighbors, right?

50
00:02:26.930 --> 00:02:27.650
That's one part of it.

51
00:02:27.650 --> 00:02:31.750
But it's also just about the human
element of supplier management.

52
00:02:31.750 --> 00:02:34.540
Is it possible to overwork a supplier?

53
00:02:34.540 --> 00:02:37.350
Make them mad, they don't wanna
be your supplier any more, right?

54
00:02:37.350 --> 00:02:39.860
Is it possible to overly blame them,
right?

55
00:02:39.860 --> 00:02:41.000
Let them be the scapegoat.

56
00:02:41.000 --> 00:02:41.878
>> Definitely.

57
00:02:41.878 --> 00:02:45.280
>> [LAUGH] Right?
So this is a two-part piece.

58
00:02:45.280 --> 00:02:48.740
I mean, you have to be a supplier manager,
honest and open with your suppliers.

59
00:02:48.740 --> 00:02:50.300
They need to be honest and open with you.

60
00:02:50.300 --> 00:02:53.830
So coming up with these good
relationships is important, right?

61
00:02:53.830 --> 00:02:56.735
And blame game is not really part of that,
right?

62
00:02:56.735 --> 00:03:01.552
Getting in a culture of blame is
more about covering your basis,

63
00:03:01.552 --> 00:03:05.455
and not stepping up to plate for
improvement.

64
00:03:05.455 --> 00:03:07.290
Whichever side of the fence you're on,

65
00:03:07.290 --> 00:03:10.200
blaming is not gonna be
a good course of action.

66
00:03:10.200 --> 00:03:12.694
In fact,
blaming is part of relationship threats.

67
00:03:12.694 --> 00:03:16.620
If the supplier is willing to throw you
under the bus as a supplier manager, and

68
00:03:16.620 --> 00:03:19.370
vice versa,
then you're going down the wrong path.

69
00:03:19.370 --> 00:03:23.990
It's a slippery slope,
it leads to bad outcomes.

70
00:03:23.990 --> 00:03:25.480
>> Nobody likes that person.

71
00:03:25.480 --> 00:03:27.410
We probably all know that one person-
>> [LAUGH]

72
00:03:27.410 --> 00:03:29.550
>> And they just can't take accountability

73
00:03:29.550 --> 00:03:34.480
for anything, whether it had been
in your past or current endeavors.

74
00:03:34.480 --> 00:03:35.048
Nobody likes them.

75
00:03:35.048 --> 00:03:35.652
>> No, exactly.

76
00:03:35.652 --> 00:03:37.605
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I mean it cost so

77
00:03:37.605 --> 00:03:41.290
much in relationships and
trust, it also cost time, right?

78
00:03:41.290 --> 00:03:44.290
If you're not willing to step up and
say my bad, sorry about that.

79
00:03:44.290 --> 00:03:46.800
And then move on to improvement, right?

80
00:03:46.800 --> 00:03:48.790
Is what it should be.

81
00:03:48.790 --> 00:03:52.880
So just as you deal with human
relationships inside your organization,

82
00:03:52.880 --> 00:03:54.970
blame game is not a great place to go.

83
00:03:54.970 --> 00:03:56.580
It also applies to your suppliers.

84
00:03:56.580 --> 00:03:58.655
And again trying to teach in
some esoteric things here.

85
00:03:58.655 --> 00:04:02.145
But what you're gonna see,
as this may play out on the exam,

86
00:04:02.145 --> 00:04:06.190
is you might see a scenario that
talks about finger pointing, right?

87
00:04:06.190 --> 00:04:12.762
You need to correct that, through
an appropriate measurement-based approach.

88
00:04:12.762 --> 00:04:15.153
So if you do need to remediate.

89
00:04:15.153 --> 00:04:20.010
If you do need to make corrective
action of a supplier, do so

90
00:04:20.010 --> 00:04:24.010
in good faith with good movement
toward achievable targets.

91
00:04:24.010 --> 00:04:26.310
Just as you would if they
were your best friend.

92
00:04:26.310 --> 00:04:27.550
Say how are we gonna do this?

93
00:04:27.550 --> 00:04:29.208
I forgive you, but, right?

94
00:04:29.208 --> 00:04:31.615
And then follow through
with some good things.

95
00:04:31.615 --> 00:04:35.990
So understanding when you've crossed
those thresholds of acceptability,

96
00:04:35.990 --> 00:04:38.260
of acceptable behavior,
of acceptable performance.

97
00:04:38.260 --> 00:04:41.170
Understand whether those
threshold have been breached.

98
00:04:41.170 --> 00:04:43.580
And understanding when,
you know what we can't do this anymore.

99
00:04:43.580 --> 00:04:45.180
What are the break points?

100
00:04:45.180 --> 00:04:48.730
Understanding those as well, okay.

101
00:04:48.730 --> 00:04:50.536
I've certainly had
the fire suppliers before.

102
00:04:50.536 --> 00:04:53.340
It's not easy, one from a human level,

103
00:04:53.340 --> 00:04:55.810
it's also not necessarily
easy contractually.

104
00:04:55.810 --> 00:04:58.773
So having understood thresholds and
break points,

105
00:04:58.773 --> 00:05:01.677
is really what part of
the aspect is there, right.

106
00:05:01.677 --> 00:05:04.270
So what about performance then?

107
00:05:04.270 --> 00:05:05.900
That's gonna be where
the rubber meets the road.

108
00:05:05.900 --> 00:05:07.060
How are they performing, right?

109
00:05:08.250 --> 00:05:12.440
How do they do with, just what they're
supposed to do, operationally speaking?

110
00:05:12.440 --> 00:05:15.670
Is it clear how we interface
with those organizations,

111
00:05:15.670 --> 00:05:17.400
those external organizations?

112
00:05:17.400 --> 00:05:21.304
And if that is clear, then you focus
on the actual operations of incidents,

113
00:05:21.304 --> 00:05:24.486
problems, change and
configuration as necessary, right?

114
00:05:24.486 --> 00:05:27.810
How do you go about
reviewing your suppliers?

115
00:05:27.810 --> 00:05:29.860
How formal is that, right?

116
00:05:29.860 --> 00:05:32.060
And how often does it happen?

117
00:05:32.060 --> 00:05:36.513
And again, building in improvement
without additional cost, should

118
00:05:36.513 --> 00:05:41.700
be a trick you try to pull out of your
hat, as you define the contract, right?

119
00:05:41.700 --> 00:05:46.320
So they should improve ongoing,
without additional cost.

120
00:05:46.320 --> 00:05:50.280
It's a great way to consider
your contract scope, right?

121
00:05:50.280 --> 00:05:52.743
As you consider the financial benefits.

122
00:05:52.743 --> 00:05:54.840
There gonna be considering
the financial benefits.

123
00:05:54.840 --> 00:05:56.830
Do they get more pay,
if they perform higher?

124
00:05:56.830 --> 00:05:59.540
Sure, you could build that
into your contracts as well.

125
00:05:59.540 --> 00:06:02.540
And of course,
the converse is true as well.

126
00:06:02.540 --> 00:06:05.030
If they're not performing,
do they get penalized?

127
00:06:05.030 --> 00:06:06.145
That also could be built in.

128
00:06:06.145 --> 00:06:10.663
So good fences, good neighbors,
good understanding, transparency and

129
00:06:10.663 --> 00:06:13.541
also trust,
needs to be built in here, right?

130
00:06:13.541 --> 00:06:19.600
As you consider renewal time or
end of term.

131
00:06:19.600 --> 00:06:22.390
Appreciate what's put
here in the red texture.

132
00:06:22.390 --> 00:06:25.350
Natural tendency is to want
to avoid making changes,

133
00:06:25.350 --> 00:06:27.600
and wait until it needs fixed, right?

134
00:06:27.600 --> 00:06:31.660
Actually you should build in the end
game within the contract itself.

135
00:06:31.660 --> 00:06:33.890
In other words, understand the end,

136
00:06:33.890 --> 00:06:38.060
what the end looks like,
before you gonna gauge at the contract.

137
00:06:38.060 --> 00:06:39.690
How do we get out of this?

138
00:06:39.690 --> 00:06:42.573
There could be a time limit for sure,
but what about these performance things?

139
00:06:42.573 --> 00:06:45.475
Is there 30-day notice period?

140
00:06:45.475 --> 00:06:49.300
You have to give them 30 days notice,
before you end the contract, etc.

141
00:06:49.300 --> 00:06:50.390
Those types of things.

142
00:06:50.390 --> 00:06:54.250
And what is the criteria for
ending, before the end of the term?

143
00:06:54.250 --> 00:06:56.490
>> Sure Terry.
I could see if there was any kind of

144
00:06:56.490 --> 00:07:00.120
premature termination there, there might
even be a little bit of high tension.

145
00:07:00.120 --> 00:07:04.400
So that's not really the time to be
negotiating any kind of exit strategy.

146
00:07:04.400 --> 00:07:06.630
>> Very good, very good point, agreed.

147
00:07:06.630 --> 00:07:12.750
And again, do it when the relationship
is young, fresh and optimistic.

148
00:07:12.750 --> 00:07:15.236
And then you don't have to worry,
through those emotions later on.

149
00:07:15.236 --> 00:07:17.780
Good point, very good.

150
00:07:17.780 --> 00:07:21.590
So again, the time to think about
the end of relationship is at the start.

151
00:07:21.590 --> 00:07:24.948
All right, and it's a good dating advice-
>> Yeah,

152
00:07:24.948 --> 00:07:25.837
I was gonna say-
>> [LAUGH]

153
00:07:25.837 --> 00:07:27.346
>> Don't use this in your personal life.

154
00:07:27.346 --> 00:07:29.541
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't see it going over too well.

155
00:07:29.541 --> 00:07:30.679
>> That's right.
[LAUGH]

156
00:07:30.679 --> 00:07:31.480
>> [LAUGH]

157
00:07:31.480 --> 00:07:32.176
>> [LAUGH] Right.

158
00:07:32.176 --> 00:07:33.546
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's pretty funny.

159
00:07:33.546 --> 00:07:35.200
But yeah, you get the idea there.

160
00:07:35.200 --> 00:07:37.260
Definitely some levity and necessary.

161
00:07:37.260 --> 00:07:40.650
But it is, as it relates to your
contracts, your contractual relationships,

162
00:07:40.650 --> 00:07:41.850
so your legal relationships,

163
00:07:41.850 --> 00:07:47.260
it's best to think about how it
ends as you begin, for sure there.

164
00:07:47.260 --> 00:07:52.360
So understand what's the criteria for
premature termination.

165
00:07:52.360 --> 00:07:56.100
What is the criteria for
rewards, punishment, etc.

166
00:07:56.100 --> 00:07:59.730
Okay, so straightforward there,
pretty much straight.

167
00:07:59.730 --> 00:08:02.750
Again, information management system,
we talked about the supplier contract,

168
00:08:02.750 --> 00:08:04.050
management information system.

169
00:08:04.050 --> 00:08:08.310
This does not have to be big,
robust, complicated.

170
00:08:08.310 --> 00:08:12.730
Certainly to get started, it can just
simply be a list of all your suppliers and

171
00:08:12.730 --> 00:08:14.450
what they do for you, right?

172
00:08:14.450 --> 00:08:15.540
And how much they cost?

173
00:08:15.540 --> 00:08:17.030
What's their price point?

174
00:08:17.030 --> 00:08:19.260
Are they a preferred vendor or not, etc.

175
00:08:21.120 --> 00:08:25.668
Again you can start off simple,
it can also end up being pretty robust.

176
00:08:25.668 --> 00:08:29.970
It could you have triggers built into it,
to remind you as a supplier manager,

177
00:08:29.970 --> 00:08:31.950
when the contract is coming up for review.

178
00:08:31.950 --> 00:08:36.800
It could have performance data built
into it, linked to dashboards.

179
00:08:36.800 --> 00:08:40.420
There's all kinds of ways to
make this very, very robust.

180
00:08:40.420 --> 00:08:42.570
But a simple one,
is a great place to start.

181
00:08:42.570 --> 00:08:45.490
Just to get your head
around your suppliers.

182
00:08:45.490 --> 00:08:48.110
And to get your head around
what category they are.

183
00:08:48.110 --> 00:08:48.910
Are they strategic?

184
00:08:48.910 --> 00:08:49.980
Are they commodity?

185
00:08:49.980 --> 00:08:51.550
What risk do they provide, etc.

186
00:08:52.850 --> 00:08:59.420
All right, supplier management built
on KPIs and critical success factors.

187
00:08:59.420 --> 00:09:01.170
Are you protecting the business,

188
00:09:01.170 --> 00:09:06.430
to make sure you're not going to leave the
business hanging, if the supplier fails.

189
00:09:06.430 --> 00:09:08.220
Just an anecdotal story.

190
00:09:08.220 --> 00:09:14.050
It happens to be from an exam agency,
that supports the ITIL certifications.

191
00:09:14.050 --> 00:09:16.638
They happen to go down
on a Friday afternoon.

192
00:09:16.638 --> 00:09:21.160
And that's a prominent test time, right?

193
00:09:21.160 --> 00:09:24.830
As an exam administrator,
I was not informed of the down time,

194
00:09:24.830 --> 00:09:26.160
I just noticed it wasn't available.

195
00:09:26.160 --> 00:09:27.544
I wasn't sure when it's gonna come back.

196
00:09:27.544 --> 00:09:29.483
>> Was this planned maintenance or
it was just-

197
00:09:29.483 --> 00:09:31.679
>> It was unplanned.

198
00:09:31.679 --> 00:09:32.412
It was unplanned.

199
00:09:32.412 --> 00:09:33.920
And I know, stuff happens.

200
00:09:33.920 --> 00:09:35.250
I'm not mad at them.

201
00:09:35.250 --> 00:09:36.330
Because things happen.

202
00:09:36.330 --> 00:09:39.060
But I was in the dark,
all through the weekend.

203
00:09:39.060 --> 00:09:41.800
And I got exam takers asking me, right?

204
00:09:41.800 --> 00:09:45.230
I have customers asking me,
so when can I take the exam?

205
00:09:45.230 --> 00:09:47.220
I was all ready to take it,
and I can't take it.

206
00:09:47.220 --> 00:09:48.460
What am I gonna be doing?

207
00:09:48.460 --> 00:09:49.690
Please advise.

208
00:09:49.690 --> 00:09:52.360
And all I could say is,
I'm sorry, I don't know, right?

209
00:09:53.780 --> 00:09:55.600
The lesson learned turned out to be,

210
00:09:55.600 --> 00:09:57.810
is that there was just
a lack of communication.

211
00:09:57.810 --> 00:09:59.330
They did have an outage.

212
00:09:59.330 --> 00:10:01.650
They simple had an outage.

213
00:10:01.650 --> 00:10:06.700
Probably they could have been better
at communicating that, right?

214
00:10:06.700 --> 00:10:09.430
So they affected my
business to some extent.

215
00:10:09.430 --> 00:10:12.000
They certainly affected
the reputation a little bit.

216
00:10:12.000 --> 00:10:15.700
I blame them, they blame their supplier,
blame, blame, blame.

217
00:10:15.700 --> 00:10:17.350
That's not solving the problems.

218
00:10:17.350 --> 00:10:22.340
So as you consider your supplier landscape
and the numbers of suppliers you have,

219
00:10:22.340 --> 00:10:24.865
think about what would happen
if a supplier under-performs?

220
00:10:25.970 --> 00:10:29.790
You as a service provider,
are on-point for providing the service.

221
00:10:29.790 --> 00:10:33.210
You can't go to your customer and
just throw the supplier under the bus.

222
00:10:33.210 --> 00:10:35.380
That really is unacceptable
to the customer.

223
00:10:35.380 --> 00:10:37.370
You are the one providing the service.

224
00:10:37.370 --> 00:10:38.810
You're relying on suppliers.

225
00:10:38.810 --> 00:10:41.440
So what is the protection of the business?

226
00:10:41.440 --> 00:10:42.998
What measures you put in place,

227
00:10:42.998 --> 00:10:45.835
to make sure the business
continuity is in place, right?

228
00:10:45.835 --> 00:10:48.380
Of course, you need to be aligned.

229
00:10:48.380 --> 00:10:49.660
Making sure that you have alignment,

230
00:10:49.660 --> 00:10:54.190
that will align with the appropriate
targets, measurable targets.

231
00:10:54.190 --> 00:10:57.830
And then do we have breaches of service?

232
00:10:57.830 --> 00:10:59.150
What do those look like?

233
00:10:59.150 --> 00:11:00.210
Do they regularly fail?

234
00:11:00.210 --> 00:11:01.913
Is it it only every now and then?

235
00:11:01.913 --> 00:11:05.080
Etc.
And of course ownership and awareness.

236
00:11:05.080 --> 00:11:06.240
Who owns this contract?

237
00:11:06.240 --> 00:11:08.240
Who owns the supplier, all right?

238
00:11:08.240 --> 00:11:11.430
Who's accountable for
when they perform well?

239
00:11:11.430 --> 00:11:13.560
Who's accountable for
when they perform poorly?

240
00:11:13.560 --> 00:11:14.610
Etc.

241
00:11:14.610 --> 00:11:19.050
So making sure your supplier
management process covers these bases.

242
00:11:19.050 --> 00:11:20.580
You got the business covered.

243
00:11:20.580 --> 00:11:22.490
You got the measurable targets covered.

244
00:11:22.490 --> 00:11:24.940
You understand how breeches are managed.

245
00:11:24.940 --> 00:11:28.650
And you understand who's on point for
addressing performance issues,

246
00:11:28.650 --> 00:11:30.120
whether good or bad, okay?

247
00:11:32.105 --> 00:11:35.510
And remember a challenge is a risk
that has a 100% chance of happening.

248
00:11:35.510 --> 00:11:36.910
You see the house of cards here.

249
00:11:37.920 --> 00:11:41.770
Understanding that you need to change.

250
00:11:41.770 --> 00:11:45.340
You have the supplier contract today,
it's been serving you well.

251
00:11:45.340 --> 00:11:48.190
But the business is moving, right?

252
00:11:48.190 --> 00:11:52.680
Again using that example of learning
management conversion of Power points,

253
00:11:52.680 --> 00:11:54.330
to e-learning.

254
00:11:54.330 --> 00:11:55.550
The demand was huge.

255
00:11:55.550 --> 00:12:01.540
We had a huge contract with a third-party
supplier to manage that conversion for us.

256
00:12:01.540 --> 00:12:05.580
And they were expecting honestly,
to have lots of demand, right?

257
00:12:05.580 --> 00:12:07.270
And they did for a year.

258
00:12:07.270 --> 00:12:08.980
They did for a year and a half.

259
00:12:08.980 --> 00:12:13.330
They were expecting high volume, so
the margins of profit were lower.

260
00:12:13.330 --> 00:12:16.587
Well when we started to feeding
them one at a time, piece work,

261
00:12:16.587 --> 00:12:19.210
it wasn't really viable for them anymore.

262
00:12:19.210 --> 00:12:21.760
So they stopped paying attention to us,
right.

263
00:12:21.760 --> 00:12:27.530
To get $50 for this one thing this week,
became a non-starter for them.

264
00:12:27.530 --> 00:12:31.050
When they were bringing in $5,000,
a week they liked it, right?

265
00:12:31.050 --> 00:12:33.842
So the suppliers attitude changed,
because our volume changed.

266
00:12:33.842 --> 00:12:35.570
It would have been a great relationship.

267
00:12:35.570 --> 00:12:40.510
So continuity of supplier relationship's
gonna be pretty important,

268
00:12:40.510 --> 00:12:41.556
as you consider these things.

269
00:12:41.556 --> 00:12:44.805
I mean, they were still on the hook to
deliver, they just didn't care as much.

270
00:12:44.805 --> 00:12:46.915
And if they lost the contract,
they didn't care as much.

271
00:12:46.915 --> 00:12:49.335
Because the volume wasn't there, right?

272
00:12:49.335 --> 00:12:52.135
So again, different ways and
different dynamics in play.

273
00:12:52.135 --> 00:12:54.325
But it's a moving target, right?

274
00:12:54.325 --> 00:12:57.395
It's not static in many cases, right?

275
00:12:58.425 --> 00:13:03.165
So understanding the challenges of
continuity, legalities, the personality,

276
00:13:03.165 --> 00:13:06.530
the trust issues,
is all a big part of this, right?

277
00:13:06.530 --> 00:13:10.360
So the way to minimize
the effect of these challenges.

278
00:13:10.360 --> 00:13:11.890
A very good contract.

279
00:13:11.890 --> 00:13:13.665
Clear roles and responsibilities.

280
00:13:13.665 --> 00:13:17.610
Well-supporting processes,
they have good processes,

281
00:13:17.610 --> 00:13:21.278
you have good processes and
they interact well, right?

282
00:13:21.278 --> 00:13:25.750
And then perhaps,
have some selection criteria in place that

283
00:13:25.750 --> 00:13:28.290
helps you get the wheat from the chaff,
a bit more effectively.

284
00:13:28.290 --> 00:13:29.640
Are they certified?

285
00:13:29.640 --> 00:13:31.495
Do they follow these
particular guidelines?

286
00:13:31.495 --> 00:13:36.740
And you see some standards,
ISO 9000 or ISO 20000.

287
00:13:36.740 --> 00:13:42.050
Sure you could look at ISO standards as
one method of improvement, your selection.

288
00:13:42.050 --> 00:13:44.060
You could look at any numbers of criteria.

289
00:13:44.060 --> 00:13:48.443
If you say, we're gonna select
suppliers that can do x or can do y,

290
00:13:48.443 --> 00:13:50.573
and have a track record, okay?

291
00:13:50.573 --> 00:13:55.920
All right, the risks,
you don't have good policy to back you up.

292
00:13:55.920 --> 00:13:57.380
You don't have management behind you.

293
00:13:58.430 --> 00:14:01.116
And policy is a great way to
show that backing, right?

294
00:14:01.116 --> 00:14:03.195
You have poorly-written contracts.

295
00:14:03.195 --> 00:14:05.830
You have too many suppliers, right?

296
00:14:05.830 --> 00:14:10.400
You have a mismatch in culture,
where that supplier is kind of rogue,

297
00:14:10.400 --> 00:14:11.580
does things on the fly.

298
00:14:11.580 --> 00:14:16.060
You're very structured,
and very predictable.

299
00:14:16.060 --> 00:14:19.230
They prefer more cowboy organization,
or vice versa.

300
00:14:19.230 --> 00:14:22.730
You're a cowboy kind of organization,
expects real responsiveness and

301
00:14:22.730 --> 00:14:25.310
they're slow and methodical,
expecting great quality, right?

302
00:14:25.310 --> 00:14:29.050
Mismatch in culture could play
out on that as well, right?

303
00:14:29.050 --> 00:14:30.940
You don't have good processes inside.

304
00:14:30.940 --> 00:14:35.980
Your corporate financial
processes pay them late, right.

305
00:14:35.980 --> 00:14:37.580
Or pay them the wrong amount.

306
00:14:37.580 --> 00:14:39.440
Because you don't have
your ducks in a row.

307
00:14:39.440 --> 00:14:42.440
I've been on the bad side of
that kind of relationship

308
00:14:42.440 --> 00:14:46.060
a couple times in managing suppliers,
where I'm demanding more performance and

309
00:14:46.060 --> 00:14:47.514
they say, well how about paying us?

310
00:14:47.514 --> 00:14:49.030
Right, [LAUGH] that sort of thing.

311
00:14:49.030 --> 00:14:51.229
Not a great place to be, right?

312
00:14:51.229 --> 00:14:54.673
So you are trying to manage these
risks in supplier management,

313
00:14:54.673 --> 00:14:56.320
you're gonna face these things.

314
00:14:56.320 --> 00:14:57.733
Hopefully they're easily mitigated.

315
00:14:57.733 --> 00:15:05.100
Hopefully they don't manifest
themselves in daily pain, all right?

316
00:15:05.100 --> 00:15:08.730
As we've talked about before,
each process, you'd have an owner.

317
00:15:08.730 --> 00:15:10.450
Supplier management is no different.

318
00:15:10.450 --> 00:15:13.840
One of the first steps, in determining
what your supplier management

319
00:15:13.840 --> 00:15:17.560
process is gonna be,
is defining a process owner.

320
00:15:17.560 --> 00:15:20.870
And of course, having a day-to-day
management of the process,

321
00:15:20.870 --> 00:15:23.469
is gonna be done and
executed through a role called,

322
00:15:23.469 --> 00:15:26.260
the supplier management process manager,
all right?

323
00:15:26.260 --> 00:15:29.337
Pretty straightforward, all right.

324
00:15:29.337 --> 00:15:34.620
So that's supplier management,
a good dose of information there.

325
00:15:34.620 --> 00:15:36.945
There is some self studies,
some good exercises for you.

326
00:15:36.945 --> 00:15:40.230
It's a brief one there, it takes about 20
minutes, related to supplier management.

327
00:15:40.230 --> 00:15:43.420
Again it's available for download,
up here in the upper right hand corner,

328
00:15:43.420 --> 00:15:44.796
it's called show files.

329
00:15:44.796 --> 00:15:46.674
Please dig in to that self study, and

330
00:15:46.674 --> 00:15:49.712
reach out into the form if you
have any questions or issues.

331
00:15:49.712 --> 00:15:51.410
>> Thank you, Terry for joining us.

332
00:15:51.410 --> 00:15:53.334
And thank you ladies and
gentlemen for being here as well.

333
00:15:53.334 --> 00:15:56.596
But stay tuned, we're not quite
finished here with our ITIL shows.

334
00:15:56.596 --> 00:15:58.210
We're gonna go ahead and sign off.

335
00:15:58.210 --> 00:16:00.125
Remember, I'm your host, Cherokee Boose.

336
00:16:00.125 --> 00:16:00.881
>> And I'm Terry Decker.

337
00:16:00.881 --> 00:16:02.657
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

338
00:16:02.657 --> 00:16:10.006
[MUSIC]

339
00:16:10.006 --> 00:16:12.932
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Terry discuss how Financial Management for IT services for provides the business and IT with the quantification, in financial terms, of the value of IT Services, the value of the assets underlying the provisioning of those services, and the qualification of operational forecasting.
episodes.title: Financial Management for IT Services
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.040
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet..

2
00:00:01.040 --> 00:00:06.781
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.781 --> 00:00:08.438
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.438 --> 00:00:12.078
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.078 --> 00:00:13.850
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to
your ITIL Service Offerings and

6
00:00:13.850 --> 00:00:18.390
Agreement series
>> I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.390 --> 00:00:22.600
In this episode we'll be taking a look at
Financial Management for our IT Services.

8
00:00:22.600 --> 00:00:25.371
And with us today back in studios,
we have Mr. Terry Decker.

9
00:00:25.371 --> 00:00:27.260
Thank you for joining us today Terry.

10
00:00:27.260 --> 00:00:28.350
>> Happy to be here.

11
00:00:28.350 --> 00:00:30.270
And some good news about
this particular topic.

12
00:00:30.270 --> 00:00:32.760
We don't scratch the surface much deeper

13
00:00:32.760 --> 00:00:35.210
than we've scratch in
the foundation course.

14
00:00:35.210 --> 00:00:39.640
Financial Management for IT Services
is a necessary evil, obviously.

15
00:00:39.640 --> 00:00:43.630
>> You gotta manage the money, but
ITIL does not position itself as a best

16
00:00:43.630 --> 00:00:48.450
practice for financial management, so
they don't go that deeply into this topic.

17
00:00:48.450 --> 00:00:52.250
So we're going to scratch the surface a
little deeper, but not so much deeper and

18
00:00:52.250 --> 00:00:56.830
I think you'll find that it's fairly easy
to pick up on some basic principles of

19
00:00:56.830 --> 00:01:00.040
financial management as relates to
the provisioning of IT services.

20
00:01:00.040 --> 00:01:03.450
It's a course relevant to this
thing called service offerings and

21
00:01:03.450 --> 00:01:07.360
agreements because what you're trying to
do when you are offering services is offer

22
00:01:07.360 --> 00:01:09.160
them at the right price.

23
00:01:09.160 --> 00:01:13.790
So financial management is helping you
on that cost provisioning piece, and

24
00:01:13.790 --> 00:01:19.290
it allows you to compare to cost of the
service to the value they're describing.

25
00:01:19.290 --> 00:01:20.910
So let's have a look here
at some of the slides.

26
00:01:20.910 --> 00:01:24.450
First of all, Financial Management
is a couple of different things.

27
00:01:24.450 --> 00:01:28.060
It's the enterprise financial
management piece at the high level.

28
00:01:28.060 --> 00:01:32.850
And it's also at the lower level on
how it applies to particular services.

29
00:01:32.850 --> 00:01:37.250
So it operates at the macro
level as well as the micro level

30
00:01:37.250 --> 00:01:41.344
as it relates to IT services
>> All right, so we'll have a look at this

31
00:01:41.344 --> 00:01:45.093
as we go through, but
it kind of sets the stage for these.

32
00:01:45.093 --> 00:01:49.788
Effectively, what financial management
services is trying to do is to make sure

33
00:01:49.788 --> 00:01:52.557
the appropriate level
of funding is obtained.

34
00:01:52.557 --> 00:01:57.790
And to make sure that the services that
are being delivered are rightly funded.

35
00:01:57.790 --> 00:02:00.930
And by rightly,
that means we don't want to overspend, and

36
00:02:00.930 --> 00:02:03.140
of course we don't want
to under spend either.

37
00:02:03.140 --> 00:02:07.400
So a big part of this is going to be
relying on the value proposition,

38
00:02:07.400 --> 00:02:11.160
not just the cost proposition of
bringing those two things together.

39
00:02:11.160 --> 00:02:15.099
Financial management obviously enabling
the cost side of that discussion.

40
00:02:16.860 --> 00:02:20.380
And of course you don't want to
under-commit on the resources and

41
00:02:20.380 --> 00:02:23.290
funds, you don't want to over-commit
on the resources of funds.

42
00:02:23.290 --> 00:02:26.440
So getting that right balance is really
what financial management is about.

43
00:02:26.440 --> 00:02:29.320
>> I've seen some little cartoon clips and

44
00:02:29.320 --> 00:02:32.800
jokes about those kind of financial
discrepancies where you go to your

45
00:02:32.800 --> 00:02:37.590
project manager or the PMO office,
whoever that sponsor was.

46
00:02:37.590 --> 00:02:41.290
Whoever you're submitting this
information to and you say hey,

47
00:02:41.290 --> 00:02:44.000
look I finished on time, under budget, and

48
00:02:44.000 --> 00:02:47.650
they're just looking at you and
thinking okay well something's wrong here.

49
00:02:47.650 --> 00:02:51.150
Okay, did you sacrifice the quality or
I've given you too much time,

50
00:02:51.150 --> 00:02:52.824
I've given you too much budget.

51
00:02:52.824 --> 00:02:56.659
It's kind of a joke but it really does
makes sense because using some of

52
00:02:56.659 --> 00:02:59.977
that background knowledge in
your experience to foresee and

53
00:02:59.977 --> 00:03:02.080
kind of plan out is pretty important.

54
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:03.120
>> Totally agree.

55
00:03:03.120 --> 00:03:06.470
And as you mentioned projects I think
another thing from my own basis of

56
00:03:06.470 --> 00:03:09.670
experience and again financial management
is trying to fix this kind of dysfunction.

57
00:03:10.810 --> 00:03:15.870
Is I've seen were projects were
potentially appropriately funded right.

58
00:03:15.870 --> 00:03:19.660
They got the fundings for
that fixed set of time and deliverables.

59
00:03:19.660 --> 00:03:22.530
I've seen that done at
a very mature level and yet

60
00:03:22.530 --> 00:03:25.420
see it fall over once the service
is actually operating.

61
00:03:25.420 --> 00:03:30.030
There wasn't enough money to buy
the new licences or to pass out the new

62
00:03:30.030 --> 00:03:33.310
headsets or those kinds of things,
to deliver the solution on time and

63
00:03:33.310 --> 00:03:37.320
on budget but they weren't quite ready for
prime time operationally.

64
00:03:37.320 --> 00:03:39.200
How do we get these licences renewed?

65
00:03:39.200 --> 00:03:40.710
What, there's an upgrade
we have to pay for?

66
00:03:40.710 --> 00:03:42.568
>> Good point.
>> Right, so we got project scope,

67
00:03:42.568 --> 00:03:46.370
which is definitely important and
certainly part of financial management.

68
00:03:46.370 --> 00:03:48.670
But also,
when you heard about service delivery,

69
00:03:48.670 --> 00:03:52.810
you're talking about on going
operational funds as well.

70
00:03:52.810 --> 00:03:53.820
So I've often seen,

71
00:03:53.820 --> 00:03:58.460
again, my own experience where the project
was done very well on time, on budget.

72
00:03:58.460 --> 00:04:01.490
But them we were found lacking of
funds when it came to some critical

73
00:04:01.490 --> 00:04:04.220
investment for
ongoing maintenance and support.

74
00:04:04.220 --> 00:04:06.400
So getting that right also key too.

75
00:04:07.470 --> 00:04:11.144
So, Financial Management for
IT services needs to be there for

76
00:04:11.144 --> 00:04:12.780
all this type of scope.

77
00:04:12.780 --> 00:04:17.650
Project scope, operational scope, design,
transitions and all of the above.

78
00:04:19.360 --> 00:04:24.109
So effectively what Financial Management
for IT services trying to do as with

79
00:04:24.109 --> 00:04:28.637
these other processes is to come up with
a methodical way to do this well and

80
00:04:28.637 --> 00:04:30.420
predictably, right?

81
00:04:30.420 --> 00:04:34.979
So as relates to financial management
you wanna be to create a framework so

82
00:04:34.979 --> 00:04:38.516
that you can track and
communicate the cost of a service.

83
00:04:38.516 --> 00:04:41.840
Even that sounds kinda easy,
as a bullet statement, but

84
00:04:41.840 --> 00:04:47.150
it's not that easy to actually figure out,
I mean what is the cost of an incident?

85
00:04:47.150 --> 00:04:52.090
If one service has a thousand incidents
a week, and another service has four,

86
00:04:52.090 --> 00:04:55.760
which one of those services costs more
as it related to incidents, right?

87
00:04:55.760 --> 00:04:58.720
So, again it can be a complex
question to answer.

88
00:04:58.720 --> 00:05:02.700
But finance management as a process
is trying to make these answers

89
00:05:02.700 --> 00:05:07.900
more readily available, more readily and
predictably available, right?

90
00:05:07.900 --> 00:05:11.700
So you can inform decision making, right?

91
00:05:11.700 --> 00:05:15.690
You're providing the right level of
funding, not the wrong level of funding.

92
00:05:15.690 --> 00:05:18.860
The counterbalance to,
are we sure we have enough money?

93
00:05:18.860 --> 00:05:21.990
Well let's just throw some more money
at it is not a good answer, right?

94
00:05:21.990 --> 00:05:24.080
And probably not very acceptable for
your CFO.

95
00:05:25.450 --> 00:05:29.040
Of course after you've decided to spend or
invest,

96
00:05:29.040 --> 00:05:32.340
it's accounting for
the actual money being spent.

97
00:05:32.340 --> 00:05:35.490
Making sure people are paid,
making sure value is created.

98
00:05:35.490 --> 00:05:38.210
Making sure that the service
is actually working and

99
00:05:38.210 --> 00:05:40.590
delivering as appropriate, right?

100
00:05:40.590 --> 00:05:44.980
So coming up with this framework through
the financial management process

101
00:05:44.980 --> 00:05:45.690
Is the objective.

102
00:05:47.690 --> 00:05:50.040
You may remember these
from the foundation.

103
00:05:50.040 --> 00:05:52.560
Again, not scratching
the surface any deeper.

104
00:05:52.560 --> 00:05:55.390
Account I call the ABCs,
a little bit different order here, but

105
00:05:55.390 --> 00:05:57.520
the ABCs of financial management.

106
00:05:57.520 --> 00:06:01.151
Accounting, budgeting, and charging.

107
00:06:03.152 --> 00:06:06.491
Cherokee, what's the difference
between accounting and budgeting?

108
00:06:06.491 --> 00:06:09.667
>> [LAUGH] Okay.

109
00:06:09.667 --> 00:06:11.276
>> First of all,
do you balance your checkbook?

110
00:06:11.276 --> 00:06:11.992
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

111
00:06:11.992 --> 00:06:13.546
>> So I'm gonna go ahead and

112
00:06:13.546 --> 00:06:16.950
kind of have a cop out here and
from the IT perspective,

113
00:06:16.950 --> 00:06:21.280
accounting is essentially logging,
kind of like auditing.

114
00:06:21.280 --> 00:06:25.040
So budgeting would be in
my mind pre-planning,

115
00:06:25.040 --> 00:06:30.250
whereas accounting would be looking at
that historical data after the fact.

116
00:06:30.250 --> 00:06:30.860
>> Perfect.

117
00:06:30.860 --> 00:06:33.100
>> Okay!
>> Budgeting is predictive,

118
00:06:33.100 --> 00:06:34.520
what you expect to spend.

119
00:06:34.520 --> 00:06:37.000
Accounting is actuals, what did we spend?

120
00:06:37.000 --> 00:06:39.499
So financial management needs to
enable both of these activities.

121
00:06:41.060 --> 00:06:45.070
Enable effective budgeting, and
enable effective accounting.

122
00:06:45.070 --> 00:06:48.037
Now, charging for
an internal service provider,

123
00:06:48.037 --> 00:06:52.039
if I'm the IT department,
working at an IT department of a company,

124
00:06:52.039 --> 00:06:55.353
you might not actually charge
your customers formally.

125
00:06:55.353 --> 00:06:57.386
You don't have an accounts receivable for

126
00:06:57.386 --> 00:07:00.220
those people using your email
service inside the company.

127
00:07:00.220 --> 00:07:05.150
So charging is actually considered in
some environments and optional activity.

128
00:07:05.150 --> 00:07:09.200
You don't necessarily have to formally
create charging mechanisms, right?

129
00:07:09.200 --> 00:07:11.870
You will have budgeting,
you will have accounting.

130
00:07:11.870 --> 00:07:15.180
And if you're an external service
provider trying to make money,

131
00:07:15.180 --> 00:07:19.764
then you're gonna to come up with a way
to charge people and get money from them.

132
00:07:19.764 --> 00:07:23.530
So, accounting is the actual spend,

133
00:07:23.530 --> 00:07:29.260
budgeting is the projected spend, and
charging is the ability to recoup money

134
00:07:29.260 --> 00:07:34.260
as appropriate to the service provider,
all right?

135
00:07:34.260 --> 00:07:36.260
The note you see here if you
look at the full screen.

136
00:07:36.260 --> 00:07:40.970
The note you see here, it's kinda small
but basically, keep in mind that financial

137
00:07:40.970 --> 00:07:46.236
management is a subset of corporate
management, financial management that is.

138
00:07:46.236 --> 00:07:52.305
It's not that IT tells finance how they're
going to do it, it's the other way around.

139
00:07:52.305 --> 00:07:56.553
The finance department tells IT how
they're supposed to manage their budgets

140
00:07:56.553 --> 00:07:57.850
and their accounting.

141
00:07:57.850 --> 00:08:02.029
That's gonna be a corporate decision
Right, with corporate governance.

142
00:08:02.029 --> 00:08:07.747
What Financial Management for IT services
adds is the new ones in specificity for

143
00:08:07.747 --> 00:08:11.279
managing the finances of IT services,
right, so

system needs to be able to do some math.

376
00:22:16.360 --> 00:22:17.097
What are we spending?

377
00:22:17.097 --> 00:22:20.382
What is the difference between budget and
accounting.

378
00:22:20.382 --> 00:22:24.870
So budget variations and
evaluation's gonna be part of it.

379
00:22:24.870 --> 00:22:29.150
Information management is not a trivial
matter for any of these processes.

380
00:22:29.150 --> 00:22:33.280
Again, this is probably going to be a
process that's governed more by corporate

381
00:22:33.280 --> 00:22:38.330
systems of information than IT
systems of information, but

382
00:22:38.330 --> 00:22:42.210
you're still gonna be driving these things
through a financial management regime,

383
00:22:44.570 --> 00:22:48.440
and finally,
critical success factors and KPIs.

384
00:22:48.440 --> 00:22:50.660
A critical success factors for
financial management for

385

have a framework to manage

386
00:22:55.630 --> 00:22:58.930
financial information that's
related to your IT services.

387
00:22:58.930 --> 00:23:00.060
So come up with your standards.

388
00:23:00.060 --> 00:23:01.440
Come up with your policies.

389
00:23:01.440 --> 00:23:03.440
Make sure you have regular reports.

390
00:23:03.440 --> 00:23:08.630
You can measure the success of your
financial processes through those reports.

391
00:23:10.280 --> 00:23:11.970
Funding.
Is funding available to support

392
00:23:11.970 --> 00:23:13.160
service provision?

393
00:23:13.160 --> 00:23:14.850
Are we spending the right amount of money?

394
00:23:14.850 --> 00:23:16.320
What is your budget variance?

395
00:23:16.320 --> 00:23:19.360
What is your predicted
spend versus actual spend?

396
00:23:19.360 --> 00:23:21.100
Are you meeting those kind of targets?

397
00:23:21.100 --> 00:23:24.190
Those are kind of KPIs that could underpin

398
00:23:24.190 --> 00:23:26.830
the critical set factor
related to funding.

399
00:23:30.160 --> 00:23:32.730
Challenges, as we've talked about before,

400
00:23:32.730 --> 00:23:37.290
are risk that have 100%
chance of happening.

401

So when you consider financial
management for IT services,

the focus on cost of infrastructure,

403

404

It's one thing to understand that a server

405
00:23:53.250 --> 00:23:56.430
that it cost so
much money to have licensing.

406
00:23:56.430 --> 00:23:58.600
That's one aspect of it, but

407
00:23:58.600 --> 00:24:03.370
to boil all that information up to say,
how much does a service cost?

408

What did your learning management
service cost you last year?

410
00:24:08.120 --> 00:24:09.610
>> That's a little more work.

411
00:24:09.610 --> 00:24:10.746

412
00:24:10.746 --> 00:24:11.331
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

413

>> Cuz you got to boil up a lot of

417

>> I think you'd have to use some kind of
an org analysis tool, like Wireshark, and

simply define it by protocol.

419

Yeah, that's manual labor, yeah.

420
00:24:29.550 --> 00:24:32.070
>> Come up with some way to do it,
yeah, absolutely, manual labor.

421
00:24:32.070 --> 00:24:33.180
It's not a trivial matter.

422
00:24:33.180 --> 00:24:33.780
>> Right.

423
00:24:33.780 --> 00:24:36.005
>> So
if you want to get service valuation,

you got some homework to do because you

425
00:24:40.269 --> 00:24:42.986
Perhaps a portion cost
across multiple services.

426
00:24:42.986 --> 00:24:49.825
Introduce so equitably, fairly, and
meaningfully, and ultimately predictably.

427
00:24:49.825 --> 00:24:53.945
So it's a good game play and
even its a aspirational for

428
00:24:53.945 --> 00:24:58.423
a long period of time,
in other words, your not quite there

429
00:24:58.423 --> 00:25:03.194
moving towards this target is
very valuable, very valuable.

430
00:25:03.194 --> 00:25:05.700
Good, roles and responsibilities.

431
00:25:06.930 --> 00:25:10.465
As we've talked about before, we have
process owners and process managers.

432
00:25:10.465 --> 00:25:15.155
Certainly you want to get ahead of this

So the activities of financial management

day basis.

You need to have management on top

438

That's Financial Management for
IT services.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Terry address how the process of Business Relationship Management contributes to SOA practices. The lifecycle stage emphasized in this show is service strategy. A complete overview of the purpose, objectives, scope and importance of BRM as a process to generate business value is explored and demonstrated using examples. BRM policies, principles, concepts, activities, methods and techniques are explained in relation to SOA practices.

1

>> Welcome, ladies and gentlemen,

Agreements series.

8
00:00:16.577 --> 00:00:17.280
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

9

We're taking a look at

16

This is the last in this series

17

And as Cherokee said, it's called

18

And it's kind of ironic that it's the last

Business Relationship Management is going

So if we have a look at the slides,

24

Using the vocabulary of ITIL,

25
00:01:03.359 --> 00:01:07.423
the main purpose of Business Relationship
Management is to establish and

26
00:01:07.423 --> 00:01:09.770
maintain the relationship, right.

27

Now, I think it's gonna be useful as we
learn this process that we considered

28
00:01:15.680 --> 00:01:19.430
that it's probably not an end to end
process, it has a beginning and end.

29
00:01:19.430 --> 00:01:22.590
It's probably often I mean,
it's probably just always active, right?

30

>> Well Terry, as we were covering
some of the other services,

00:01:25.420 --> 00:01:28.832

S, o I could see how it's integrated and

not just in one particular area but

>> Good point,
consider portfolio management.

35

Service Portfolio Management is trying
to link services to business value.

36

A lot of the feedback that's gonna go

37

a service is gonna be generated by having
a relationship with the business, right?

38
00:01:53.010 --> 00:01:56.755
So BRM is certainly gonna be involved in
feeding the value chain, if you will,

39

Business Relationship Management

00:02:24.240 --> 00:02:27.260

We've talked about
the role of service owner.

00:02:29.660 --> 00:02:33.180
A service owner is someone that's gonna

So that role of service
owner in some regards

00:02:36.680 --> 00:02:40.590

00:02:40.590 --> 00:02:43.310
So again a couple tell-tale things there,

business relationship

54
00:02:45.990 --> 00:02:48.095
Not necessarily an end-to-end process.

00:02:48.095 --> 00:02:52.081
And BRM is probably practised by lots

56

So, it's not one monolithic role

58

Now, that said,
as you're taking an exam, you might see

Business Relationship Management

61
00:03:08.315 --> 00:03:11.995
You can certainly see distinguished
characteristics between these roles and

62
00:03:11.995 --> 00:03:12.965

00:03:12.965 --> 00:03:16.155
But just keep in mind that there's
probably gonna be lots of practitioners

64
00:03:16.155 --> 00:03:16.735
for BRM, right?

65

The objectives of BRM also

66

What's the customer want?

67
00:03:23.550 --> 00:03:24.410
Are we delivering it?

68

69
00:03:27.090 --> 00:03:28.610
What do they want and are we delivering?

70
00:03:28.610 --> 00:03:31.108
Now this idea,
is the customer always right?

71
00:03:31.108 --> 00:03:36.660

72
00:03:36.660 --> 00:03:39.660
But we know that that's is
not a survey always true.

73
00:03:39.660 --> 00:03:41.510
>> So interesting you bring that up.

I actually read a statement from a CEO

00:03:50.930 --> 00:03:56.020

00:04:14.240 --> 00:04:16.620
they actually had a lawsuit

00:04:16.620 --> 00:04:22.410

a return policy for new purchases and

83
00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:25.720
then they're also accepting returns

84
00:04:25.720 --> 00:04:31.230
But in the statement from the CEO,
he said he wasn't going to go ahead and

00:04:31.230 --> 00:04:34.860
put out a blanketed apology
because he feels at this point

his company really didn't need to do so.

And I just thought,

00:04:47.460 --> 00:04:48.470
>> Of course it is.

And, so to answer the question,

00:04:51.090 --> 00:04:53.605
I think we could certainly
find a circumstances were,

00:04:53.605 --> 00:04:55.890

94
00:04:55.890 --> 00:04:58.830

95
00:04:58.830 --> 00:05:01.854
With your internal service provider or
one selling IT services for

96
00:05:01.854 --> 00:05:04.770
profit, if you don't have customers

97
00:05:04.770 --> 00:05:08.345
if you don't have happy customers

98
00:05:08.345 --> 00:05:10.708
>> Or start a Facebook group about your-

totally tarnish your reputation.

100
00:05:11.901 --> 00:05:13.550
>> Right.
>> Good point, right?

101
00:05:13.550 --> 00:05:19.680
So to understand that perhaps the customer
is not always right is fair and fine.

102
00:05:19.680 --> 00:05:23.550
But to understand that their perceptions
are going to matter to you is also fine.

103
00:05:23.550 --> 00:05:27.300
So if they're not quite right, you're

104
00:05:27.300 --> 00:05:31.830
So I mean the dangers in not
managing expectation are large.

105
00:05:31.830 --> 00:05:36.390
If they think it's going to do x and it
only delivers y and you've talked passed

00:05:36.390 --> 00:05:39.990
each others to those requirement stages,
then you're gonna have a dissatisfied

00:05:39.990 --> 00:05:42.845

108
00:05:42.845 --> 00:05:46.465
The classic,

00:05:46.465 --> 00:05:48.975
not what they needed or
not what they wanted.

110
00:05:48.975 --> 00:05:49.575
>> Yeah.

111
00:05:49.575 --> 00:05:50.145
>> Right?
So

00:05:50.145 --> 00:05:52.525

And BRN, Business Relationship Management

116
00:06:03.190 --> 00:06:06.490
Okay, so the scope of BRM

118
00:06:11.550 --> 00:06:16.550
This principles apply certainly
Internal Service Provider of the BRM

process facing the customers is

00:06:21.380 --> 00:06:25.160

00:06:26.190 --> 00:06:28.940

get the customer's money, right?

122
00:06:28.940 --> 00:06:31.970
So that makes the relationship a little
bit different because you're selling

00:06:31.970 --> 00:06:33.240

00:06:33.240 --> 00:06:37.100

that you have to be concerned about

125
00:06:37.100 --> 00:06:40.760

what you intend to do for

126
00:06:40.760 --> 00:06:45.370
them that's different,
then they could get elsewhere, right?

127
00:06:45.370 --> 00:06:51.004
Is it cheaper, is it faster,
is it better, etcetera, okay.

128
00:06:51.004 --> 00:06:53.822
So another key distinguishing
characteristic here,

129
00:06:53.822 --> 00:06:56.884
is looking in the box down below,

00:07:00.780 --> 00:07:04.060
We've talked in previous episodes

00:07:19.880 --> 00:07:23.840
Very specific objective
measurements are in place,

137
00:07:23.840 --> 00:07:26.190
that's what service level
management is about.

138
00:07:26.190 --> 00:07:29.930
BRM is gonna be a little bit more on

139
00:07:29.930 --> 00:07:30.810
How is the utility?

140
00:07:30.810 --> 00:07:32.650
Does the functionality work for you?

141
00:07:32.650 --> 00:07:35.260
Are you selling more widgets
because of what we got here?

142
00:07:35.260 --> 00:07:37.470
Those types of things.

143
00:07:37.470 --> 00:07:40.880
So there's a lot of salesmanship
almost in BRM, you're glad handing,

144
00:07:40.880 --> 00:07:44.360

there is a little bit of that.

145
00:07:44.360 --> 00:07:46.500
But there's also the follow through,
right?

146
00:07:46.500 --> 00:07:49.415
So Service Level Management,
managing the objective,

147
00:07:49.415 --> 00:07:52.767
Business Relationship Management,
managing the subjective.

148
00:07:52.767 --> 00:07:54.940
There's a good way to distinguish
between these two processes.

149
00:07:54.940 --> 00:07:58.977
And both have interface with customers,
all right.

150
00:07:58.977 --> 00:08:01.722
All right, so why do this?

151
00:08:01.722 --> 00:08:04.714
Why formalize your business
relationship management?
